headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp.'s Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind our listeners that during the call, m
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp.'s Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind our listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by the SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measures can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com, by selecting the press release regarding the company's fourth quarter 2015 earnings.
Before turning the call over to Marc Holliday, Chief Executive Officer of SL Green Realty Corp.  [Operator Instructions]. Thank you. 
I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, and I appreciate everybody calling in this afternoon to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. Before we jump into it, I just want to mentioned that Andrew Mathias is going to be joining in by phone from the orthopedist's o
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, and I appreciate everybody calling in this afternoon to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. Before we jump into it, I just want to mentioned that Andrew Mathias is going to be joining in by phone from the orthopedist's office with cell phone in hand, because he sort of suffered an injury, but wouldn't let that hold him back from the call. And Steve Durels also calling in remotely, but available for Q&A, as I guess the stress and tension of an active year-end and beginning of January took a toll on him physically as well, but wouldn't keep him from the call either. So we are all here and just want to express our enthusiasm about the operating performance that we ended 2015 on a relative high note. As I think, most of you had an opportunity to see at the investor conference in December, we're feeling very good about the fact that our buildings are extremely well leased and generally well leased, with below-market rents that are ticking up 15% to 20% in some cases in the recent quarters. We have a modest amount of lease expirations in the coming years, and that is matched with a modest amount of debt maturities, which -- both of which were actively managed over the years to make sure that leading into markets where things are more uncertain. We have good tenure of lease maturities and good tenure of debt maturities. We are substantially complete with our redevelopment projects at 280 Park, 10 East 53rd Street; smaller project over at 16 Court Street. The important aspect there being: a, the buildings are all well positioned now like the rest of our portfolio; and b, all of that capital is now behind us. And speaking about capital, the remaining capital to fund for the Viacom and city leases are now reduced in the aggregate to under $200 million, which will be spread over the next few years. So that number has also been mitigated to a great extent over time.
Turning first, what I'd like to do is hit some of the questions and topics that have been raised in some of the analysts' notes that we've seen in the past 24 hours or so, and then open it up to Q&A.
So I guess beginning with Manhattan leasing market, office market in particular. We ended the quarter with 416,000 square feet of leasing at a mark-to-market rents that were up about 20%. So, obviously, a big end to the year. We're very happy with that. I think that was sort of on or ahead of schedule. We slightly exceeded our 2.2 million square feet of velocity for the full yea, but you should recall that we did advertise a pretty significant pipeline of leasing activity during the investor conference. And obviously, now we continue to capitalize on that pipeline not only through December but also in January. We've announced some leases as of yesterday, some big deals and a good way to kick off the New Year with Omnicom, Music Choice and Nordstrom, along with some other leasing in January, that brings the total -- the first month of the year to about 310,000 square feet of leasing in January.
So clearly, that is us executing on that pipeline. And now obviously, we're very focused on continuing to build that pipeline for future quarters. 
As a footnote to the Omnicom deal, because we got the question, it does represent a reduction in space at the news building, but we are actively working on a lease to absorb the remaining space. So I think we feel pretty good about where we are positioned with that space and that asset at this time.
Even after that December-January activity, the pipeline still stands today in excess of 1.1 million square feet, with more than half of that amount, consisting of leases that are either out for signature or are in advanced stages of negotiation.
So that leaves us this year with about 800,000 square feet left to lease on a portfolio of nearly 30 million square feet. That is  obviously a very small and manageable amount for us to be handling this year. Therefore, a lot of our attention, a lot of Steve's attention and Steve's attention will be focused on the expirations in 2017, where at the moment, exploration stand at about 1.7 million square feet. But I do want to add that the pipeline I mentioned earlier consists of about 650,000 square feet of leases that expire in '17. So obviously, one month into the year, we are already working hard on mitigating and reducing 2017's exposure. In '18, we go back to a more normalized -- below normalized expiration amount of 1 million square feet. So I think we feel very good about '16, '17 and '18 where we stand in terms of availabilities, pipeline. Our portfolio was 97.1% leased over that extraordinary amount of space, which, I think, is a real achievement and a real testament to this team to be able to keep these buildings at such a high level of performance.
With all of that said, we look at the current market environment and look at how we think it may affect job creation going forward, and how that may turn -- in turn translates into demand for space. And I would say that those 2, which are highly connected, we expect to see a bit of a rollback in job creation for the first time in the past 4 or 5 years in New York City, and I'll get into some stats on that. And in turn, that, that will have an impact on leasing velocities which we do expect will begin to slow sometime in the second half of the year.
So I think, as far as we are concerned with the guidance we had given about 45 to 50 days ago at the investor conference, we still feel like all of that was somewhere between priced in or forecasted into our goals and objectives for the year. And we still feel very good about where we stand, both for leasing velocity for 2016, about 2 million square feet mark-to-market, which we set a very high bar for ourselves on the same-store NOI and leasing velocity. Looking at the portfolio where we stand almost a month into the year, we feel good and can affirm those levels for sure. But we do see headwinds that we think are fairly -- should be fairly expected for an economy that has been producing greater than 2% job growth for 5 consecutive years, that is -- far outpaces the numbers nationally. It also far outpaces historical normative in New York City. And whereas last year, 2015, there was about 87,000 or 88,000 private sector jobs created in New York City, about 30,000 of which we were office-using. We would expect that number to still be significant, but probably more in the order of 50,000 to 60,000 jobs created this year, and hence 12,000 to 16,000 office-using jobs created in 2016. So by historical standards, in excess of 1% job growth, still a very good number, but it does reflect a slowing of this unprecedented rate of growth, as I think businesses sort of catch their breath over 4 or 5 years of significant expansionary period. But with these numbers, we do think that absorption will stay positive, and that we'll be able to maintain our rent spreads and our occupancy levels.
Looking at the retail leasing market and what we've been able to accomplish there, we're joined today by Brett Herschenfeld who fields some comments. Brett, as you recall, you saw in the investor conference, leads our SLG retail division and will have more to say. But I think that the retail is generally still very positive aspect and is positive part of our strategy for 2016. Although, as we had said and probably for 12 to 18 months now, we do see signs of slowing sales in certain condos, in certain of these submarkets, most notably some of the luxury branded retailers, maybe on Fifth and Upper Madison, are experiencing sales that would prevent these rents from continuing to rise. Whether or not there will be any pullback in rent is yet to see, but our embedded retail rents across the board are about 100% below market. That's a number that you should recall from the investor conference, 100% below market. So whether the rents stay the same, go up a bit, or even pullback 5% or 10%, I would say to you that there's still significant, significant upside in the retail portfolio. We're still very bullish about the prospects of meeting our growth objectives, which last year, it was $30 million in the growth portfolio; this year, it's about $32 million in the growth portfolio. And then I think for the 5 years thereafter, we projected something in the order of $45 million or so incremental, mostly out of the growth in retail portfolio. So that, I would say, is still highly achievable whether the rents are at market, whether there's a slight pullback in that market. We still have very good demand in retail as you saw with that 40,000 square foot plus Nordstrom lease we're able to sign at 3 Columbus. I think that's a great mark. You saw we got the Armani deal done back in end of November, beginning of December, at rents for Upper Madison -- Upper East Side Madison that are very, very reflective of today's market rents. Soho, I think is kind of a tale of 2 areas, but some of the products along Broadway is probably losing a little bit of velocity, but on the side streets, where we focused on Green Street and Spring Street and elsewhere, we still see very, very good demand from the smaller retailers for those kind of boutique and unique spaces. And I think we'll have more to say about that this year as we continue to lease up assets, like 110 Greene Street and

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: and 102 Greene Street.
componenttext: and 102 Greene Street.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: 102 Greene Street. So those are real bright spots. I don't think we really have a retail exposure of any note other than 650 Fifth, which we continue to work on, had been to the finish line a couple of times on that, but haven't yet crossed the finish lin
componenttext:
102 Greene Street. So those are real bright spots. I don't think we really have a retail exposure of any note other than 650 Fifth, which we continue to work on, had been to the finish line a couple of times on that, but haven't yet crossed the finish line. So that's one asset we hold in a joint venture out of the myriad of assets we own in retail where we'll be working hard this year to get at least. But the rest of it, I would say, is either put to bed or has significant, significant upside, given our low basis in those assets and the low rents in place. 
Looking at the investment market. 2015, you recall Isaac Zion saying that we had record volumes. I don't have the number in front of me, but I want to say, with an excess of $60 billion of commercial transaction activity [indiscernible] and there was more transactions that rounded out the year in December. And I know our constituency likes to look at just what's of the moment, not what happened 3 or 6 or 9 months ago. And in that regard, I would point you in the direction of 4 sort of interesting transactions, all of which we believe are either -- well, all under contracts, for the most part. I don't think any are closed yet. 
This 1285 Sixth, which is a deal that Scott Rechler was doing, which is, I think, a very good down the middle deal for Scott. It was -- it's a 4.4%, 4.5% stabilized -- going-in yield and stabilized yield. So it's about a 4.5% cap going in. It's under 1,000 foot, 950 a foot for Sixth Avenue product and a large transaction, so in that large transactions of $1.7 billion or more can still get done and capitalized in this market. 787 Seventh there, again, going-in yield about 4.5%, 4.6%, which is similar to the yield that we were able to achieve on 11 Madison. But here, we look at 787 is having above-market rents. And we think that there'll be pressure in execution to keep those yields at those levels, as opposed to on 11 Madison deal, which was contractually there with upside and no downside. The per foot there was $1,150 a foot for that deal on Seventh and that's $1,950,000,000 purchase price. Then we have 2 other deals, which may not be quite as well known or appreciated by our shareholders, and these are very recent. 853 Avenue is a deal that's being done, at least our -- what our reconnaissance tell us, this is around $875 a foot, a sub-3.5% going-in yield. There will be real work there to kind of rework that tenancy in order to get up to a 5% or 5.5% or so stabilized yield, but that would be some time now, probably 5 years or more out in time. And that's the deal, that's about $460 million of price. And lastly, 405 Park is rumored to be under contract at a purchase price of $240 million. But more importantly, at a price per foot of $1,450 per foot, stabilized basis, we project it'll be closer to $1,600 per foot. That was about a 3% going-in yield. And I would say, this transaction doesn't just flatter 280 Park, it picks it up and puts it on a pedestal. So the investment market, as evidenced by those 4 deals, I would say, is still alive and well. Although, like with the leasing market, we put a caveat here. We do expect a slowdown in the transaction volume. We certainly do not expect the record levels that we saw last year or anything close to it. In part, that's going to be particularly due to, what we think, will be some softness in the areas of condos and hotels, where we think that this market will probably take a more strict view of pricing with respect to those assets. However, just to draw a distinction, we do think that well-leased and well-located commercial assets will still be in demand. I would even use the words "high demand" because there's still few and far between and there's still a lot of equity looking to invest in this market, they're just going to be very particular now about the kinds of assets they want to be in. And for those high-demand assets, I think, cap rates will remain exactly where they were in that 4% to 4.5% range, or even in some cases, 3.5% to 4% to 4.5% range for the best assets.
However, further on these commercial assets, there are the transitional types of assets that require significant redevelopment, reposition and leasing execution. There we would expect hurdle -- IRR hurdle rates, not cap rates, but IRRs to increase maybe 50, 75, maybe even depending on location, 100 basis points in threshold returns for these sort of transitional assets.
So clearly, I think that the deals I just rolled you through and our view of the market flatters the 11 Madison deal even more so. I said in the investor conference, I thought it was one of the best deals this company has ever done, because it's a high-quality asset with high-quality tenants. The financing was put away long term at 4%, limited downside and very significant long-term upside. Not only that, but it allowed us to get out of some of these transitional assets, where I think that there will be more market headwinds this year. So our timing, I think, was excellent, both on the [indiscernible]. I think our sales were well executed. And all in all, I think it certainly bears out the strategy that we've laid out for everybody. 
Look at acquisitions and dispositions now for 2016. I just want to address this issue. I've seen a lot of reports about net acquirers.  We tackled the question in the investor conference, I want to hit it on here. I'm sure I'll get it again in Q&A. When we put up numbers for goals, those are gross numbers, gross numbers, gross means gross of joint ventures. So $1 billion of acquisition is $1 billion of product, it's not $1 billion of wholly-owned product. As you know, we do wholly-owned and we do joint ventures, like Tower 46, a joint venture. 10 East 53rd was a joint venture. Those are 2 of our recent -- more recent office asset buys.
So when you see $1 billion of acquisition and $700 million of dispositions, or $750 million dispositions, that does not imply $250 million of equity issued nor debt leverage up. It just doesn't. What it implies is that we believe that during this year, we might see 1 or 2 interesting opportunities to exercise on them maybe. And if we do, we'll do it in a way where they are either funded entirely by sales or with JV equity period. There is no -- should be no ambiguity about that even though we continue to read about expanding the balance sheet or levering up or issuing equity, none of which, we did as part of last year's what we called room work, nor would it be part of this year's business plan. I don't think we've issued equity since the first quarter of last year. 
So that's been a concern. I would sort of take that concern off the table in terms of whether or not we're going to be net acquirers or not. I think it's going to be a neutral position, and whether we do the full $1 billion or not, that will sort of be dependent on the opportunities we see in the market. It's easy to say, well, when the market gets tight, don't do anything. We don't exactly agree with that. We think that you have to moderate your investment approach. Recall that the Citibank building, 388-390 Greenwich was a deal we closed on, I believe, in December of 2007, okay? And we made a lot of money on that deal, both in terms of total return and capital gain. So you have to be choosy, you have to be creative, you have to make sure it's well capitalized. But I think a blanket statement that no deals get done would be inconsistent and not the right thing to say nor is anyone buying that this is an expansionary market for SL Green. We're going to be very, very discerning on our purchases as we always are at this point in the market. In 2007, I think, we did literally 2 deals, that one and the small other; 2008, nothing; and 2009 or '10, again, because you can't just sit on your hands, we did 510 Madison Avenue debt deal, which turned out to be one of our most exceptional DPE assets we ever did. We were first, we were early in that sort of cycle of upswing. So I think we're going to -- I think we're doing the right things on the acquisition side, and I think there's the opportunity to make good deals. But if we don't see them out there, then you won't see the acquisitions across the tale [ph], and we'll be focusing, I guess, instead on simply dispositions. 
So on the dispositions front, there's one, in particular, to take note of that 380-390 Greenwich, which we talked about at the investor conference as being: a, highly likely to occur; and b, part of our capital plan. I did see in 1 or 2 reports the word "surprise", surprise exercised by Citi. There can be no surprise. There can only be what we say in that investor conference about the high likelihood of Citi exercising in December, turned into an actual exercise in January. And the reason why we are fancied at deal a, it allows us to close out a very profitable position -- investment position we took in the asset. But 2, it will result in a reduction of indebtedness gearing of one full term. So between $1.45 billion of debt and this $350 million of net equity paydown or thereabout net equity proceeds, there will be about 1 full turn of debt reduction associated with that resolution of asset. Not a surprise because that's we put that there as kind of a pro forma investment as to how the gearing gets, not only to where our leverage levels were in 2015 at the beginning, which were already reduced, but gets reduced further. 
Second, we have other sources of equity that we would look to capitalize on this year, either for reinvestment or further debt reduction beyond 380-390. And clearly, 11 Madison, again, no surprises, I said on the call right after we purchased it, that it was one particular asset that we might JV -- re-JV after purchase. If we do that, there is no tax impediment to a joint venture. It's set up as a tick, so it's relatively easy to joint venture of that asset and still maintain the tax protection that we structured in the balance of the investment. And it's the kind of investment that has attraction in good markets and bad. There are other assets we are looking at now that we can sell in this market, that we'll still receive a very good reception from foreign and domestic investors, that I think you will see us execute on as part of reaching our goal for the year. But on one hand, while the market orients into those kind of assets in terms of dispositions, it will make us choosier and pickier in other assets where there's more execution and this may not be the right time to optimally sell those assets, in which case, we'll just continue to hold those for the future or execute upon them ourselves.
Lastly, before I open up for Q&A because I know this is an unusually long introduction, we have One Vanderbilt. There were literally questions about whether there's any update in leasing status in what we did 45 days ago. I don't know what to say to that other than reiterate what I said in December, which is, "This is an asset that tenants will be taking possession of sometime generally in late 2019 and '20." Therefore, at the end of 2015, beginning 2016, it's far too early for most of these tenants to make that kind of space commitment. Most of the larger tenants today are looking for space commitments at around 2018, early '19. And One Vanderbilt is not intended to be designed for the 1 million square-foot user. It's more in line for the 50,000 to 400,000 square foot user. Those kind of users make their decisions later in the cycle, generally 2 to 3 years in advance of possession date, such that the lead of the leasing for One Vanderbilt will likely be in 2017 and '18.
So that's where we are in that. In terms of funding plan for One Vanderbilt, we laid out a funding plan in December. I was asked whether we changed our funding plan. So the answer is no, we haven't changed the funding plan. It is still our plan to obtain construction financing in the first half of this year and then joint venture financing in the second half of the year. I would imagine 45 days from now we'll say the same thing, although, obviously, we do adapt as the markets adapt. However, I want to just go a little further, not only on the plan but on the numbers, to give you a sense of how confident we feel in the execution of One Vanderbilt. Given the monies we already have invested in the project, all the monies through the end of '15 and the $230-some-odd million we project to expand out of cash flow in 2016, we should need to fund beyond that no further equity into the deal once we obtain construction financing and JV financing. We have modeled it in a way such that the balance of the project, which is the bulk of the construction, will be funded out of a conventionally structured construction loan and roughly a 50% JV partner. That would require not only no money invested into the deal after the end of this year, but actually will result in money back to SL Green as kind of profit, if you will, over and above our invested basis.
So that is what we'll call Plan A. The Plan B would be a construction financing. We sell other assets, and we would have the ability to fund the remaining equity over the ensuing 4 or 5 years, essentially out of cash flow. There would be no need for equity issuance or lever up beyond the construction loan to fund the equity portion, because we generally fund out of this company $200 million to $250 million or more of redevelopment or development capital annually. And that would be an amount sufficient over that period of time to fund the balance of the equity in the event we couldn't or to chose not the JV asset. However, the reception, we believe, in the market for partners for this asset is exceptionally strong, and therefore, we think plan A is far more likely than plan B. 
So with that said, we'll take some more questions on that at the end of -- in the Q&A session. But that is how we see having that One Vanderbilt project funded in a way that puts no liquidity pressure on the company whatsoever. 
So with that, I'd like to open up for Q&A.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from David Toti with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from David Toti with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. Marc, it's an unusually cautious tone from you relative to the tone that we heard in December. What are some of the indicators that are giving you a bit more pause at this point in the year?
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. Marc, it's an unusually cautious tone from you relative to the tone that we heard in December. What are some of the indicators that are giving you a bit more pause at this point in the year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, in terms of the cautious tone, I would say, it's more market-driven. If you look at the last 45, 50 days in the market, there's obviously concern, I'd say, I think predominantly about potential bank exposure to the energy sector and what tha
componenttext: Well, I mean, in terms of the cautious tone, I would say, it's more market-driven. If you look at the last 45, 50 days in the market, there's obviously concern, I'd say, I think predominantly about potential bank exposure to the energy sector and what that might mean in terms of earnings visibility and whether or not that will result in some kind of people contraction. So, I think, the investor sentiment, in general, has degraded substantially over the past, call it 50 days or so, even though the property metrics, if you will, have not. There's still -- we see very good access to debt financing. So we think projects will be -- better projects will be refinanced in this market. There is a lot of equity capital out there but still looking for investment, and it's intended demand for the first  month of the year was good and the pipeline remains. However, I would say, for -- what I'll say out of -- I don't know-- out of favor or more secondary tertiary assets, either asset classes or transitional assets, I think, as the financing becomes tougher to obtain for those kinds of projects, you're going to see those kind of projects back up a bit, but I don't think that's going to affect our portfolio in almost all respects.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could just ask a follow-up. If we extrapolate that view of the market in the coming year or 2, the transaction markets, does this speak to relatively stable cap rates and property values in your mind in the Metro New York City market,
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could just ask a follow-up. If we extrapolate that view of the market in the coming year or 2, the transaction markets, does this speak to relatively stable cap rates and property values in your mind in the Metro New York City market, particularly for your asset type?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I think you really got to parse asset type, which is what I tried to do in those opening remarks. I think that for the well-located, high-quality assets, the answer is, absolutely. In the 2% treasury environment, the kinds of returns that can be ma
componenttext: Again, I think you really got to parse asset type, which is what I tried to do in those opening remarks. I think that for the well-located, high-quality assets, the answer is, absolutely. In the 2% treasury environment, the kinds of returns that can be made on these core assets are still going to be, we think, very attractive to real estate investors, and demand will remain high for those assets. There are other assets -- because real estate is a broad term in New York City, there are other asset classes and are other asset profiles, which, I think, will -- you'll see cap rates and/or certainly IRRs increase may be IRR thresholds increase 50 to 100 basis points for hotels, condos and I'd say, commercial assets with a lot of execution and redevelopment. But I think this is where quality gets parsed. I don't think it affects our portfolio. By and large, retail and commercial is extremely high quality and I think we'll be a net beneficiary of that market.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Nick Yulico here with Ross. Can you just go through what's going on with the sale process for assets right now, whether you're still looking to sell 1745 Broadway and so what's the status on that?
componenttext: This is actually Nick Yulico here with Ross. Can you just go through what's going on with the sale process for assets right now, whether you're still looking to sell 1745 Broadway and so what's the status on that?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that given the notice that we received in January on the sale of 380-390, we're kind of reevaluating all of that. As it relates to -- reevaluating our whole disposition program for the year because that one is so sizable. With that said, 174
componenttext: Well, I think that given the notice that we received in January on the sale of 380-390, we're kind of reevaluating all of that. As it relates to -- reevaluating our whole disposition program for the year because that one is so sizable. With that said, 1745 is in the market. We're negotiating offers on that deal. And I guess, we'll have more visibility on that during -- in between now and the next call or by the next call. With that and other assets that we are in dialogue with, that we think it would be the best asset to sell in this market. Because, again, there's a lot of demand out there, but the profile of what you sell changes somewhat, because we're always looking to sell, not just sell for the sake of selling but sell whatever we think is accretive to our NAV, which is matchlessly accretive to stock price, because the stock price is a fraction of NAV.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, just I guess on overall sales -- and you're thinking about getting money in as you're debating doing an acquisition or using that money to deleverage, I guess, how are you weighing those 2 options based on your outlook now for the overall
componenttext: Okay. And then, just I guess on overall sales -- and you're thinking about getting money in as you're debating doing an acquisition or using that money to deleverage, I guess, how are you weighing those 2 options based on your outlook now for the overall economy and in the investment market? And then also on the Citi sale, how are you thinking about that? You talked about you could deleverage from that process, but you're also going to be losing NOI. So how are you thinking about the FFO dilution impact there?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that -- I mean, FFO dilution, you're taking a 2018 trip there because the FFO -- I mean, that sale is scheduled for the end of '17. So it's certain. It's money in the bank. But it's -- I mean, there is a lot of growth in this portfolio. I mean, I hope
componenttext: No, that -- I mean, FFO dilution, you're taking a 2018 trip there because the FFO -- I mean, that sale is scheduled for the end of '17. So it's certain. It's money in the bank. But it's -- I mean, there is a lot of growth in this portfolio. I mean, I hope that came across in December the amount of embedded growth we have in the office portfolio, the growth portfolio, the retail portfolio. So we're only now talking about '16. I assume, even hope we'll have additional growth in '17 and '18, such that whatever the diminution is from 388 as a result of paying down the mortgage and the proceeds to pay down the line is sort of just a factor of our overall plan, as we continue to increase NOI and all other assets and keep overall growth trajectory going forward. So I don't think any 2018 dilution from Citi is factoring into our decision today to use all of those proceeds for debt reduction, which I mentioned earlier to you would be about one full turn of gearing of reduction. What was part at the end of the question? I didn't [indiscernible].

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was just as you're thinking about -- if you have a bunch of assets potentially earmarked for sale this year, how do you think about that money as it comes in weighing, deleveraging the balance sheet today versus buying an acquisition?
componenttext: It was just as you're thinking about -- if you have a bunch of assets potentially earmarked for sale this year, how do you think about that money as it comes in weighing, deleveraging the balance sheet today versus buying an acquisition?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the same way we always we want to. We've set goals for deleveraging, so we'll -- the way we presented that plan is we'll continue to pay down debt, with asset sales where we can most efficiently, meaning there's no major tax impediment in doing so.
componenttext: Well, the same way we always we want to. We've set goals for deleveraging, so we'll -- the way we presented that plan is we'll continue to pay down debt, with asset sales where we can most efficiently, meaning there's no major tax impediment in doing so. Sometimes, we have significant capital gains that you can simply do without having to pay out, I guess, the stock dividend, which is an option and something we'll look at but something we haven't done in the past. And then when we get to the levels we feel are the right gearing levels at the end of the cycle, then we're looking for a very opportunistic investment. So the thresholds rise. You're looking for very opportunistic investments, which we always generally are. And they're few and far between. I know people like to think in choppy markets, that means there will be a plethora of deals. It shows this market is so solid right now generally, and you saw it a lot in '08, '09. Over a half of the inventories owned by 12 or 15 of the best capitalized players in the city, so you just don't get these sort of highly distressed situation. So my point is if you see 1 or 2 this year or next year, it doesn't matter, if you see 1 or 2 really solid deals and you act on them because they just don't come along that often. But I guess the default assumption is that most of the money raised through -- capital raising activities is going to reduce the line of credit, which was there as our source of liquidity to grow the portfolio and take advantage of the market over the past 4 or 5 years.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marc, just going back to kind of the change in tone here for December to today, maybe it's quite a bit more bearish. But I think -- I thought I heard you say that you're not really moving away from the outlook that you projected back in December. I'm just
componenttext: Marc, just going back to kind of the change in tone here for December to today, maybe it's quite a bit more bearish. But I think -- I thought I heard you say that you're not really moving away from the outlook that you projected back in December. I'm just curious why that is given the much more subdued sort of tone out there and expectations of a slowdown in the back half.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you'd have to look at each of the metrics. But I guess -- because we still think we're going to be able to achieve the metric. And it's -- the mark-to-market on leasing, I think, we had pegged around 13% to 16%, and we still feel we're going to end
componenttext: Well, you'd have to look at each of the metrics. But I guess -- because we still think we're going to be able to achieve the metric. And it's -- the mark-to-market on leasing, I think, we had pegged around 13% to 16%, and we still feel we're going to end up there. So I guess the question, why would -- you can't really alter that if you still think that's where you're going to end up. I mean, looking at the mark-to-market we have, on the $1.1 billion in pipeline, it's very significant, so probably in excess of that. So -- and looking at same-store NOI, which we put out there, a very healthy number, I think it was around 6%. We feel good about the 6%. So I think you're -- I wouldn't take these comments about the market generally and sort of the -- where I think there'll be differentiation in the market with our portfolio and product on the light side of that differentiation as any indicator or reason that we would be modifying or coming off of the achievements, the financial performance we think we'll be able to achieve this year. So I guess we're not modifying, we still feel confident in where we sit.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is it fair to say, though, that your outlook for the market has deteriorated since then, so I mean the conditions under which you made that outlook were somewhat different from a market perspective?
componenttext: Okay. Is it fair to say, though, that your outlook for the market has deteriorated since then, so I mean the conditions under which you made that outlook were somewhat different from a market perspective?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say I think the market has deteriorated, and I think that we see a differentiation in this market. And because of that, we see opportunity, both in the DPE program, maybe down the road, 1 or 2 asset buys. I had described the $1 billion of acquisit
componenttext: I would say I think the market has deteriorated, and I think that we see a differentiation in this market. And because of that, we see opportunity, both in the DPE program, maybe down the road, 1 or 2 asset buys. I had described the $1 billion of acquisition, which was an aspiration goal at the time, as 1 or 2 opportunistic investments. So I don't think that's changed. I mean that's how we looked at it. I think that the composition of what we may sell will change because I think different assets will sell better in this market, so that may change. But the aggregate volumes, we're not revising. And most importantly, I think from a portfolio and company performance level, when we're looking at things like expenses, margins, leasing volumes, occupancy, mark-to-market, NOI, we feel very, very strong about that. So remember, New York City projects 60,000-plus of new job growth. That's a very positive market. I just want to -- it's not a -- I would not use the term bearish market. If the city is going to grow by 60,000 private sector jobs, that would, in most markets, be, in most time periods for New York City, considered very solid and enviable. It's just not at the same level it was last year. Those are stats we've recently come across. And I've always said that we tend to look at the job growth stats as kind of a leading indicator. So with that, I think it is a precursor, if you will, or at least a look into what will still be positive absorption, but potentially a slowing leasing market in the second half.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You had a very active quarter on the D&PE book. Can you talk about the spike in volume in the fourth quarter, especially given your more cautious comments about the market? And then also, it looks like your exposure per foot rose meaningfully for the juni
componenttext: You had a very active quarter on the D&PE book. Can you talk about the spike in volume in the fourth quarter, especially given your more cautious comments about the market? And then also, it looks like your exposure per foot rose meaningfully for the junior mortgages and mezzanine debt. Just how should we think about your appetite for risk and volume in that book if we are heading into weaker times?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think I said -- this is David Schonbraun. I think I said at Investor Day, sometimes the results are lumpy. I think Q3, we had very low originations. And Q4, you just saw a normalized kind of origination level kind of look for the year. So I wouldn
componenttext: Look, I think I said -- this is David Schonbraun. I think I said at Investor Day, sometimes the results are lumpy. I think Q3, we had very low originations. And Q4, you just saw a normalized kind of origination level kind of look for the year. So I wouldn't read into Q4 volumes as anything happened other than Q3 we had a bunch of deals that didn't close in Q3 and had slipped into Q4. So from a level standpoint, I think we're running exactly where we always have. And I think the type of product has been consistent. I think we did a lot of -- most of the ones we did were a whole lot originations where some of them we sold off senior pieces, some we held. I think we have tended to stay more senior in the capital stack and take less risk and maintain our yields which I think has been a stated goal of ours. And I think that's going to be consistent in this year. So I think we have a pretty healthy pipeline right now. I think yields has held firm but we've really tried to go consistent with last year and take a little bit less risk while maintaining yields and not try to outperform on yields that get kind of the 8.5-plus percent yield while taking the minimum risk to get there.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then how should we think about the buyer exposure per foot for junior mortgages and mezz. I mean it's up meaningfully. Does that mean you think asset values are higher or it's a mix?
componenttext: And then how should we think about the buyer exposure per foot for junior mortgages and mezz. I mean it's up meaningfully. Does that mean you think asset values are higher or it's a mix?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it just depends on what we originate. So I won't read into it. I don't think it's -- it may be because we did a couple of retail deals that drive the value. So I think if you would get us a homogenous pool, it's a little tough. I think we probably
componenttext: I think it just depends on what we originate. So I won't read into it. I don't think it's -- it may be because we did a couple of retail deals that drive the value. So I think if you would get us a homogenous pool, it's a little tough. I think we probably did more retail plays in the fourth quarter, which is a sector, I think as Marc and Brett said we love. so I think those have higher per foot but probably may have less inherent risk, so you may just be seeing that come through.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just thinking about your risk appetite. It sounds like you're more willing to pull back than get more aggressive here.
componenttext: Okay. And then just thinking about your risk appetite. It sounds like you're more willing to pull back than get more aggressive here.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's been consistent with how we run the program and consistent with what you saw last year, which is it's all about risk-adjusted return and us finding the right -- what we think is the most mispriced piece in the stack. If that's mortgage, senio
componenttext: I think it's been consistent with how we run the program and consistent with what you saw last year, which is it's all about risk-adjusted return and us finding the right -- what we think is the most mispriced piece in the stack. If that's mortgage, senior mezz, junior mezz, that's where we look upon.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from John Guinee with Stifel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from John Guinee with Stifel.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question, I guess, is you guys have been on the FFO treadmill for a lot of years now, also doing pretty well on a value creation. If you can only go one way, are you going to continue to push FFO or are you going to focus more on value creation?
componenttext: A question, I guess, is you guys have been on the FFO treadmill for a lot of years now, also doing pretty well on a value creation. If you can only go one way, are you going to continue to push FFO or are you going to focus more on value creation?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, John, I think we're always pushing value creation. The FFO, I think, is a byproduct of that. But we're in the business of investing capital and making money. We try to do it in a way to have recurring and replicable FFO. And I think we've done tha
componenttext: I mean, John, I think we're always pushing value creation. The FFO, I think, is a byproduct of that. But we're in the business of investing capital and making money. We try to do it in a way to have recurring and replicable FFO. And I think we've done that about as good as anyone in the sector with an FFO that will be approaching $7 a share this year, and the lion's share of that coming from stabilized commercial portfolio. So I don't think we invest to create FFO but, obviously, we invest to create cash flow and profits, and FFO is a result of that. But I think we're always trying to be very selective about what we buy. I think that's why we have the portfolio we have today, which is, I think, second bar none in terms of quality and positioning. And we also are probably the most active recyclers of capital, so that we're always generally looking first to monetizing gains and reinvesting them to drive value which, in turn, drives FFO. So I think they're very connected, if you will. But the DPE book is always a constant as it relates to the aggregate amount of our real estate portfolio. And that -- those proportions don't really -- haven't changed over the years and don't change much. And if we're going to invest incremental capital this year, it will be done very selectively, whether it's in commercial assets or the DPE book to make what we think will be outsized returns or -- and then only once we are at the sort of the leverage levels that we have set out as targets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then refresh my memory, where are you in terms of total cost for One Vandy and cost per square foot? Have you given guidance on that yet?
componenttext: Great. And then refresh my memory, where are you in terms of total cost for One Vandy and cost per square foot? Have you given guidance on that yet?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me -- give me a second because I have that here. I think it's sort of an interesting stat. So One Vanderbilt depends -- there's book balance, there's cash balance. The asset is carried on our books at a grand total of $133 per gross square foot,
componenttext: Yes. Let me -- give me a second because I have that here. I think it's sort of an interesting stat. So One Vanderbilt depends -- there's book balance, there's cash balance. The asset is carried on our books at a grand total of $133 per gross square foot, and I think that's $227 million. That's the book balance. In terms of invested capital to date, or I should say through 2015, that number is $433 million or $250 per square foot, both of which, I think or hope you would agree, is a very, very attractive basis for us to own that land. It gives us complete flexibility, if you will, with respect to the future because we have a very low basis in it. We don't generate cash flow from it, so there's nothing in our current or future numbers. That's an important point, actually. In all the growth numbers we've shown, we've never shown any incremental NOI growth from One Vanderbilt. So the project, it will either be capitalized in a way I mentioned earlier, which would require essentially no further out-of-pocket from SLG, or build it out of cash flow, which I don't think we'll be in a position of having to make that decision, or you can sit on it for a time without any pressure or effect. Not many developers have development sites with that kind of inherent flexibility with no debt and no joint venture pressure to have to perform and meet and no earnings to have to support. So it sits on the balance sheet at very low levels. It has an investment level at a very low level and it gives us the flexibility, which is why we're very comfortable with it.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your total development cost, is that 1,500, 1,600, 1,700 of square foot as of today?
componenttext: And your total development cost, is that 1,500, 1,600, 1,700 of square foot as of today?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Rob Schiffer is not here at the moment. We put up a development budget at the IC, and I want to say it was about 1,000 a foot for construction costs. And you can, obviously, add to it what we have sunk into the deal, which is the numbers I just ga
componenttext: I think Rob Schiffer is not here at the moment. We put up a development budget at the IC, and I want to say it was about 1,000 a foot for construction costs. And you can, obviously, add to it what we have sunk into the deal, which is the numbers I just gave you. And then we have some soft cost and leasing and everything beyond.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tony Paolone with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tony Paolone with JPMorgan.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marc, in an environment where you think leasing may slow in the second half of the year, do you think office rents for the market went end up, flat, downward? Where do they go from here?
componenttext: Marc, in an environment where you think leasing may slow in the second half of the year, do you think office rents for the market went end up, flat, downward? Where do they go from here?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as long as leasing absorption stays positive, I would say at a minimum, it should be flat. I would have otherwise said up except you have incremental supplies, so that would keep -- you have incremental demand, incremental supply, that should keep r
componenttext: Well, as long as leasing absorption stays positive, I would say at a minimum, it should be flat. I would have otherwise said up except you have incremental supplies, so that would keep -- you have incremental demand, incremental supply, that should keep rents, I think, for at least '16, at the levels they currently are, which is why we're modeling a mark-to-market consistent with last year's as opposed to something higher. Does that make sense or...

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, I mean it sounds flattish, I guess.
componenttext: Okay. Yes, I mean it sounds flattish, I guess.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it sounds -- well, again, it sounds flattish because of incremental supply. But yes, because the point is where you want to -- where you would look to declining rents would be when you have significant job loss, which is not at all being forecasted
componenttext: Well, it sounds -- well, again, it sounds flattish because of incremental supply. But yes, because the point is where you want to -- where you would look to declining rents would be when you have significant job loss, which is not at all being forecasted as part of this cycle right now. But yes, I would say flat. It could be up. It could be -- I mean -- if you said it will be up 3% to 5%, that wouldn't surprise us. That's possible. So it's sort of property-specific. Because we're so leased, we'll have the opportunity to push those marginal rents higher than we normally would because we have very little space available and not a whole lot expiring so -- and a lot of other landlords during that same situation. So we will, certainly, be responsive to the market, but we're also holding our rents and can push those rents.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question, the 3 Columbus and 280 Park, I know you have partners on those, but it does seem to be rounding the corner than now. What would you guys want to do with those? Like do you keep them? Do you try to sell? What are the plans t
componenttext: Okay. And then second question, the 3 Columbus and 280 Park, I know you have partners on those, but it does seem to be rounding the corner than now. What would you guys want to do with those? Like do you keep them? Do you try to sell? What are the plans there?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think both assets are long-term holds. So I don't -- it's not a part of the current thinking on asset dispositions in either of the two of those.
componenttext: I think both assets are long-term holds. So I don't -- it's not a part of the current thinking on asset dispositions in either of the two of those.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Marc, just given where your stock is trading this year, as well as your CDS spreads and your debt, are you considering deleveraging further than the 8x debt-to-EBITDA that you projected by year-end?

componenttext: Well, I think the projections we put up with Citi had us below 7.6. So I guess the answer is yes because that's what we put up in December. It was I think 7.5 or 7.6. Matt?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would say that's still the target. We could go below that as well. But the target is not 8.0, it's 7.6.
componenttext: So I would say that's still the target. We could go below that as well. But the target is not 8.0, it's 7.6.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. 7.6 is pro forma 2017? But I was wondering if there was any thought of deleveraging quicker than that.
componenttext: Right. 7.6 is pro forma 2017? But I was wondering if there was any thought of deleveraging quicker than that.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think that, certainly, if we wind up reinvesting or utilizing all the proceeds of our expected sales to retire debt, then it'll be quicker than that and further than that, if you will. So the answer is certainly something we would do and co
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think that, certainly, if we wind up reinvesting or utilizing all the proceeds of our expected sales to retire debt, then it'll be quicker than that and further than that, if you will. So the answer is certainly something we would do and could do if, based on the assets we sell -- and again, the only sort of asterisk there is to what degree is the tax implications on what we're selling. Some assets have modest tax implications; others, we've created such enormous embedded gains that they tend to -- it's more efficient if you will, to reinvest in the 1031 the way we usually do because selling assets and paying down debt works if you're not making any money, but if you're making sizable capital gains, then you've got sizable taxes to pay.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you commented on the potential increases in IRRs for transitional type of assets. But I was wondering if you had any comment on trophy assets as far as exit cap rates because I think, earlier this year, exit cap rates are being underwritten
componenttext: Okay. And then you commented on the potential increases in IRRs for transitional type of assets. But I was wondering if you had any comment on trophy assets as far as exit cap rates because I think, earlier this year, exit cap rates are being underwritten at 50 basis points higher than going in for trophy type of asses.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're going to see no change in trophy cap rates.
componenttext: I think you're going to see no change in trophy cap rates.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Even with the job growth slowing?
componenttext: Even with the job growth slowing?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Even with job growth slowing. These are -- I mean, trophy assets to me are the premier assets in the city which, generally, are well leased and long-term leased. So an incremental job growth in 2016 is sort of meaningless for the asset. There are people t
componenttext: Even with job growth slowing. These are -- I mean, trophy assets to me are the premier assets in the city which, generally, are well leased and long-term leased. So an incremental job growth in 2016 is sort of meaningless for the asset. There are people that just are looking to put core money to work. The interest rates are low. I mean, the debt market -- the spreads have tapped out, but swaps and treasuries have declined, such that financing rates are still extremely low relative to those cap rates and IRRs. And because of that, we still see, at the moment, pretty heavy investor demand. I think the message is, I'll keep repeating so, hopefully, people come away with it, is that it will be selective. And the best assets, I think, will be -- we still continue to be at these record levels, if you will, or most desired levels throughout the year. Unfortunately, our portfolio falls primarily into that bucket.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Manny Korchman with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Manny Korchman with Citigroup.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman with Manny. Two questions. The first is just on One Vanderbilt. And Marc, I certainly appreciate your comments that in option 1, using joint venture equity as well as construction loan, you wouldn't have to put any more capital. I'm
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman with Manny. Two questions. The first is just on One Vanderbilt. And Marc, I certainly appreciate your comments that in option 1, using joint venture equity as well as construction loan, you wouldn't have to put any more capital. I'm just curious, as you're thinking about that project and investing that extra $1.7 billion of capital, at what point do you make the decision to move completely forward? Is it at pre-leasing level or is it at a date? Because I do think that there is even, if you use joint venture in a construction loan, still some concern in the marketplace that you're going to move forward with an extraordinarily large development in an uncertain market and one where, clearly, your more subdued comments today would give people more pause. And so I think I'm just trying to understand when and in what sort of environment you would fully move forward with this?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the environment into which -- today is really not the environment in which we're leasing into. So you really have to look at what's the environment in '17 and '18 when we would expect the bulk of the leasing to be done. So with regards to a go-no go
componenttext: Well, the environment into which -- today is really not the environment in which we're leasing into. So you really have to look at what's the environment in '17 and '18 when we would expect the bulk of the leasing to be done. So with regards to a go-no go, to me it's about capitalization and risk mitigation. So to the extent you've got long-term and low-cost construction financing in place, that gets you into the 2020s. So I mean, this market becomes like an asterisk to the relevant market for this asset, which is 5 to 6 years forward, and you have your JV equity in place such that we would have no further equity commitment. So without a financing risk and without any further equity component, that makes it easier "to move forward" than not. So I think that the level of leasing will be known in '17 or '18. So I would say, at least on a spec basis, that's the date on which we'll be reassessing -- or assessing the project. But I'm very confident that, that project is going to be met with extraordinary demand on both the debt equity and leasing market. Just -- the meetings we've done to date have kind of codified for us, if you will, just how well received this product is going to be. But again, it's for a much future market. So I think the issue is predominantly capital risk mitigation, which is really in the form of equity bringing in a JV partner.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions here. The first is, over the past several years, we've had a number of market swoons where there's been extended volatility, whether it's last August or previously back in '13. Given large financial firms haven't really been active growers,
componenttext: Two questions here. The first is, over the past several years, we've had a number of market swoons where there's been extended volatility, whether it's last August or previously back in '13. Given large financial firms haven't really been active growers, so it's been either smaller financial or this social media or advertising or other industries, can you just give a sense of -- as far as tenant discussions, how right now is different that's made you more subdued versus what happened last August when people panicked over China or in prior sort of market meltdowns?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve Durels, are you...
componenttext: Steve Durels, are you...

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me -- you got to put things in context. Marc was commenting as to where there are headwinds and speculation as to what we may face throughout the year, that's one point. But as we sit here today, coming off of a very strong fourth quarter and goi
componenttext: Yes. Let me -- you got to put things in context. Marc was commenting as to where there are headwinds and speculation as to what we may face throughout the year, that's one point. But as we sit here today, coming off of a very strong fourth quarter and going into the first quarter, we haven't seen any letup on the leasing, so we've got a very full pipeline. And we've probably got as better diversification on the types of tenants than we've seen in any time in the past. Of the 1,100,000 square feet of pipeline transactions that are active either in term sheet negotiations or leases out, it runs the gamut of big deals with insurance firm, health care, advertising, legal, information services and financial. So a very, very broad spectrum of tenants that we're in active discussions with.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as far as the leasing slowdown in the second half, that's just a general market observation? Or Steve, that's based on your conversations with tenants, you're sensing more hesitancy by people who normally would be in discussions at this point for secon
componenttext: So as far as the leasing slowdown in the second half, that's just a general market observation? Or Steve, that's based on your conversations with tenants, you're sensing more hesitancy by people who normally would be in discussions at this point for second half, where they're not in those discussions?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It hasn't infected yet the conversations at my level. I think we're looking more forward down the line saying if there's going to be moderating job growth, is there sentiment out there that will lead people to pause, then that's a -- later down in the yea
componenttext: It hasn't infected yet the conversations at my level. I think we're looking more forward down the line saying if there's going to be moderating job growth, is there sentiment out there that will lead people to pause, then that's a -- later down in the year. But as we sit here today, the only kind of hesitancy we've seen is on some of the financial service guys, as you would expect, whenever we've seen big gyrations in the stock market then, all of a sudden, you get some of those hedge funds, some of those financial service guys, say, you know what, let's just pause for 30 days, 60 days and see where the world shakes out.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question. On the finance book, what percent of the book are residential or condo conversion opportunities? If it's like an office building where you land and the person wants to do condo conversion or something that would be like tha
componenttext: Okay. And then second question. On the finance book, what percent of the book are residential or condo conversion opportunities? If it's like an office building where you land and the person wants to do condo conversion or something that would be like that. And then what's the split of rental on the residential on your finance book?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] The answer is, as it sits today, we don't have loans on active condo projects and any loans that we have that are transitional either work as office buildings or work for us as multifamily. So we don't tend to make condo loans. The only time we reall
componenttext: [ph] The answer is, as it sits today, we don't have loans on active condo projects and any loans that we have that are transitional either work as office buildings or work for us as multifamily. So we don't tend to make condo loans. The only time we really lend on residentials, we think the fallback is multifamily works. So we're not really long right now. We're not long in condo product as condo products, we're not really long any -- construction as it sits today. We have some land loans that I think sponsors wants to go to condo, but that's -- our basis works out with a very different business plan.

componenttext: Yes, I think that's completely on the table. If we get to a point  where we think that's the best [indiscernible]. Sure. I mean I think it makes sense. We've generally been able to sell into this market with numbers that are far, far in excess of people's models and everything, but consistent with our NAV, which gives us confidence, cements our confidence in our NAV. So I think the implied trading right now is somewhere around 7 to 8 cap, which I think is somewhat absurd and, therefore, you have to look at that -- outline there, Steve, as a strategy is definitely a possibility.

componenttext: Yes. I think it's -- our commentary was in response to inquiry as to whether rents would go up. The question was whether the rents will remain healthy or not. We're in a very strong market. We've had strong velocity in the fourth quarter. Midtown, in particular, had a very strong leasing quarter last -- in the fourth quarter. Our pipeline and the overall velocity of the market remains strong. So I think that, from our perspective, the question is whether or not there's going to be erosion, it's just a matter of how good it's going to be. And if it's not great, it will still be a very solid leasing market for the year.

Some of the European funds are also focused on the city. You got to remember, those are much longer-term players. their view of the market is very long-dated, so we haven't seen any pullback from those players in terms of looking for assets.

componenttext: This is Jordan Sadler here with Craig. On the CMBS market dislocation we've seen over the past 6 months but, in particular, over the -- since your IC. Any thoughts ahead of risk retention coming into play later this year and what that portends for either New York City real estate values or for your structured finance business?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, are you -- I hate to -- I know [indiscernible].
componenttext: Andrew, are you -- I hate to -- I know [indiscernible].

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think everybody's talking about risk retention for sure and nobody's -- there's still a lot of uncertainty in terms of how the rules are actually going to play out. I think it will have less of an impact, frankly, on large New York City assets and
componenttext: Yes. I think everybody's talking about risk retention for sure and nobody's -- there's still a lot of uncertainty in terms of how the rules are actually going to play out. I think it will have less of an impact, frankly, on large New York City assets and a much more direct impact on financing costs for typical conduit product where today that market have gotten rather efficient. And you don't see a lot of conduit loans in New York City because they're all large loans, either single assets or they're sort of dominant pieces of bigger securitizations. I do think that dislocation, one we've been highlighting since the fall, does create opportunity in our structured finance book and, as sizing of senior loans changes due to higher cost and more conservative underwriting or less players in the market, it does generally improve the subordinate debt market and were either taking less risk or able to charge more for our capital. So I'd look for a more impact in the structured finance book than on New York City assets, where I think there's still a very robust commercial bank market, there is a robust CMBS market for large assets. I don't see risk retention really playing that much into those assets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you talk about leasing velocity slowing this year potentially, you mentioned big banks as one group. But when I hit the pause button, are you expecting a slowdown from the TAMI crowd as well? And then as you kind of look out into '17 and '18 and as y
componenttext: When you talk about leasing velocity slowing this year potentially, you mentioned big banks as one group. But when I hit the pause button, are you expecting a slowdown from the TAMI crowd as well? And then as you kind of look out into '17 and '18 and as you sit here today, you mentioned the back half of the year could be tough. I mean just generally speaking, are you expecting a continued slowdown in the rent velocity environment going into '17 and '18?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's hard to predict whether it's going to be -- which industry will experience any kind of slowdown. I think the big banks in particular, the investment banks, we haven't seen them grow in the market, obviously. We've seen them lease space
componenttext: Well, I think it's hard to predict whether it's going to be -- which industry will experience any kind of slowdown. I think the big banks in particular, the investment banks, we haven't seen them grow in the market, obviously. We've seen them lease space in the market and they're in the market right now, but mostly through consolidations or because they're attending to lease expirations. And being able to, quite frankly, forecast where I think any other industry is going to see any slowdown, I don't think I've got that crystal ball. I can only say that as we sit here today, everyone of those industries, whether it be financial advertising, TAMI, the whole -- the biggest sectors in the market, we've got deal flow from those sectors. But I think only time is going to tell as to who feels the pain, if there's a slowdown at all.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So sort of underpinning your kind of outlook for job growth later this year as kind of more of a broad-based impact.
componenttext: So sort of underpinning your kind of outlook for job growth later this year as kind of more of a broad-based impact.

componenttext: Yes, I think that's a big view on the 400 million square foot market, what it does to the overall leasing market and how are we suited to be able to respond to that. And the reality is we've got very little vacancy. We've got a year of very little lease expirations. So we're well defended to handle whatever happens in the marketplace, and we're forward-looking by really attending to a lot of our 2017 expirations as we sit here today.
