componenttext: Okay. And Steve, it sounds like you're seeing pretty good broad-based leasing demand out there today. But just wondering if there's any submarkets or industries or tenant sizes that really stand out as seeing particularly a good amount of activity.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the TAMI sector, whether it's in our portfolio or in the overall market, continues to be a big driver. But Marc, in his opening comments, I think, spoke a little bit about the diversity of tenants. And if you break it down of the deals that we have
componenttext: Well, the TAMI sector, whether it's in our portfolio or in the overall market, continues to be a big driver. But Marc, in his opening comments, I think, spoke a little bit about the diversity of tenants. And if you break it down of the deals that we have in pipeline, it's composed of TAMI being the leader. Health care being a big chunk of it, financial services being a significant player, legal services and then general business services and even government, to a certain extent, are the 5 or 6 major industries. But the top 4 being TAMI, health care, financial services and legal. And I don't think that's really different today than what we were seeing through most of last year, quite frankly. And I think we take a lot of comfort from seeing that kind of diversity.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any submarkets stand out as particularly strong or soft?
componenttext: And any submarkets stand out as particularly strong or soft?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think there's a lot of questions that we get about the West Side, meaning Midtown West, meaning Sixth Avenue in particular. And like a couple of years ago when Sixth Avenue had a bunch of vacancies, Sixth Avenue right now has probably got some of th
componenttext: No. I think there's a lot of questions that we get about the West Side, meaning Midtown West, meaning Sixth Avenue in particular. And like a couple of years ago when Sixth Avenue had a bunch of vacancies, Sixth Avenue right now has probably got some of the biggest deals that are in negotiation. One of the big headline deals that's over there is 0.5 million square feet going to Major League Baseball. So Midtown proper is a very active part of the marketplace. And I think it's active on both East and West and all parts of Midtown. So I think Midtown is more active than Downtown right now, quite frankly. So I mean -- and we're certainly feeling it in our portfolio.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp.'s First Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, mana
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp.'s First Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also, during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com, by selecting the press release regarding the company's first quarter 2016 earnings. Before turning the call over to Marc Holliday, Chief Executive Officer of SL Green Realty Corp. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. 
I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. It's an absolutely glorious day here in New York City. The sun is shining and the stock is up, and we're glad you've joined us for our first quarter earnings call. Andrew Mathias is back in the saddle and with us today after his surgery, and we
componenttext:
Thank you. It's an absolutely glorious day here in New York City. The sun is shining and the stock is up, and we're glad you've joined us for our first quarter earnings call. Andrew Mathias is back in the saddle and with us today after his surgery, and we look forward to answering all of your questions, but first, a few comments on the quarter and the outlook for New York City market. Our Q1 results, by any measure were outstanding and indicative of a company that is firing on all cylinders. By my count, we have done over 70 of these earnings calls since IPO, and there were none that I can remember where the earnings results were so complete and so satisfying. 
On this past December 7, we set out for ourselves a host of intentionally challenging and specific goals and objectives with the hope and expectation of meeting all of them in 2016. On January 27 of this year, against global market headwinds, we reaffirmed our guidance, evidencing the confidence we have in our company, ourselves, our market to continuously deliver superior results on both an absolute and relative basis. This is because our discerning approach to investing in assets with significant growth opportunity and the constant recycling of our portfolio enables us to generate market-leading earnings growth, while also assembling the highest quality property portfolio in New York City.
These activities have resulted in our steadily increasing funds from operations from just $1.70 per share in our first year of being listed on the stock exchange to a normalized amount of approximately $7 per share estimated for 2016, a rate of growth that is unsurpassed in our industry sector.
Overall, New York City remains extremely solid, notwithstanding the dislocations we saw in the financial sector in December, January and the first half of February, volatility that has since leveled off. New York is often perceived to be heavily dependent upon the financial services sector for jobs and office-based demand. The reality, however, is that New York is, by far, the most compelling, diversified and resilient commercial property market in the country, possibly the world, and continues to attract businesses and investment capital, notwithstanding where we are at any one point in time in the market cycle.
Further, New York City's dependence on the financial services industry has been reduced, as other industry segments have proliferated, such as media, technology, education and health care. In fact, the financial services industry's contribution to incremental leasing absorption has fallen in recent years from 34% of square footage leased to 24% of square footage leased over the last 5 years, thereby, reducing occupancy risk if that sector were to shed jobs, though we have not witnessed any material shedding. Population, tourism and job growth continue in New York City, with industry profiles more diversified and less reliant on any one sector than ever before.
The first quarter numbers coming out of the Bureau of Labor Statistics were surprisingly strong for the first quarter, as New York City added net new 38,000 private sector jobs, 11,000 of which were in the office using sectors of business services, fire, the fire sector and information, and that's just in the first 3 months. Obviously, if that pace continues into the second quarter, the city would have to revisit its 2016 forecast for private-sector job creation, which was reduced by then to a still healthy total of 50,000 net new jobs earlier in the year when they revised that number. But as I said earlier, almost all of that job creation has been experienced in just these 3 months. 
While the city estimate is lower than the record-setting growth rates over the last 5 years, millions of square feet of positive office space absorption are still expected, and we have come out of the gate strong in 2016 with 850,000 square feet of Manhattan office leases signed in the first quarter alone at a remarkable 39% cash rent mark-to-market. Furthermore, in the first 21 days of April, just 3 weeks, we have leased an additional 72,000 square feet of Manhattan office space, and the near-term leasing pipeline is similarly growing with 1.3 million square feet of Manhattan leases in active leasing negotiations out for signature or advanced stages of term sheets. 
We are also very pleased to see that asset values in New York continue to hold up from their record levels in 2015, and demand from both domestic and international equity investors and commercial lenders remain strong, as evidenced by recent activity, which exceeds $6 billion so far, notwithstanding the market pause that we saw in January and February. Investors will be more discerning this year and certain asset classes, like residential condominium projects, hotel and land, will see values fall as investors concentrate on well located, income-producing assets with embedded growth opportunity, the kind of assets that dominate SL Green's portfolio. Non-core or transitional office assets may see some downward pricing pressure, but as money continues to flow to quality Manhattan commercial assets, it is likely that their values will remain relatively steadfast. 
From an overall investment capital perspective, we are seeing a continued flow of money from foreign investors, sectors that we had highlighted over the past few months and on the last call, Japan, China, Korea, Germany, Canadian money and still money coming from Middle East. These are investors and nations that regard New York as the safest and most attractive place to invest and diversify their holdings. A number of overnight reports made reference to our Q1 results being evidence of a solid New York City market, and certainly, that is a major contributing factor. But the much bigger story, in my opinion, is the way in which we have positioned SL Green to be a dominant force with this market and sector and to drive earnings and increases in shareholder equity, while running an investment-grade portfolio and investment-grade balance sheet that represents less than 40% loan-to-value on a consolidated basis. We have strategically fortified our company by upgrading and diversifying our portfolio through selective acquisitions and dispositions, expanding business lines, but within our market, and by operating the portfolio with a focus on long-term leases, high occupancy levels, low annual lease role and high credit quality tenants. 
Despite our many successes, one significant frustration that we share with all of our investors is a stock price that does not merely reflect those accomplishments, does not correspond to the current value of our underlying assets and undervalues the substantial additional growth embedded in our portfolio. For our shareholders, we will work relentlessly to illuminate value, continue our earnings progression, invest opportunistically, manage our liabilities and build substantial liquidity.
I want to thank you, and we'll open it up for questions.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Manny Korchman from Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Manny Korchman from Citi.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marc, if we just look at the forecast and the actual job creation, do you think they were just sort of light on the forecasting? And maybe do you have any idea on why they have been light on the forecasting earlier in the year? Was it just a scare because
componenttext: Marc, if we just look at the forecast and the actual job creation, do you think they were just sort of light on the forecasting? And maybe do you have any idea on why they have been light on the forecasting earlier in the year? Was it just a scare because of volatility or were there other deeper trends going on, and now you think that those have abated a little bit?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that there's -- the environment, as it's played out, was probably different than when the forecast were being made, and they might have been a little too conservative going into it. So we'll see how it plays out, the year's only 3 months ove
componenttext: Well, I think that there's -- the environment, as it's played out, was probably different than when the forecast were being made, and they might have been a little too conservative going into it. So we'll see how it plays out, the year's only 3 months over. But I think they were looking at downward estimates of GDP. They were looking at what the effect of the minimum, $15 minimum wage was going to have on jobs in the city. And I think that they -- you have to remember, at 50,000 jobs, it's still by most accounts an extraordinary -- extraordinarily high number. So I don't think they were looking at it as being conservative or fearful or concerned. I think that was maybe misinterpreted on this call 3 months ago, that a 50,000 job creation number in the private sector is somehow a number that has a negative connotation to it. To the contrary, it's a strong number. Now will the city exceed that? Clearly, if it stays on the path it's on, it will not just exceed it, it will blow it away. But these things have a seasonality fostered to it. And you have to, I think, let more than 3 months past to see exactly where things level off, but clearly, sitting here through what hopefully was -- will be the worst part of the market for us, I haven't seen that kind of robustness, not only evidence from the jobs numbers, but in the leasing statistics, gives us much better confidence as we sit here today.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe switching to One Vanderbilt, was hoping you could give us an update on where you are in discussions for both the JV on that project and construction financing, and maybe a leasing update as well if you have anything.
componenttext: And then maybe switching to One Vanderbilt, was hoping you could give us an update on where you are in discussions for both the JV on that project and construction financing, and maybe a leasing update as well if you have anything.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let's cover One Vande. So we'll bring in Steve and Andrew and others as part of the conversation, but I just want to...[Audio Gap]say to you that this is going to be the premier project, probably in the city, maybe the world, when this is comple
componenttext:
Okay. Let's cover One Vande. So we'll bring in Steve and Andrew and others as part of the conversation, but I just want to...
[Audio Gap]
say to you that this is going to be the premier project, probably in the city, maybe the world, when this is completed. That's how we feel about this project. And that's the kind of feedback we've gotten from every single player we have presented this to. Now in terms of the financing, the financing is going exceedingly well. We still are on track for what we hope will be a closing and completion by the end of the summer, which is what we said on the last call. And then following that, we will focus in on equity capitalizations from JV partners, understanding that we get calls daily on this. We have a queue of potential interested investors that's not measured in the dozens. It's measured in the 50 to 100, and it's a matter of us being very deliberate about -- going about this very long-term project to make sure we get it exactly right. And the first order of business is the financing and completion of the demolition, and the beginning of excavation, which starts this summer, the finalization of our marketing materials, which are spectacular, and which many of our investors will get to see in December. And then getting out on the road and finding the right equity investor for us, we're committed to finding a partner for this project. I am confident we will have more than one party to choose from at the end of the day, and we'll be basically just bidding terms for who we think brings the most to the table beyond just capital at the end of the day. So with that, let me turn over to Steve on the leasing side. What do you -- what's your update there?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are presenting the building on a very regular basis to tenants. It gets rave reviews at the end of every presentation. I don't think we've ever been involved with a project where the presentation to prospective tenants is so well received. Our single g
componenttext: We are presenting the building on a very regular basis to tenants. It gets rave reviews at the end of every presentation. I don't think we've ever been involved with a project where the presentation to prospective tenants is so well received. Our single greatest challenge, quite frankly, is that we're 5 years out as far as being able to deliver. So that's very early in the time line for tenants to be able to make decisions. Notwithstanding that, we present this building to significant sized tenants. If not once a week, sometimes as many as 2x to 3x a week. The majority of those tenants are either financial service related-type businesses or very high end, international headquarters type companies, and I think that as -- time will tell. But we have 3 or 4 tenants that are doing active diligence on the building. And I feel personally very, very confident about where we stand in the lease up process.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, any change in strategy. I don't think there was a change in strategy. I think that there were a number of things that came together for us in some cases earlier, in some cases, accelerate to future years. Crdit Suisse, exercising renewal options f
componenttext: Well, any change in strategy. I don't think there was a change in strategy. I think that there were a number of things that came together for us in some cases earlier, in some cases, accelerate to future years. Crdit Suisse, exercising renewal options for 170-some-odd-thousand square feet at 11 Madison was unexpected and not modeled and a huge boost, I think, a positive sentiment on the market. Huge boost for the assets, and I think it really cements exactly the reason why we think 11 Madison is as great as it is. And we had a very significant pipeline going into the first quarter. You heard me say that on the last call, and a lot of it converted, and Steve, I don't know, there's no change in strategy, per se, just...

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not at all. I think that's the point. We had a very full pipeline of not just prospective tenants. But since the fourth quarter of last year, we've had a significant number of leases that have either been ready for execution or have been in advanced s
componenttext: No, not at all. I think that's the point. We had a very full pipeline of not just prospective tenants. But since the fourth quarter of last year, we've had a significant number of leases that have either been ready for execution or have been in advanced stage of negotiation. And the stars aligned and we ended up converting a bunch of those transactions over. And the good news behind that is that even with those conversions, we've been able to refill that pipeline.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There were some local reports that asking rents had declined in certain buildings. Did that help your cause at all?
componenttext: There were some local reports that asking rents had declined in certain buildings. Did that help your cause at all?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think that had anything to do with Q1. There were 2 or 3 buildings where we had pushed rents extremely hard. At Tower 46, 10 East 53rd. And in those projects, we probably brought those back $10 or so, still well ahead of vendor underwriting. But y
componenttext: I don't think that had anything to do with Q1. There were 2 or 3 buildings where we had pushed rents extremely hard. At Tower 46, 10 East 53rd. And in those projects, we probably brought those back $10 or so, still well ahead of vendor underwriting. But you don't really know where the market settles unless you push. And then if you find you pushed a little too far, then you recalibrate back. There's excellent activity on those 2 projects. But I don't think that had anything to do with Q1.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to clarify some of that. The -- where we adjusted some rents on those spaces that we had pushed rates ahead of -- arguably ahead of the market, those adjustments were done on a select handful of spaces on only a few buildings. So it was not all
componenttext: Yes, just to clarify some of that. The -- where we adjusted some rents on those spaces that we had pushed rates ahead of -- arguably ahead of the market, those adjustments were done on a select handful of spaces on only a few buildings. So it was not all buildings and not all spaces by any stretch of the imagination. In fact, at the same times we had -- that we moderated some, we actually increased the rents on some of our other space. So it's really got -- that stock got lost in the mix.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say to the contrary, our experience had been increasing construction cost leading up to, let's say, middle or end of '15. My expectation is you're going to see a leveling off, or in certain of the trades, possibly a slight decrease in construction
componenttext: I would say to the contrary, our experience had been increasing construction cost leading up to, let's say, middle or end of '15. My expectation is you're going to see a leveling off, or in certain of the trades, possibly a slight decrease in construction cost relative to what we had projected. Because I'm going to say, for One Vanderbilt, we took kind of a trend line of increases, which was substantial and then like added 5% of your compounders on top of that, and then to significant contingency on top of that. So I mean we're kind of set for whatever the market may bring. But I think that the reality maybe that we may catch a break here along with others, building during this time period over the next few years of possibly pricing that we hope will be right on target and maybe we can bring it inside. So no, we don't see that.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, you have to remember, most of our vertical construction here is in '18 and '19. And I think if you sort of survey the trade now, there's a little bit of concern about how much of a backlog they're going to have for '18 and '19, whereas they're very
componenttext: John, you have to remember, most of our vertical construction here is in '18 and '19. And I think if you sort of survey the trade now, there's a little bit of concern about how much of a backlog they're going to have for '18 and '19, whereas they're very busy, very engaged now building out a lot of residential projects. There's some concerns that on the back end of that, there may be some excess capacity, which we intend to take advantage of on pricing.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just broadly, can you walk us through the acceleration of the 388 Greenwich deal and why that was moved up early? Was that really sort of the buyer driving that or was it more of a call on with forward market conditions?
componenttext: Just broadly, can you walk us through the acceleration of the 388 Greenwich deal and why that was moved up early? Was that really sort of the buyer driving that or was it more of a call on with forward market conditions?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that it was -- the buyer probably had more of a desire than we did. From our perspective, the deal was inked, and whether it close next year or this year and we collect the earnings now or over time, I think we were somewhat indifferent.
componenttext:
Well, I would say that it was -- the buyer probably had more of a desire than we did. From our perspective, the deal was inked, and whether it close next year or this year and we collect the earnings now or over time, I think we were somewhat indifferent. I think we had heard a message from certain shareholders that now better than later, if the economics makes sense. But I would say that we were equally happy or willing to go along with the midyear, end of year close or as scheduled. So I would say more or less, there was certain advantages probably for the buyer in this case, which drove the transaction. For us, it worked out.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, just one more actually, which is more of a strategic question for you, Marc. And obviously, you're still pretty bullish on Metro New York City and confident in market fundamentals. If we were to go into weaker market conditions and we can sort of le
componenttext: Well, just one more actually, which is more of a strategic question for you, Marc. And obviously, you're still pretty bullish on Metro New York City and confident in market fundamentals. If we were to go into weaker market conditions and we can sort of leave that open ended, how would your capital recycling strategy change in the context of maybe lower rent growth or less sort of investor demand? Would we see significant shifts in activity?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say, David. I mean, we are the most active capital recyclers, right, by far. We sell, I think, certainly, by number of properties, more in a year than any of our REIT peers. So I guess the question is if the market outlook worsens, how would
componenttext: It's hard to say, David. I mean, we are the most active capital recyclers, right, by far. We sell, I think, certainly, by number of properties, more in a year than any of our REIT peers. So I guess the question is if the market outlook worsens, how would that affect sale? I guess, to the extent the market for sale is still there, but our outlook is worse than other investors, then you would continue to sell. I mean, that would be the natural inclination. If everyone is on the same issue, then it becomes harder to sell, so your sales volumes may take a pause until the market gets better. So we typically look at things -- when a property is ready for sale, when you feel it's matured to a level that it's ripe to be harvested, it doesn't have any further strategic value for us or the ability to drive NOI over a 5- to 10-year period is below the average trend line for the portfolio, we will be much more readily desirous of either selling or JV-ing that asset and we do that constantly. I mean, we do it annually and we do it in size. So I think if -- we'll continue to do that, I guess the answer to your question will be we'll continue to do it, provided the market is there to do it. Sometimes, the market isn't there, but right now, it's excellent. There's a lot of demand for New York City assets. I'd say as much demand as there was last year, the demand has just shifted, as I said in my remarks. I think it's a little more discerning. I think it's really focused in highly on quality and income-producing assets. It's in our sweet spot, so we're actively pursuing sale and JV opportunities.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Anthony Paolone with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Anthony Paolone with JPMorgan.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is with regards to the proceeds from the Citi sale, should we think about that as a permanent reduction in debt as we start to think about 2017 estimates now that this will have a full impact on next year or will these proceeds be used to m
componenttext: First question is with regards to the proceeds from the Citi sale, should we think about that as a permanent reduction in debt as we start to think about 2017 estimates now that this will have a full impact on next year or will these proceeds be used to make other investments? Like, how do you think about it?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, it's Matt. So we are going to use the proceeds from the sale for debt reduction unequivocally. In the interim, we are going to pay down our revolving credit facility. And then, in November, we are going to repay the $450 million mortgage on 45 Lexin
componenttext: Tony, it's Matt. So we are going to use the proceeds from the sale for debt reduction unequivocally. In the interim, we are going to pay down our revolving credit facility. And then, in November, we are going to repay the $450 million mortgage on 45 Lexington, which opens up for repayment in November. That's a 5.6% debt position. So it is going to be used exclusively for debt reduction.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, second question for you. If I just look at your first quarter, the $1.85 times 47.40 and apples-to-apples, your guide is $7. I know relative to our model, you kind of beat actually almost every line item. Like, what rolls off in t
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, second question for you. If I just look at your first quarter, the $1.85 times 47.40 and apples-to-apples, your guide is $7. I know relative to our model, you kind of beat actually almost every line item. Like, what rolls off in the next few quarters here?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in the first quarter, Tony, you had $0.12 right off the bat. That was in the first quarter that's not replicable in the second, third or fourth, $0.07 from the repayment of a debt position. We would have recognized that $0.07 over the course of the y
componenttext: Yes, in the first quarter, Tony, you had $0.12 right off the bat. That was in the first quarter that's not replicable in the second, third or fourth, $0.07 from the repayment of a debt position. We would have recognized that $0.07 over the course of the year, has accelerated in the first quarter. We also had $0.05 of one of our favorite topics, FAS 141 income, off 11 Madison that's attributable to '15, 2015. That was in our guidance number, but again, comes during the first quarter, not for the remainder. And as I look through other line items, lease termination income of $3.6 million is a couple million dollars higher than we otherwise project for each coming quarter. So based on that, we said $0.05 given only 3 months of activity so far is a pretty healthy raise, and that's where we ended up.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question is from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, Marc, in your opening comments, I think you talked about you guys focused on relentlessly growing earnings at the same time closing the NAV gap. Given the demand in the market that you spoke about, what's your appetite for maybe sacr
componenttext: Two questions. First, Marc, in your opening comments, I think you talked about you guys focused on relentlessly growing earnings at the same time closing the NAV gap. Given the demand in the market that you spoke about, what's your appetite for maybe sacrificing earnings growth in favor of selling more, crystallizing some of that NAV discount?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's what you're seeing in this first quarter, and probably for most of the second half of last year, was the continued illumination of value typically at prices that we see are well ahead of analyst and shareholder models that bear out, I
componenttext: Well, I think that's what you're seeing in this first quarter, and probably for most of the second half of last year, was the continued illumination of value typically at prices that we see are well ahead of analyst and shareholder models that bear out, I think, the NAVs that I think are intuitive to people. We show it in the December investor, what the implied NAV looks like at market cap rates. You folks on the sell side have your own NAVs, which average about $135 per share through your models, and many of our investors are at that level and higher. So I think that we continue to illuminate that value through sales and we'll do that. Often, I think we've shown an extraordinary ability to: one, recycle that capital into very profitable undertakings; and two, at this point in time, the recycling is less necessary because we have so much extraordinary embedded growth in the remainder of the growth portfolio in our retail portfolio, and just through mark-to-market of our stabilized office portfolio. You don't need to do a lot of investing if you're marking to market on a cash rent basis well into the double digits and you're leasing up retail assets, like we did with Armani, like we did with McDonald's, like we did with Nordstrom's at rents that are in x percent higher. They're multiples higher, 2x 3x, 4x what the expiry rent was. So we have that kind of embedded earnings velocity that will carry us through '16 and '17 and beyond without incremental investment, but obviously, we are -- we do look for incremental investments from time to time.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Marc, if I understand you though, so you're saying that if you guys accelerate dispositions, the embedded growth in the mark-to-market in the growth portfolio is enough that you guys could still have positive FFO growth even if you sell more assets tha
componenttext: So Marc, if I understand you though, so you're saying that if you guys accelerate dispositions, the embedded growth in the mark-to-market in the growth portfolio is enough that you guys could still have positive FFO growth even if you sell more assets than you plan?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the answer is generally yes because we've done it almost every year. But I don't want to make any statements now about '17 because we don't have '17 guidance out on the street. But I think you sort of look back at the history of the company o
componenttext: Yes, I think the answer is generally yes because we've done it almost every year. But I don't want to make any statements now about '17 because we don't have '17 guidance out on the street. But I think you sort of look back at the history of the company over the last 19 years and draw your own conclusion from that, but we are not making now statements about '17 or beyond. We'll do that later in the year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is for Durels.
componenttext: Okay. Second question is for Durels.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, go on.
componenttext: Okay, go on.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you guys leased about 850,000 square feet in the first quarter versus 2.5 all last year. The beginning of this year, the market sentiment was that everyone was on the sidelines pause, given the volatility in the capital markets, and yet, obviousl
componenttext: Okay. So you guys leased about 850,000 square feet in the first quarter versus 2.5 all last year. The beginning of this year, the market sentiment was that everyone was on the sidelines pause, given the volatility in the capital markets, and yet, obviously, leasing was very strong. So could you just help us understand the disconnect, that sometimes, we hear capital markets are upset, and therefore, tenants are on the sidelines not leasing space? And yet, clearly, they were out leasing space in the midst of some pretty rough capital markets activity.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not certain there's a correlation between the capital markets and the fundamentals of the leasing market, per se. But just to start with a couple of data points. One is we've said through the last couple of quarters that we've had a very full pi
componenttext: Well, I'm not certain there's a correlation between the capital markets and the fundamentals of the leasing market, per se. But just to start with a couple of data points. One is we've said through the last couple of quarters that we've had a very full pipeline of transactions. Two, that pipeline had a great deal of diversity in the types of tenants that we were talking about. Three, the feedback that we get from our tenants and prospective tenants as to how they view the health of their business and the hiring prospects, and therefore, the rents -- the space demands, have really not moderated at all over the past year, even as we sit here today, which would explain why even in the face of doing 800,000 square feet, we've been able to then replenish the pipeline. So I sort of think that there was a lot of uncertainty in the market, that people had about what the future held, but the reality is our tenants are still feeling very strong about where their business is, how it's performing, where they're hiring is, and therefore, how much space they need.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question is from Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first question, a follow-up on the leasing. Maybe Steve, could you talk a little bit about price points and just where you're seeing the activity? My understanding is that the really, really high end of the market has really kind of taken a pause
componenttext: I guess, first question, a follow-up on the leasing. Maybe Steve, could you talk a little bit about price points and just where you're seeing the activity? My understanding is that the really, really high end of the market has really kind of taken a pause, maybe north of $125 a foot. I'm just wondering if you could comment on kind of where your pipeline sits today in terms of price point and have you experienced that same thing? And then I guess I wanted to follow-up on the mezz book when you're finished.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I really haven't seen any moderation on deal volume, on the high price point part of the market or in any other part of the market, quite frankly. And maybe the best example of that, although I don't have a lot of product, where I currently have vacan
componenttext: No, I really haven't seen any moderation on deal volume, on the high price point part of the market or in any other part of the market, quite frankly. And maybe the best example of that, although I don't have a lot of product, where I currently have vacancy at $125 or above, but I do have plenty of products that's $80, $90, and $100 kind of space. And maybe the 2 best examples of that of where we're seeing transactional volume is 10 East 53rd Street and Tower 46. 10 East 53rd Street, I'm enthusiastic as I said to Marc and Andrew yesterday. Yesterday alone, we converted 5 tenants over 2 leases out. So all of a sudden, that building, which is $80 to $90 to $100 kind of product, is like on fire. And Tower 46, which is sidestreet, great quality product but sidestreet location, although we haven't cited a lot of deals there yet, we have a tremendous amount of prospective tenants coming through and are trading term sheets with a number of very significant tenants at big rents in the $90 to $100 price point. So we're feeling very bullish about the prospects for that building. And I think those are 2 very good barometers about the strength of the overall market even at a high price point.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess, I noticed that the mezz book did come down by several hundred million dollars. So I'm just wondering is there a strategy at all to try and take that book down? I know there's been some investors that have been a bit concerned about
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess, I noticed that the mezz book did come down by several hundred million dollars. So I'm just wondering is there a strategy at all to try and take that book down? I know there's been some investors that have been a bit concerned about that. And I realized it can be lumpy quarter-to-quarter. But just kind of what are your thoughts on making new investments there, and how do you think about pay offs and maybe shrinking that book?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Definitely, it's more quarter-to-quarter movements than any kind of strategy to reduce the book. To the contrary, we have a very active pipeline right now of new investments. We did sell and syndicate a bunch of investments in the first quarter, so that b
componenttext: Definitely, it's more quarter-to-quarter movements than any kind of strategy to reduce the book. To the contrary, we have a very active pipeline right now of new investments. We did sell and syndicate a bunch of investments in the first quarter, so that brought the house down, and -- but not representative of any sort of broader corporate strategy. We're still very dedicated to that business.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Guinee with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Guinee with Stifel.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: 11 Madison Avenue, I think you bought that about a year ago. You had a while until it got to be stabilized. I think you partitioned it into some tenant and common positions so that you may or may not be able to monetize a -- sell out a JV position. Where
componenttext: 11 Madison Avenue, I think you bought that about a year ago. You had a while until it got to be stabilized. I think you partitioned it into some tenant and common positions so that you may or may not be able to monetize a -- sell out a JV position. Where are you on 11 Madison?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, 11 is -- we've owned it now, I think, for about 9 months. The Sony work is done and the tenant has moved in. As I mentioned earlier, Crdit Suisse exercised its renewals for the 2 floors that we could've gotten back, won't be getting back, that rep
componenttext: Well, 11 is -- we've owned it now, I think, for about 9 months. The Sony work is done and the tenant has moved in. As I mentioned earlier, Crdit Suisse exercised its renewals for the 2 floors that we could've gotten back, won't be getting back, that represented a very substantial mark-to-market. There is, I think, one space remaining, about half the floor, if I'm correct, that we had significant activity on. And I would hope in the next -- in the near term, we'll go to lease on that vacant space, at which point the building will be basically fully leased at rents that average like $70 a foot in a market that's north of $90 a foot. So it's worked out excellent. It's got long-term debt in place. We will talk to investors. That was something we had talked about setting up as a JV for future years, stabilization of that, meaning full rent paying is still about, I would say, plus or minus 18 to 24 months off. So I think the maximum execution for something like that could be end of this year, maybe next year. In that regard, it's not part of our guidance, but it's there as a storehouse of cash and liquidities we can monetize in the future to use either for debt repayment or new acquisitions in the future. And by doing so, there's little to no tax gain the way we structure it by selling that JV interest. So that is one of those sort of well-structured deals and a deal that will be a little bit more opportunistic in our timing for generating those funds and redeploying those funds or for paying down debt.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then a follow-up question for Steve Durels. The headline is 39% rental rate increase, $71 number. I guess that means it's coming off a $50 base. Can you give a little more color as to how sausage is made? What sort of a OpEx reset you'd have or
componenttext: Great. And then a follow-up question for Steve Durels. The headline is 39% rental rate increase, $71 number. I guess that means it's coming off a $50 base. Can you give a little more color as to how sausage is made? What sort of a OpEx reset you'd have or base year reset you'd have? And what $71 would look like on a net basis? And then what sort of leasing commissions you should factor into that equation?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what's happening here is you're going from $51 full service to $71. Your operating expenses are moving around in that equation. And I'm curious as to what the net rent is going, from where to where. And then also, the...
componenttext: Well, what's happening here is you're going from $51 full service to $71. Your operating expenses are moving around in that equation. And I'm curious as to what the net rent is going, from where to where. And then also, the...

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, John. Andrew makes the point. The $51 -- other people quote like the nominal rent. We don't do that. The $51 is as escalated. So the $51 is base rent plus OpEx plus real estate tax. And when we say the rent is going from -- I'm just using your number
componenttext: Hey, John. Andrew makes the point. The $51 -- other people quote like the nominal rent. We don't do that. The $51 is as escalated. So the $51 is base rent plus OpEx plus real estate tax. And when we say the rent is going from -- I'm just using your numbers, kind of have those in from of me, $51 to $71, that $20 increase is bottom line. There's no expenses against the $20 because whatever ops and taxes against it are in the $51. The $71 is the new rent, the cash mark-to-market is $20, that's all bottom line stuff, Matt, yes?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right.
componenttext: Yes, that's right.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so that, to be clear, we don't mark new rents to old base rents, in which case you'd have to ask the question you just asked. This is better and more transparent. We're using fully escalated rents and then marking against that.
componenttext: Okay, so that, to be clear, we don't mark new rents to old base rents, in which case you'd have to ask the question you just asked. This is better and more transparent. We're using fully escalated rents and then marking against that.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the $71 generally comes with phase year operating and taxes starting roughly this year. So you pick up wherever you left off in terms of escalates.
componenttext: And then the $71 generally comes with phase year operating and taxes starting roughly this year. So you pick up wherever you left off in terms of escalates.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So we're completely inflation protected on the $71 going forward.
componenttext: Right. So we're completely inflation protected on the $71 going forward.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it too much of a stretch to say going from $51 to $71 is a $20 increase in net rents, or a $15 increase in net rents?
componenttext: Is it too much of a stretch to say going from $51 to $71 is a $20 increase in net rents, or a $15 increase in net rents?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's $20.
componenttext: I think it's $20.

componenttext: Sure. I think you saw 1285 Sixth and 787 Seventh close. So those were the 2 large transactions sort of from the end of fourth quarter. And then there are a number of assets -- an asset went to contract earlier this week on Wall Street, that was market-rate residential. That cap rate has a 3 handle on it. That's to a U.S. opportunity fund. We've had a number of retail assets that are in the market that are drawing very strong bids, one of which on Fifth Avenue is reportedly under contract, so it's not -- I don't think it's publicly announced yet.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's probably in total about $6 billion to $8 billion worth of assets on the market now. Some of those are going to be straight trades of office buildings; some large recaps, both in Midtown and downtown.
componenttext: Yes, there's probably in total about $6 billion to $8 billion worth of assets on the market now. Some of those are going to be straight trades of office buildings; some large recaps, both in Midtown and downtown.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you saw in Brooklyn, the Watchtower portfolio go under contract. That's a large tract of land in a off-commercial building, which is a complete redevelopment from sort of industrial space to office space as the plan. That drew very wide competiti
componenttext: And then you saw in Brooklyn, the Watchtower portfolio go under contract. That's a large tract of land in a off-commercial building, which is a complete redevelopment from sort of industrial space to office space as the plan. That drew very wide competition in pricing that pushed up to a level that, I think, exceeded the initial expectations in the market.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Right.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the buyers and their financing, is it -- it's still more equity buyers seeing leverage. What are the capital sources?
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the buyers and their financing, is it -- it's still more equity buyers seeing leverage. What are the capital sources?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, CMBS has come back. AAA spreads are in the 130s now from a -- the wides of, call it, 170s. So I think CMBS is viable again, and there are a bunch of CMBS deals getting done currently in the city. But the bank market, it continues to be very active o
componenttext: Well, CMBS has come back. AAA spreads are in the 130s now from a -- the wides of, call it, 170s. So I think CMBS is viable again, and there are a bunch of CMBS deals getting done currently in the city. But the bank market, it continues to be very active on both syndicated loans and bridge and bridge transitional loans. So it's a mix, I would say.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question for Steve Durels. Couple of years ago, you made the comment that there'd be a premium for large blocks in the market. Can you talk about what you're seeing today? And as we are seeing more blocks come on the market, just
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question for Steve Durels. Couple of years ago, you made the comment that there'd be a premium for large blocks in the market. Can you talk about what you're seeing today? And as we are seeing more blocks come on the market, just sense and your perspective on whether you think that's a risk to the market or you think the -- there's still a premium to those kinds of spaces?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's still a premium, in all reality, because it's -- if you're a tenant who goes out looking for a couple 100,000 square feet and you need that space in a relatively reasonable time line, in the next 12 to 18 months, 24 months, your availabili
componenttext: I think there's still a premium, in all reality, because it's -- if you're a tenant who goes out looking for a couple 100,000 square feet and you need that space in a relatively reasonable time line, in the next 12 to 18 months, 24 months, your availabilities, your selections are pretty thin. Because not all blocks are created equal, either because of geographic or space quality or price point or delivery time and whatever it may be. So if you -- if a tenant's had to lease that block as opposed to the landlord turning around and saying, "We're going to lease it floor by floor," I think I would still expect to see a premium on the bigger block.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, do you see heightened risk of sublease space coming on the market here?
componenttext: Okay. And then, do you see heightened risk of sublease space coming on the market here?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't. There has been -- if you look statistically, we're at the low end historically of sublease availability. Even the most recent stats that have come out from the various brokerage houses, I think its like 1.75% or something like that. It's n
componenttext: No, I don't. There has been -- if you look statistically, we're at the low end historically of sublease availability. Even the most recent stats that have come out from the various brokerage houses, I think its like 1.75% or something like that. It's not -- very, very modest. And quite frankly, with the phenomenon of densification in the market, even if we were to hit a rocky point where tenants laid off employees, it becomes very difficult for a tenant to then put space on the sublease market because they pack so many people into their spaces. So I don't see it near term, and I don't see any indicators to suggest that it's an issue to worry about for the balance of this year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm here with UBS -- Nick Yulico. We'll split them up. Marc, can you top sell -- one of your goals -- or actually, I think it was 2 of your goals from the investor day last December where relating to acquisitions of both office and retail, and I think in
componenttext: I'm here with UBS -- Nick Yulico. We'll split them up. Marc, can you top sell -- one of your goals -- or actually, I think it was 2 of your goals from the investor day last December where relating to acquisitions of both office and retail, and I think in total, you had over $1 billion combined of office and retail acquisitions in the goal category for this year. Now that we're almost 4 months through the year, how do you feel about that goal, I guess, in relation to the current state of affairs in New York and the volatility that we're seeing in the capital market?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me be sure that last thing you just said: "given the volatility of the capital markets?"
componenttext: Let me be sure that last thing you just said: "given the volatility of the capital markets?"

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I'm just curious how the state of affairs in the world over the last 4 months -- have they shifted the goalposts for those original goals you put out?
componenttext: No, I'm just curious how the state of affairs in the world over the last 4 months -- have they shifted the goalposts for those original goals you put out?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay, so let's just clarify one thing upfront on the acquisition targets, which we said on the last call and said in December investor and am going to say it again now. Those goals that were originally set forth as they always are when we put tho
componenttext: Got you. Okay, so let's just clarify one thing upfront on the acquisition targets, which we said on the last call and said in December investor and am going to say it again now. Those goals that were originally set forth as they always are when we put those goals forth, are gross targets. So it doesn't account for deals we do in joint venture. So I can give you an example. There is a residential asset that we're looking at in pipeline, very good off market kind of situation, where we might be anywhere between, call it, roughly 1/3 to half the asset, if that thing turns out. I'm not -- I don't know if it will or won't. That would be at a gross value even though, a, our share of it would be far less; and b, joint ventures tend to have secured debts. So the equity component of a JV of an asset tends to be quite small. So when people hear $1 billion, $1.5 billion of investment activity, they think equity, and that's the wrong way to think. The equity component of that $1 billion, $1.5 billion is far, far less. That's a -- b. I would say 4 months into the year, the office goal is probably something we'll reassess mid-year, possibly downward, because we certainly don't have a pipeline now that comes anywhere close to that number. But the way these things go, the assets in New York are big. A deal could pop up second half of the year or towards the end of the year, that might be of a size to make some kind of dent in that goal. But it's not -- right now, our focus has really been on the things we've talked about, which is consummation of the Citi deal, that's done; certain sales and JVs that we -- are out there in the market with and have made good progress with to date and we'll continue to work on that through the balance of the year. There is a pipeline of some retail/resi and an office asset that could or could not come together between now and the end of the year. If we do, they will be deals that we think are going to be highly accretive to value and earnings in the future. Or else in a market like this, we wouldn't -- we would be more discerning, as are other investors. So we're only looking for deals that we think have high value add for somebody like us in this market. But I would say, the office component is probably something that could come in less than originally budgeted. The retail, too early to say. It's only April. It wouldn't even make any assessments there. Because the number for resi/retail, I think was $500 million in total. So $500 million in total, if it's a 50% JV, its $250 million, if it's levered. It's a 100-and-some-odd million dollar investment. We could do that like in December. I couldn't sit here in April and predict it, but I can say there's nothing near term in pipeline that would have us reaching those goals any time in the next quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Nick. I just had a question on the Omnicom renewal. So I guess there's still over 300,000 square feet that Omnicom did not renew. Can you remind us where in the building those floors are? And what are your plans there? There were some talk -- I guess
componenttext: It's Nick. I just had a question on the Omnicom renewal. So I guess there's still over 300,000 square feet that Omnicom did not renew. Can you remind us where in the building those floors are? And what are your plans there? There were some talk -- I guess there was an article the other day about how you're exploring selling a condo interest in that space. Can you just give as an update on what's going on there?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The article was a little premature, but the reality is that we are in very advanced discussions -- in negotiation of a transaction with a tenant for a leasehold condominium. So it's not a sale of a condominium in perpetuity. It's a leasehold condomi
componenttext: Sure. The article was a little premature, but the reality is that we are in very advanced discussions -- in negotiation of a transaction with a tenant for a leasehold condominium. So it's not a sale of a condominium in perpetuity. It's a leasehold condominium, which has a finite life to it of 30 years. And that transaction is expected to close in the next several months. It's really just subject to a couple of outstanding approvals. But that will take care of the lion's share of the Omnicom space, which is over 300,000 square feet. I think the second thing to note about that is that -- and it's a good segue into the following fact, which is of that 300,000 square feet, that will knock off a big chunk of our 2017 lease expirations, of which we've already signed almost 460,000 square feet of leases for 2017 and have another 500,000 square feet, including this deal that we talked about in active negotiations. So we're way, way ahead as far as being able to knock down our 2017 expirations.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was curious if you can talk about the -- obviously, the leasing in the quarter was very strong, 850,000 square feet. I believe at the investor day, your guidance was for 2.2 million square feet for the rest of the year. So just hoping to get a little mo
componenttext: I was curious if you can talk about the -- obviously, the leasing in the quarter was very strong, 850,000 square feet. I believe at the investor day, your guidance was for 2.2 million square feet for the rest of the year. So just hoping to get a little more context on -- I know you didn't update your full year leasing guidance. But how should we think about this quarter and kind of what it implies for the remaining 3 quarters of the year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it was a very -- it's an excellent start to the year. Obviously, we're trending ahead. We'll reevaluate probably next call and if there's any cause for guidance shift, I think we'll evaluate it then. We certainly don't do it quarter-to-quarter. And
componenttext: Well, it was a very -- it's an excellent start to the year. Obviously, we're trending ahead. We'll reevaluate probably next call and if there's any cause for guidance shift, I think we'll evaluate it then. We certainly don't do it quarter-to-quarter. And we'll see how things bear out. But obviously, I did mention there's a 1.3 million of pipeline. So if we have a great second quarter and convert very high ratio of that 1.3 million, then we may have to look at that stat for upward revision.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The goal was 2.0 million to be clear.
componenttext: The goal was 2.0 million to be clear.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2.0 million, okay. Then you're even closer. So -- and then just one other question. I mean, we touched a little bit on retail. I'm curious what your thoughts are on rents in the street retail in Manhattan, especially in the major corridors, Fifth Avenue,
componenttext: 2.0 million, okay. Then you're even closer. So -- and then just one other question. I mean, we touched a little bit on retail. I'm curious what your thoughts are on rents in the street retail in Manhattan, especially in the major corridors, Fifth Avenue, Times Square. Just kind of what your thoughts are on the durability and the growth of those over the next couple of years?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we're seeing and experiencing is durability for sure. I think growth in retail rents has moderated in certain submarkets, Fifth Avenue and I would say Times Square as well. That's after multiple, multiple years of very significant compounded growth i
componenttext: What we're seeing and experiencing is durability for sure. I think growth in retail rents has moderated in certain submarkets, Fifth Avenue and I would say Times Square as well. That's after multiple, multiple years of very significant compounded growth in those rents. So they're sort of leveled off, I would say, in those submarkets. But then there are other submarkets in the city, SoHo and Downtown particularly, where we continue to see increases in rents.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I think last quarter, when you were talking about the pipeline of leasing, you noted that the mark-to-markets were pretty strong. I'm just curious if you could comment a little bit on the pipeline in terms of what kind of rental rates you're seeing in that pipeline as well as the composition by industry and between new and renewal.

componenttext: All I would say is it's very healthy mark-to-market for the pipeline rents. In excess of our guidance, which I think was around 15%, thereabouts, I would say that incrementally, that pipeline exceeds that mark-to-market. I would also say its not 39%, so something in between.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just maybe one other one, if I could. I mean, it's a little bit maybe at odds with the commentary earlier about the type of investor advantage you're seeing this year versus last. But you've sold a couple of suburban assets recently and that see
componenttext: Okay. And just maybe one other one, if I could. I mean, it's a little bit maybe at odds with the commentary earlier about the type of investor advantage you're seeing this year versus last. But you've sold a couple of suburban assets recently and that seems like the fundamentals there have held up pretty well or looked pretty good for the last couple of quarters. I'm just curious if there's an opportunity to do something larger.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, there's opportunities to do something large. I don't know that it's a strategic goal of ours to do something larger. The market is good for the better suburban assets. We -- the guys in White Plains have done an extraordinary job of bringing
componenttext: Well, I mean, there's opportunities to do something large. I don't know that it's a strategic goal of ours to do something larger. The market is good for the better suburban assets. We -- the guys in White Plains have done an extraordinary job of bringing that portfolio to a level that's far in excess of the markets. Those suburban markets are highly impaired generally in the Tri-State area, with 20% plus vacancy rates; and our occupancy levels, far better than that; and our average rent levels far better than that. So I think it's better for us as a company to take those assets sort of one by one and optimize and sell. There's no pressure. There's no -- I don't see any pressure to do something of -- I think what you'd call of a large size, unless something made extraordinary sense. But we like having that portfolio there to create longer-term value with and continue to monetize and harvest as time goes on. I think we've done an excellent job of stewardship on that portfolio, as have the guys up in White Plains. And I think we're reaping the rewards for that now on some of these sales, which had been occurring in '15 and '16.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I'll -- just to answer the first question. Of leases that we have out front, the signature or that are in active negotiation, there's 650,000 square feet of new leases in negotiation and 160,000 square feet of renewals. And then I don't have the breakdown on the term sheets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just following up on 388, 390. I think around the time the Citi lease renewal was announced in early 2014, you guys estimated a 9.7% levered IRR for your holding period, assuming the purchase option was executed in the period established. So I was wond
componenttext: So just following up on 388, 390. I think around the time the Citi lease renewal was announced in early 2014, you guys estimated a 9.7% levered IRR for your holding period, assuming the purchase option was executed in the period established. So I was wondering if you guys had run the math again, and whether this early purchase agreement had any significant effect on that IRR.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the answer is yes. The 9.7%, or whatever the number you quoted, that was actually what I'll call yield to worse, which was an exercise at the end of 2020, I guess, sometime in 2020. So by -- so the way the deal was going down with an early exercise a
componenttext: Yes, the answer is yes. The 9.7%, or whatever the number you quoted, that was actually what I'll call yield to worse, which was an exercise at the end of 2020, I guess, sometime in 2020. So by -- so the way the deal was going down with an early exercise and the other components of that deal, the total IRR over, I think it's a 9-year period, so it's a 9-year annual compounded IRR of 10.9%.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious, Marc, with the updated kind of first quarter numbers here, if your view of market rent growth in Manhattan has changed at all relative to kind of where you were trending on the 4Q call.
componenttext: Just curious, Marc, with the updated kind of first quarter numbers here, if your view of market rent growth in Manhattan has changed at all relative to kind of where you were trending on the 4Q call.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think the call that I had last time, we had said the rent spikes that people were putting in of 5%, 7%, 10%, we thought that the second half of the year, you might see something more in the single digits, and I think I said something along the lines
componenttext: No, I think the call that I had last time, we had said the rent spikes that people were putting in of 5%, 7%, 10%, we thought that the second half of the year, you might see something more in the single digits, and I think I said something along the lines of 2%, 3%. And I think, at least, from an underwriting perspective, that's what we're going to continue to use and broadcast just for the second half of this year. We have given no guidance for '17 and beyond. I can see a scenario where, as the market settles and this job growth continues apace, that you could get into growth rates higher than that beyond this year, sort of. I could see that definitely occurring. But we're not making that call now. I would say pretty much no change in guidance for a back half of the year in kind of 2% to 3% up in rents range. So good with the emphasis being on up. I think there was, again, a misinterpretation by some on the last call that we had said down. There's no down. There's only up in our guidance, and the question is up by how much.

componenttext: No, I mean, the lease term probably went up as a result of Crdit Suisse since the Crdit Suisse is a 20-year lease.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: 20 year -- yes.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a function of the ratio of how many leases that we do that are for new -- first-generation tenants coming into the portfolio as opposed to renewal deals, and frequently, whether those -- the length of the lease as opposed to whether it's a 15-year de
componenttext: It's a function of the ratio of how many leases that we do that are for new -- first-generation tenants coming into the portfolio as opposed to renewal deals, and frequently, whether those -- the length of the lease as opposed to whether it's a 15-year deal, 10-year deal, 5-year deal, that can drive the concession. So there's no shift as far as the market goes. It's more a function of the variables of those specific transactions.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, and we were 50 a couple of quarters ago and priced 50 before that. I mean, it varies quarter-to-quarter and it's dependent on what buildings at what rents for what term we're leasing space. So -- and I think that's a pretty consistent trend acr
componenttext: Yes. Well, and we were 50 a couple of quarters ago and priced 50 before that. I mean, it varies quarter-to-quarter and it's dependent on what buildings at what rents for what term we're leasing space. So -- and I think that's a pretty consistent trend across. If I look at one large renewal that had a full package because it's a 20-year renewal, is the CS deal at 11 Madison. So while it is considered a renewal, because they're [indiscernible] 20 years, actually 21 because it goes out to 2037, so they get a full package with that, and that's 180,000 square feet.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to be clear, that was pursuant to contractual option, not that it was negotiated by us that way. Their renewal provides no downtime and a significant mark-to-market. But their option also provided for a TI package because it is a 20-year lease.
componenttext: Yes, just to be clear, that was pursuant to contractual option, not that it was negotiated by us that way. Their renewal provides no downtime and a significant mark-to-market. But their option also provided for a TI package because it is a 20-year lease. Somebody like a Crdit Suisse is making a 20-year commitment to 180,000 feet is going to want to refresh the space. So I don't see that as a -- it's not a shifting market trend because it was embedded within the lease document.

componenttext: Yes, so in addition to the 11 Madison mark-to-market, the Omnicom renewal at 220 East 42nd Street, about 167,000 square feet, had a mark-to-market even higher than that, north of 70%. headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: That is much more property NOI than interest expense. If you look at what we're paying down in the short term, that is probably our lowest cost of debt capital, because we're going to take the proceeds from 388 and repay our revolving credit facility. We won't be repaying the more expensive debt, the mortgage at 45 Lex until November or December. So that benefit will really reap its rewards in 2017.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
