headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you talked about getting debt-to-EBITDA down to about 7.5x, 7.6 I believe, pro forma of the Citi sale. I'm just wondering if that's still the right betting line for the end of this year. And then can you talk about your longer-term debt-to-EBITDA
componenttext: I think you talked about getting debt-to-EBITDA down to about 7.5x, 7.6 I believe, pro forma of the Citi sale. I'm just wondering if that's still the right betting line for the end of this year. And then can you talk about your longer-term debt-to-EBITDA target as we look out to '17 and '18?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we are still on track for 7.6 by year-end, as to your first question. And Matt, I think on the math we've run is about a 30% -- somewhere between 35% to 37% debt-to-value on a consolidated basis, low 40s on a combined basis and right within the st
componenttext: Yes. So we are still on track for 7.6 by year-end, as to your first question. And Matt, I think on the math we've run is about a 30% -- somewhere between 35% to 37% debt-to-value on a consolidated basis, low 40s on a combined basis and right within the strike zone of all the rating agencies. So I think we will probably wind up taking it down further, just based on how we're modeling not just the year but some of our long-term plans going into next year and beyond in application of funds and while still keeping our earnings momentum. I think it will allow us to reduce that further, although I would say, when you get into that 7%, 7.5% range, we view the portfolio as pretty much completely derisked and delevered, especially given the cap rate environment we operate at, which is typically between 3.5% and 4% cap rate environment. Debt-to-EBITDA, I think is not the best model to use. I know you guys use it and that's the one you like. But there is also a notion of equity or embedded equity, which is more of a loan-to-value concept. And I think because New York is a very liquid market, with anywhere between $40 billion to $70 billion a year of transactions, you can get a pretty good handle on the NAV. I know you guys carry a pretty high NAV for the company relative to where our stock price is. And if you look at the debt on a debt to, I'll call it, your NAV as opposed to debt-to-EBITDA, I think we would be sort of right in the middle or possibly even below peer average.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And Steve, it sounds like you're seeing pretty good broad-based leasing demand out there today. But just wondering if there's any submarkets or industries or tenant sizes that really stand out as seeing particularly a good amount of activity.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the TAMI sector, whether it's in our portfolio or in the overall market, continues to be a big driver. But Marc, in his opening comments, I think, spoke a little bit about the diversity of tenants. And if you break it down of the deals that we have
componenttext: Well, the TAMI sector, whether it's in our portfolio or in the overall market, continues to be a big driver. But Marc, in his opening comments, I think, spoke a little bit about the diversity of tenants. And if you break it down of the deals that we have in pipeline, it's composed of TAMI being the leader. Health care being a big chunk of it, financial services being a significant player, legal services and then general business services and even government, to a certain extent, are the 5 or 6 major industries. But the top 4 being TAMI, health care, financial services and legal. And I don't think that's really different today than what we were seeing through most of last year, quite frankly. And I think we take a lot of comfort from seeing that kind of diversity.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any submarkets stand out as particularly strong or soft?
componenttext: And any submarkets stand out as particularly strong or soft?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think there's a lot of questions that we get about the West Side, meaning Midtown West, meaning Sixth Avenue in particular. And like a couple of years ago when Sixth Avenue had a bunch of vacancies, Sixth Avenue right now has probably got some of th
componenttext: No. I think there's a lot of questions that we get about the West Side, meaning Midtown West, meaning Sixth Avenue in particular. And like a couple of years ago when Sixth Avenue had a bunch of vacancies, Sixth Avenue right now has probably got some of the biggest deals that are in negotiation. One of the big headline deals that's over there is 0.5 million square feet going to Major League Baseball. So Midtown proper is a very active part of the marketplace. And I think it's active on both East and West and all parts of Midtown. So I think Midtown is more active than Downtown right now, quite frankly. So I mean -- and we're certainly feeling it in our portfolio.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp. Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, manag
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp. Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also, during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measure most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's second quarter 2016 earnings.  
Before turning the call over to Marc Holliday, Chief Executive Officer of SL Green Realty Corp., I ask that those of you participating in the Q&A portion of the call, please limit your questions to 2 per person. 
Thank you. I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, operator. We're pleased that all of you joined us on this gorgeous day at New York City, and we're even happier that we were able to put out yet another quarter of strong operating results and market-leading capital transactions. Our seco
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, operator. We're pleased that all of you joined us on this gorgeous day at New York City, and we're even happier that we were able to put out yet another quarter of strong operating results and market-leading capital transactions. Our second quarter results continue a trend in 2016 of surprising to [ph] the upside and leasing velocity and rental achievement. We executed another 620,000 square feet of Manhattan office leases, highlighted by the recently announced expansion of Bloomberg in 919 Third Avenue and the renewal and expansion of New York Life at Graybar Building. In fact, SL Green was responsible for 3 of the 8 largest leases transacted in the second quarter in Midtown, [ph] Bloomberg, New York Life and Wells Fargo at 100 Park Avenue. 
The mark-to-market on the second quarter Manhattan leases was a robust 16%, bringing first half 2016 average rental increases on replacement leases to 28%. And that's on about 1.5 million square feet of leasing during 6 months. I think it speaks for itself as an extraordinary accomplishment. 
Velocity continues even into the month of July, with another 84,000 square feet of leasing in office in Manhattan in just the past 3 weeks at an 18% mark-to-market inclusive of the recent Omnicom renewal at 220 East 42nd Street. 
In terms of forecasting these leasing trends for the remainder of the year, I would note that the best indicator of what those results are likely to trend towards would be our current leasing pipeline. That current pipeline stands today at about 1.6 million square feet, the vast majority of which is comprised of leases pending, 4 [ph] leases out for signature. And notably, the mark-to-market on all of those pipeline deals exceeds 20%. 
So fortunately for shareholders and unfortunately for Steve Durels and his leasing team, we must and are increasing our full year guidance for completed Manhattan office leases to 2.6 million square feet for the full year and mark-to-market on those leases, which are replacement leases, to 22% mark-to-market. So numbers that, in each case, are fairly significantly ahead of where we were in December. That sound you just heard was Steve hitting the floor. You can pick yourself up, Steve, and let's keep -- let's just put the best face on and go forward, okay? 
In this manner, we provide additional motivation and encouragement to our leasing and operations team to execute at the highest level that's consistent with this firm's culture of hard work and outperformance. 
These leasing results and our projection of second half performance is driven by continual demand for high-quality, well-located, reasonably priced office space, which descriptively is the sweet spot of our entire portfolio. 
Midtown space continues to be in high demand as the vacancy rate decreased 10 basis points to 9.2%, and sublease space in Midtown stands at only 2.9 million square feet, near historical lows over the past 8 or 9 years for sublease space. Very important barometer, we haven't talked about that on the last few conference calls, but we're talking about sublease space in Midtown that's about 1.1% of total inventory. So very, very [ph] well. 
Job creation in the financial security sector is roughly flat for the year. I think, contrary to market perspective that there has been some substantial contraction in this sector, it's actually, I think, going [ph] down about 1,000 jobs year-to-date, which on that job basis is essentially 0. But interestingly, the FIRE sector, finance, insurance real estate, is accounting for much of the first half leasing activity in Midtown and elsewhere. Health care is also making a reasonably good showing, but I would say financial services had an above-average showing in the first half of the year. 
That activity, and all that, [ph] whether it's the FIRE sector, health care or otherwise, is driven by jobs and job creation. Unfortunately, the June New York City job numbers are not out yet. They're going to be out imminently. We would have hoped to have had them for the call, but we don't. But if it's any indicator, the national numbers that came out from Bureau of Labor Statistics for June were quite strong relative to May and earlier. And we're hopeful that the New York City numbers will follow and inform the national numbers. In part, it's almost self-fulfilling because the end of the Verizon strike in and of itself will probably put back on the rolls [ph] of the city, I think, 3,000-plus jobs in June. So we're just hoping that and more growth on top of that, but we'll see shortly.
So that's a quick snapshot of the leasing picture. I'm sure you guys will have questions as we go forward. But I also want to make sure we touch upon the investment side of the portfolio. We did complete some important divestitures during the quarter, including the Citigroup headquarters building sale, 33 Beekman sale, and sale of the suburban property in Greenwich. The proceeds of these significant capital transactions went to pay down debt and invest in certain new opportunities, including a 20% stake in a recently completed residential project on the West Side, known as Sky, and an additional investment in the debt [ph] and preferred equity portfolio. 
On the topic of DPE, we are still on track and reaffirm our December guidance that for year-end balances, [ph] we'll be just shy of $2 billion, about $1.95 billion of balance, and contribution for the year should be on the order of about $200 million of gross revenues from that book of business.
We have sizable, identified pipeline of deals that we expect to close during the second half of the year, carrying routine spreads of approximately 9.9% for that pipeline book of business, which is higher than first half's achievement, but when blended will certainly exceed the 8.5% that was used in our earnings guidance back in December and then our earnings revision at the first quarter. So that's a very, I'd say, positive story and a good market for us to be conducting our business with on the lending side as well as on the equity on [ph] real estate side.
We have been market leaders in the provision of subordinate debt capital for large and small New York City commercial projects for years and years. We established that position by being the most active lender in that market, I guess, for nearly 20 years. So there's a reputation and franchise and knowledge of the business, which I think you'll see has been paying off over the years and will be a shining example through the balance of this year. 
With excellent visibility at this point into our remaining 2016 production and performance, given there's only 5.5 months to go, our focus will naturally turn to 2017 and beyond. In order to meet our stated objective of delivering market-leading recurring earnings growth and sector-leading total return to [ph] shareholder growth, we have positioned our investment portfolio to generate substantial increases in NOI through leasing up the remainder of the growth portfolio and taking advantage of the embedded rental mark-to-market in our stabilized office and retail portfolios. 
These engines of growth should enable us to continue to deliver sector-leading increases in FFO over the next 3 to 5 years, and this is before accounting for the earnings contributions from One Vanderbilt. Speaking of One Vanderbilt, we are on track with this iconic development project, with the site now almost 100% cleared of the 4 older buildings that formerly occupied the site. Heavy equipment is rolled in to complete the removal of the last 2 floors. And in 3 weeks, we will have a clean site ready to be excavated and foundations poured. Extraordinary amount of credit goes to our construction and operations team for undertaking over the past year what we believe to be the largest surgical demolition of commercial buildings in decades. And it was done on time, on budget and in a safe manner. And New York City is better for it. There's barely a day that goes by we're not getting a comment from somebody who sees how that site is now being transformed in a way to upgrade the appreciation you have of these great landmark properties that surround the site, like Grand Central and Chrysler and Lincoln and others. It's [ph] by allowing what will replace those buildings, the new building having setbacks to the property line in a tapered form [ph] to let in maximum light there, enormous benefit to the city, to the skyline and to this company by adding this extraordinary building to our portfolio. 
Our financing arrangements for the $1.5 billion construction loan are on track as we've signed the final term sheet with a consortium of 5 lenders, and we will look to have the loan fully committed and closed by the end of the third quarter.
You also saw we took advantage of interest rates by entering into a $300 million swap, 7-year term swap. And what's interesting to note is that in the past 2 Decembers, Andrew Mathias, [ph] a quick write-up on the screen, another engine of earnings growth, which I think doesn't get the proper amount of due, which is not top line revenue growth but bottom line debt service savings. And we showed that there was extraordinary amount of mark-to-market savings that we could achieve over the next 3 to 5 years in our debt book by having rates just basically stay roughly where they were when we went through the analysis in December. In fact, rates have fallen since then, so I would imagine the opportunity for us at this moment exceeds the $30 million or $40 million per year annually that we have forecasted at that point. And these swaps are one -- just one point of evidence of how we can take advantage of that because the rate we locked in for 7 years is actually lower than the floating rate we had forecasted for the year. Recall, we always model LIBOR curve plus 50 basis points, and the amount, what was it, 1.13?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: 1.14%, we locked in for 7 years is actually below that floating rate now and now locked in for 7 years. So clearly, we are going to be intensely focused on these kinds of opportunities with the rest of our debt portfolio to take advantage of rates, lock i
componenttext:
1.14%, we locked in for 7 years is actually below that floating rate now and now locked in for 7 years. So clearly, we are going to be intensely focused on these kinds of opportunities with the rest of our debt portfolio to take advantage of rates, lock in these sort of historical lows where we can and where it's prudent to do so and wind up hopefully creating a fourth measure of earnings growth on the debt service expense savings side. 
So I feel like we are firing on all cylinders. I said that last quarter. I feel like the cylinders are still properly functioning. I feel very good about our positioning in the market for the present and for the future. Our same-store portfolio was 97.4% leased. Our leverage levels were the lowest in the company's history and getting better. Our liquidity exceeds $1.5 billion. We expect to have little or no line of credit balance outstanding by year-end based on projections for the balance of the year. We have substantial storehouses of growth embedded in the portfolio, which I mentioned, and we're on track to develop the greatest buildings in New York City.
So with that, I'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] Steve will address the sort of the tenant mindset and/or mood, but I just wanted -- I want to go back to the supplemental while Steve's answering. [ph] I think we have very little in the way of -- not even large expirations, very little in the way of
componenttext: [ph] Steve will address the sort of the tenant mindset and/or mood, but I just wanted -- I want to go back to the supplemental while Steve's answering. [ph] I think we have very little in the way of -- not even large expirations, very little in the way of expirations in the next -- for the balance of this year and next year. So something we've done and we've done with like a single-minded focus is to do a lot of not just current leasing but forward leasing. The only way we could lease 2.6 million square feet this year when we only had like 1 million or 1.2 million square feet rolling is by putting to bed what could be either exposure or opportunity in 2016, '17, '18. So we'll look back -- I think just I want to make sure we're clear, we have very little in the way of rollover exposure for the balance of this year and next year. But with that said, Steve, what's the thought? [ph]

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the feedback we're getting from tenants today is no different than what we were getting a year ago. The general mood from the tenants that we speak to was they feel good about their businesses. They think they're in a healthy position. I thin
componenttext: Yes. I think the feedback we're getting from tenants today is no different than what we were getting a year ago. The general mood from the tenants that we speak to was they feel good about their businesses. They think they're in a healthy position. I think it depends on the type of industry you're talking about as to how bullish they are, but most people are still in the mindset of expanding their businesses, making capital commitments as far as restacking or rebuilding and changing how they like to use their space. And I don't think that's ever going to go away for the next several years to come because it's a bit of a cultural thing. And tenants, we've continued to see tenants [ph] in 2017, '18 expirations a willingness to engage in early renewals. And as Marc touched on, a lot of the sort of outperformance on the leasing velocity within our portfolio is a combination of filling vacancy but also tenants' willingness to step up and do early renewals. And in the 1,600,000 square [ph] feet that is [ph] our pipeline, there are some very many [ph] deals inside that pipeline, which we hope to have success on before the end of the year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. [ph][ph]  And if I could just follow up with a quick follow-up. And I know in a vast market, we've actually seen this before, about the presence [ph] of rework in the New York City market now occupying close to 3 million square feet
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. [ph][ph]  And if I could just follow up with a quick follow-up. And I know in a vast market, we've actually seen this before, about the presence [ph] of rework in the New York City market now occupying close to 3 million square feet by some estimates and recently demonstrating some weakness in revenues or in profits. Does it have any -- does that concern you at all as that number gets larger and larger in the market? And I'm thinking back to the late '90s when we saw a number of sort of WeWork-like tenants kind of disappear during periods of economic weakness. Does that prevent -- present incremental risk in the market, in your mind?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I'm old enough to remember that far back at this point.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and we were there, too. So it's a different company with a different model, a very successful model and a model that's attracting an enormous amount of financial support. So to me, the difference between companies, not just fractional office companie
componenttext: Yes, and we were there, too. So it's a different company with a different model, a very successful model and a model that's attracting an enormous amount of financial support. So to me, the difference between companies, not just fractional office companies or full-service communities like WeWork that do their business but really any company to ride through any period of downturn is simply -- well, not simply but is, in large part, capacity and liquidity. So I think that if any of these companies are capitalized properly, and WeWork looks to be like they are, then these downturns in New York tend to be short-lived. Downturn doesn't mean things like go to 0. [ph] Downturns in New York may just be marginal rent reductions of 10%, 15%, 20%. I think that the model we've seen them execute in this market is sort of best-of-class, and I think that is generally perceived to be such when you look at the landlords that are doing business, looking to WeWork as sort of, in many cases, a prime tenant. So it doesn't give us concern. 3 million square feet for any tenant on a 400 million square foot inventory, I don't want to be too dismissive, but it's not like 3 million square feet in a 100 million square foot market. It's -- this market is 4x that size. And therefore, we don't -- it's not something that keeps us up at night.

componenttext: [ph] On the investment side, we haven't seen any change. There's some expectation that New York will draw even more capital interest as London is less attractive for foreign investment. Still too early to tell on that front. We're monitoring the deals that are in the market now, and certainly, values are holding up or even taking another step forward. But it's too early to sort of tie that to Brexit or not.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It's -- in that 1.6 million, nothing is directly connected to One Vanderbilt nor would we expect it to be. We are 4-plus years out before we're delivering the building. And although we're actively presenting the building, we are early into the game. A
componenttext: No. It's -- in that 1.6 million, nothing is directly connected to One Vanderbilt nor would we expect it to be. We are 4-plus years out before we're delivering the building. And although we're actively presenting the building, we are early into the game. And we've got a stretch goal for the company to do [ph] some leasing this year of about 200,000 square feet. But like in every year, we have a list of goals, and then we have stretch goals because we push ourselves to outperform. And we're working hard at it, but nothing to announce yet.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I mean, I think it sort of speaks for itself. We are -- we'd like to think of ourselves as having among the best platforms in New York City and executing these kind of deals. So there's a wide disparity of buildings and ownership groups that compr
componenttext: Yes. So I mean, I think it sort of speaks for itself. We are -- we'd like to think of ourselves as having among the best platforms in New York City and executing these kind of deals. So there's a wide disparity of buildings and ownership groups that comprise the 400 million feet of inventory in the city. I hope we're, if not the best, among the best, but I'd like to think we are the best. And as a result, we, I think, have a unusual scale and footprint in the city, almost 30 million  square feet of real estate. So we are able to kind of leverage that position to maximize our relationships with tenants, partners, lenders and vendors to keep this portfolio 97.5% leased, maximize our rent, keep our TIs, leasing concessions low. I don't think anybody mentioned that, but I think it's worthy of mentioning. I think we were about $26 a foot or $30 a foot thereabout for the quarter. So quite efficient, I think, in terms of how we executed the business, and that's our [ph] calling card.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just add, too. I think the market is better than those reports we're getting [ph] as well. A lot of the market reports that get printed are lag reality. [ph] And we're in a better market than statistically that's being reported, as evidenced by som
componenttext: Let me just add, too. I think the market is better than those reports we're getting [ph] as well. A lot of the market reports that get printed are lag reality. [ph] And we're in a better market than statistically that's being reported, as evidenced by some of the deals that we are working on, that we think are going to close in the third quarter and as evidenced by some of the deals that closed at the very end of the second quarter. So we are ahead of the market, we're doing well, but I think the market's better than what's actually been in [ph] those reports.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just going back to the Brexit question just on a different angle. I mean, I guess it's still very early days in terms of what's going on and what the impacts might look like. But I guess does this pique your interest at all in -- and [ph] l
componenttext: And then maybe just going back to the Brexit question just on a different angle. I mean, I guess it's still very early days in terms of what's going on and what the impacts might look like. But I guess does this pique your interest at all in -- and [ph] looking at London again?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I think that, that [ph] sort of reinforces our strategy, which is a question from time to time of wanting to be sort of a sharpshooter in one market. I think we attempted to not just -- it wasn't by accident. We chose to do $25 billion of busin
componenttext: All right. I think that, that [ph] sort of reinforces our strategy, which is a question from time to time of wanting to be sort of a sharpshooter in one market. I think we attempted to not just -- it wasn't by accident. We chose to do $25 billion of business in one market. It was designed to be done in what we thought was the market that had the best liquidity, stability, transparency, depth of market participants, Fortune 500 tenants. London, I think, exhibits many of those traits, but I think New York is a better market going in. And I don't think there's any more desire on our part to diversify into that market or other markets, which we would almost deem as like adverse diversification. So there's plenty for us to do in this city, both -- in office, retail, multi, [ph] preferred equity. We've got actually quite a full plate. And while there may be some good opportunities in London that emerge, my guess is that'll be taken advantage of by people who have or groups that have significant footprints in that market. So I wouldn't think so, but it's not something we've looked at all that closely at the moment. If shareholders start asking us to take a look at it, maybe we'll become more focused. But it's not [ph] time will tell.

We obviously always want to be accurate in our guidance, conservative and prudent. And as we look out over the balance of the year, where [ph] we reset guidance only 3 months ago, which is pretty unusual, only 3 months into  the year to adjust. We feel good with [ph] the range. [ph] You have to keep an eye on a couple of things that we have out there, not the least of which is the potential impact of the [indiscernible] situation [ph][ph]  at 1515 Broadway, which has not resolved itself, that may have an impact. And so at this point, we thought it was prudent to keep the FFO guidance for the moment unchanged.

componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up, I'm not sure how much you could say on this. But on One Vanderbilt, the decision to JV or not sell a JV interest and the kind of the timing of that, how do you think about the risk reward of mitigating some risk, maybe JV a way to get better pricing close to stabilization or is it too early to talk about that?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we said in December and reiterate on the last call, and I guess what I'm saying now just as a refresher, our focus right now is on closing out that loan. As I think it should be. I think the first order of business and an important part of the overal
componenttext: What we said in December and reiterate on the last call, and I guess what I'm saying now just as a refresher, our focus right now is on closing out that loan. As I think it should be. I think the first order of business and an important part of the overall capitalization of this project is to get a properly structured price, $1.5 billion construction and facility closed out, which we've been working intensely hard on for several months now. And looks like we're nearing the conclusion point and hope to have that close in the next 50 [ph] days or so, 60 [ph], 75 [ph] days. So I think along the way, we have begun to have conversations with equity investors, I would say, all of which have gone exceedingly well in terms of this activity of these various institutional players who have the capacity to fund a deal like this and have the desire to be a part of development projects, which are kind of best building, best market, best location. With that said, there are certain signals from our shareholders and analysts about trying to expedite, do it rapidly, we're not on that approach. It's a bad approach. We don't want to, I think, no exact right or wrong , but we think that for a project like this, we should see the whole market and there's going to be a lot of different opportunities out there, different structures, different amounts, different kind of yield enhancements available for the company. We're working very closely with Heinz in this regard. I'd say by the end of this year, we would've covered, I don't know maybe 40 of the top domestic and foreign investors in the world for a project like this. And then we'll try to zero in and grind it down to the right partner for a project like this. You don't want the wrong partner. You want to make sure this is the absolute right partner, shares a long-term vision, has the capacity to fund side-by-side all the way through the project and has a real deep love and affection for this project. I'm confident we'll get there as I was confident we would find, pull together the debt financing. It is not -- business is not on an urgent track, not on fast-track. It's on what I would call kind of a responsible track for a project like this. Remember, there's very little money spend right now. I keep reinforcing the fact that most of the money spent begins middle of '17 when you start going vertical on project. We kind of fully decided on unencumbered. We had no partners. We'll be funding what remains in demo activation, cash or between now and year-end. And then we get to do some initial loan draws where our expectation is we'll be able to do a initial loan draws under loan facilities to basically prime the pump for 2017. So we have time. We think the market's coming our way because as rates drop and you have things like Brexit, which take a fairly attractive and competitive market and maybe put it on the sidelines for a year or 2, we'll be the beneficiary of at least temporarily, if not permanently, some excess investment dollars searching for project like One Vanderbilt and I think it's our job to take advantage of that. We're on -- we're preceding a pace Bays and we'll definitely keep you apprised, but I didn't expect much in the way of announceable events on the JV side of '16, I would probably reiterate that at this point.

So we're going to just get that done, and then hopefully on the next call, we'll be able to share with you some info.

You talked about Brexit potentially driving more money towards New York, but have you seen any of the opposite given sort of the turbulence in the stock markets?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little bit too early to tell. We're seeing values hold up to take a step forward even in certain cases, but it's too early to tell whether those buyers are sort of form shopping and would've otherwise been investing in London but for now in
componenttext: I think it's a little bit too early to tell. We're seeing values hold up to take a step forward even in certain cases, but it's too early to tell whether those buyers are sort of form shopping and would've otherwise been investing in London but for now investing in New York, or if it's just the natural flows of capital we've been talking about consistently which are really continue to drive values in New York. So it's -- just not sure if it's situational or if it's just more of the overall trend we've been tracking.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We put rents up in December. And our whole approach was to price the building in 2021 at rents that are consistent with the what the best buildings are getting in the city today. So we view that very conservatively because our performance are based on, I
componenttext: We put rents up in December. And our whole approach was to price the building in 2021 at rents that are consistent with the what the best buildings are getting in the city today. So we view that very conservatively because our performance are based on, I guess, what you would say no growth in those rents over 5 or 6 years well offer today's rents, even though this building is a physical -- as physical face and infrastructure, sustainability and [indiscernible], [indiscernible] nature will be far in excess of what this city considers the best building. We just kind of priced this based off of today's rents. And those rents are going to go up and down over the next 5, 6 years. You mentioned earlier the bulk of the leasing we expect will occur at [indiscernible] 2018 and beyond. So the real question is, what's the market then? We feel very good about the projects positioning and the rent positioning of the projects where we sit today, not just where we sat in December. And we might be conservative, we might not be. But I don't think we're aggressive and the returns are such that even if the rents are 3% or 5% off, the deal returns development side of this quality are still for an excess of [indiscernible]

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The pipeline changes weekly, monthly. There are deals on the sheet none of which exist in December of '15. Financing deals are not like this. Real estate deals can take anywhere you have to take 1, 2, 3 years to ferment. Transactional activity financings
componenttext: The pipeline changes weekly, monthly. There are deals on the sheet none of which exist in December of '15. Financing deals are not like this. Real estate deals can take anywhere you have to take 1, 2, 3 years to ferment. Transactional activity financings are typically, have a 3 to 4 month shelf life. So none of this was in pipe in December. This is all brand-new product. That which we projected to close in first half, we closed it. We sold -- we sold a lot of products because if we don't syndicate, then we're going to be far in excess of balances at year-end. So we may originate over the second half of the year well over $1 billion. But the real issue is not what are we going to close, what are we going to retain. We control that, Jamie. So that's how we can be highly confident of hitting our goals when we have a pipeline that might be $1 billion to $1.5 billion and we're only looking to originate the same, maybe $600 million, $700 million between now and then. At most. So we control the brake and accelerator on our decision how much we're going to syndicate, if we could syndicate less. But I think the issue will have if not your issue of pay, will you be able to originate the business. It's going to be syndicating ferociously to keep the balance within and below the $2 billion mark. That I would say is more challenge.

componenttext: And there were other closings earlier in the year, but just that just 3 closed in the quarter. That brings us on a pro forma basis of 7.5x debt-to-EBITDA by year-end. So that $150 million of incremental growth that was part of the forecast to get us to the 7.5 [ph]. So it's also unplanned. By the way, $150 [ph] million doesn't move the needle like 10 basis points. But it is in there just to answer your question directly accounted for. So it looks like as we said now we're right where we hope to be at year-end.

componenttext: Got you. Got you. And then I guess for Steve, just a little nuance on the world of leasing. You're quoting a sort of of a full year 22% cash mark-to-market. Maybe this is Matt's question. What's the math look like if you did a GAAP mark-to-market for the year? And what the mark-to-market look like on a net rent basis versus the gross rent basis? Do you guys have a sense for those kind of escalations?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, okay. That sounds like 4 questions. We're obviously writing it. The first one is GAAP, right? The question is, if 22% cash, do we know what GAAP is like? We always -- we think we can maybe formulate and I don't think we have it, John. We always look
componenttext: Well, okay. That sounds like 4 questions. We're obviously writing it. The first one is GAAP, right? The question is, if 22% cash, do we know what GAAP is like? We always -- we think we can maybe formulate and I don't think we have it, John. We always look at the best representative of spot market increase is the current cash rent versus the immediately preceding escalated cash rent. That's the -- that's most of the increase. If you then take it over time, which is I guess the GAAP if we did a 10-year deal and had average of 50% [ph] increases, plus midyear bump -- midterm bump, right? Then that's going to be, I think, wildly in excess of the 22% because you're going to be comparing sort of your average rent to the spot rent. And it's going to be -- [indiscernible] but it will be definitionally higher than 22%.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will be a misleading number for people, I think. You're seeing the mark-to-market compares starting rent to the ending rent, but you did it against GAAP.
componenttext: It will be a misleading number for people, I think. You're seeing the mark-to-market compares starting rent to the ending rent, but you did it against GAAP.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The ending rent will be lower because...
componenttext: The ending rent will be lower because...

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It would be like a midpoint rent, mid-GAAP. We will play around with it for couple of leases and see what the results look like. But I just want to get through the implication of that metric once you have it. The second thing will be gross and net.
componenttext: It would be like a midpoint rent, mid-GAAP. We will play around with it for couple of leases and see what the results look like. But I just want to get through the implication of that metric once you have it. The second thing will be gross and net.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it was net. Net effective was net concessions or was it gross of net?
componenttext: I think it was net. Net effective was net concessions or was it gross of net?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The quick math is let's say you have a $75 rent and a $25 OpEx and that's $50 of that for the $75 rent goes up by 22% while your OpEx stays constant, your cash rent, your net rent is going up much more than 22%, unless of course you've got a big OpEx incr
componenttext: The quick math is let's say you have a $75 rent and a $25 OpEx and that's $50 of that for the $75 rent goes up by 22% while your OpEx stays constant, your cash rent, your net rent is going up much more than 22%, unless of course you've got a big OpEx increase factored in. And I'm just trying to sense if you guys do that math or not.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is right. Because it's 22% gross to gross, which would be higher if you went net-to-net. I think that's right, yes? Yes, I think that's right. But I guess what we're looking at is within our NOI at any given point in time, you have the net. So the qu
componenttext: That is right. Because it's 22% gross to gross, which would be higher if you went net-to-net. I think that's right, yes? Yes, I think that's right. But I guess what we're looking at is within our NOI at any given point in time, you have the net. So the question is how much contribution are you getting to the NOI, which already remember NOI has taken out the expenses because of the contribution is the differential in the gross rent. So if the NOI of the building is $10 million, and we sign a new lease and the gross rent goes from $75 million to $80 million. We've got $5 or more to drop to that bottom line to the NOI because expenses don't go up when you sign the lease. Your point is that increase on a net basis, probably more than 22% [ph] I think that's right. So we can take a look at that.

componenttext: Just going back to the new 22% mark-to-market guidance for this year. Is that because, which is higher than your prior guidance, is that because of getting better rents on a lot of space? Or is it because of 1 or 2 big leases of moving into the pipeline this year, affecting those numbers?

componenttext: It's not driven by -- it's all over the board as far as what particularly deal up or down. If you -- if we share with you the pipeline, the vast majority of the deals that we're working on all have positive mark-to-market. And this question of just some having more than others. It's not disproportionately dependent upon a single deal.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The quarter would have been 150 basis points higher.  But the tendency, Nick, is for the larger leases. The outlier leases may not quite get as much mark-to-market. Your point is pay the bigger leases have the biggest mark-to-market to drive the deals, th
componenttext: The quarter would have been 150 basis points higher.  But the tendency, Nick, is for the larger leases. The outlier leases may not quite get as much mark-to-market. Your point is pay the bigger leases have the biggest mark-to-market to drive the deals, that's not usually our experience in this market, it's the opposite. By number of deals, the number of deals we have paid mark-to-market but then you have some margin deals where you don't always have the exact same price in dollars and then they have to take a lower amount. But whether it's 16% or 28% or 22%, I mean these are big numbers to throw out.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of guidance, as Steve starts the year '17, '18, '19 leases you're going to pull forward the year into the year we've had an early goal. We probably renewed some leases that were big mark-to-market. And that's driving that guidance.
componenttext: In terms of guidance, as Steve starts the year '17, '18, '19 leases you're going to pull forward the year into the year we've had an early goal. We probably renewed some leases that were big mark-to-market. And that's driving that guidance.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that speaks to the health of the market right now because we're not in a defensive position. We're -- we're in a point of view where tenants are coming to us and are going to do early renewals and they're paying up for it. I think that's obviously whe
componenttext: And that speaks to the health of the market right now because we're not in a defensive position. We're -- we're in a point of view where tenants are coming to us and are going to do early renewals and they're paying up for it. I think that's obviously where we want to be and the market is on our side right now.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I know, that's helpful. The follow-up then has to go to any idea of the kind of overall market, whether you're seeing given that the vacancy rate in the overall market hasn't come down much, business uncertainties maybe a little bit higher. Marc, you
componenttext: Yes. I know, that's helpful. The follow-up then has to go to any idea of the kind of overall market, whether you're seeing given that the vacancy rate in the overall market hasn't come down much, business uncertainties maybe a little bit higher. Marc, you talked about earlier this year worried about kind of job growth slowing and maybe some of that impact in the back half of the year. Is this -- is New York City a market where you can see positive rent growth? Not that you necessarily need it, or is things flatten out from here you think?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have look at our own portfolio and our own [indiscernible]. Because we've got $1.6 million in the pipe in the 20% mark-to-market. I couldn't sit here and say I think rents are going down because of that evidence, you know what I'm saying? We could look
componenttext: I have look at our own portfolio and our own [indiscernible]. Because we've got $1.6 million in the pipe in the 20% mark-to-market. I couldn't sit here and say I think rents are going down because of that evidence, you know what I'm saying? We could look at in the future and speculate as to what the longer-term trends might look like. But we're busily at work trying to close out that $1.6 million fairly substantial rental increases. So I guess I'd had to answer that question by saying it looks like we're going to get those increases. The other way of saying is I would have raised the guidance 22% if I did feel pretty good about that. I did say earlier at the outset that it has suprised us in the upside. I didn't expect the second half of the year to be quite as good as it looks like it's planning out to be. In response to someone's earlier question, maybe we're outperforming the market. So you could have a situation where both things are true. And that's okay for us, which is maybe the market is slowing a bit and rental growth is slowing a bit. But it's our portfolio is still full speed ahead. Then I don't want to question it. I want to go with that and do more of that and keep going and differentiate ourselves from the markets. That's what you look for, I think, the top companies in the industry's that set of differentiation. We're not bigger than the market, but we can certainly do better than the market. And I think we haven't will. So I think both good through, but we see a very good environment over the next 6 months to conduct our business and finish out our year and hit these sort of sector-leading numbers then towards the end-of-the-year we'll give you our view of '17, which I think is a little too early because I'd like to see a few more months of job numbers before I even go there. Let's see June, July, August and the balance of the year and see where those job numbers go, because if the private sector job numbers, opportunity job numbers are up, and still not up as much as last year and the years prior, but in the range of 50,000 new jobs plus and 50,000 plus office leasing jobs, then we're still in a good market. But I want to see that data.

componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back on an earlier comment on the leasing side. Steve, I know you said that in general is kind of an expansionary mode. I'm just curious, are you seeing the pendulum swing back at all in tenants getting more efficient in the space?
componenttext: I just wanted to go back on an earlier comment on the leasing side. Steve, I know you said that in general is kind of an expansionary mode. I'm just curious, are you seeing the pendulum swing back at all in tenants getting more efficient in the space?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are they getting more efficient? I think every tenant continues to try to maximize efficiency. You've heard me say in the years past, I don't think that's a trend that ever goes away. It's just a function of what people are willing to do through a combina
componenttext: Are they getting more efficient? I think every tenant continues to try to maximize efficiency. You've heard me say in the years past, I don't think that's a trend that ever goes away. It's just a function of what people are willing to do through a combination of technology and ultimately allocation per person. But yes, everybody wants to either use the space differently that can be set of like just cultural. And others may want to use it differently and that goes to space per employee. But I don't think we're seeing anything different today than we saw last year or 18 months ago or even 2.5 years ago.

componenttext: I got you. We've heard soundbites of that, yes. But I can't say that there's anybody who found the absolute perfect solution for themselves. There's been a number of examples were tenants have gone out and tried to be overly aggressive as to the small amount of allocation per square footage per person, and then had to come back and adjust it because it was operationally too taxing on their employees. But I don't -- I think those are exceptions to the rule.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing of note. I mean if we saw a contraction in this market: A, we would tell you; B, we would have a different tone on this call. There's no sublease space that's the first contraction. Shadow vacant space doesn't really fit. All the big financial fir
componenttext: Nothing of note. I mean if we saw a contraction in this market: A, we would tell you; B, we would have a different tone on this call. There's no sublease space that's the first contraction. Shadow vacant space doesn't really fit. All the big financial firms that might have had a sublet space in the past, Craig, they all own their buildings now. Goldman owns their own building. Citi owns their own building. Morgan owns their own building. Those buildings are not going to be for the most part multitenant. JPMorgan owns their own building. I don't think we're subletting the building. I don't think they're going to shed space and take in -- we'll multitenant 270 Park. It's a different market today, and it's good. More balanced, we're diverse, a lot of big financials own their own facilities for safety and security and control reasons, which is probably smart. That puts more tenants competing for less inventory because that space is not on the market or nondirect submarket. I hear the nature of the questions, we're just not seeing it right now and which is why we're upping our guidance on different levels. If you saw that [indiscernible]

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, on same store NOI. Sorry if I missed this. But last year, you had a termination fee associated with 919 3rd. Did that have any effect on same-store NOI growth this quarter? Were there any other kind of onetime items? And what would the normalize res
componenttext: Matt, on same store NOI. Sorry if I missed this. But last year, you had a termination fee associated with 919 3rd. Did that have any effect on same-store NOI growth this quarter? Were there any other kind of onetime items? And what would the normalize result be if you adjusted for any of that?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It didn't have any effect on same-store cash NOI. The termination fee received last year at 919 is paid out over time, so it's included in GAAP NOI, but not in cash NOI. So really a pure cash termination. These were received second quarter of last year wo
componenttext: It didn't have any effect on same-store cash NOI. The termination fee received last year at 919 is paid out over time, so it's included in GAAP NOI, but not in cash NOI. So really a pure cash termination. These were received second quarter of last year would be about $2.2 million as against about [ph] $1.4 million we received in the second quarter of this year. So it did affect GAAP NOI but not cash flow.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you guys talk a little bit about the Omnicom extension you guys recently signed? I think that reduces their expiration 2017 to close to 225,000 to 250,000 square feet. So what's the plan for the rest of that space? I think there have be
componenttext: Okay. And then can you guys talk a little bit about the Omnicom extension you guys recently signed? I think that reduces their expiration 2017 to close to 225,000 to 250,000 square feet. So what's the plan for the rest of that space? I think there have been some talk about selling condo interest in the 300,000 square feet that they had expiring when you talked about that last quarter. Any update on what's going on there?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Omnicom's story is a great story on many fronts. When their lease was originally scheduled to expire, we had 0 expectation as they would be renewing any portion of the space, because they've got a big portfolio in town and they were making other plans
componenttext: The Omnicom's story is a great story on many fronts. When their lease was originally scheduled to expire, we had 0 expectation as they would be renewing any portion of the space, because they've got a big portfolio in town and they were making other plans. But we had a very good relationship with them, and their business needs change. If you can background they had a big deal with us at the beginning of the year. And then thought they were put to bed. And this most recent renewal is a function of them growing body count and wanting to do business with one of the preferred vendors, so they picked up another 64,000 square feet. We've got a large lease that we're -- a large transaction that we are working on for a big account that's remaining but it's premature for now.

componenttext: Just looking at all the leasing that you've done last year and especially the first half have been really strong. componenttext: It's Matt. Certainly it sets us up nicely, because of the benefit of the leasing that we do this year generally pulls through 12 months later. You're right, we're not going to give any guidance at this point. We'll touch on that in December. But it's certainly put us on a good trajectory. Bear in mind, of course, that we had very strong growth last year like, growing [ph] 4.5% [ph]. And we're going to be north of 6% this year. So we're growing off a big base but Steve is setting us up nicely.

componenttext: I know you said on prior calls that risk your lower quality assets in New York might be repriced downward this year. Have you seen that actually come in fruition, and if so maybe what kind of magnitude or impact are you seeing on a percentage basis?

componenttext: I think it sort of depends on the building of the situation. There's a building on 9th Avenue trading which I think would've fit in that category. And then there's other sidestreets, really inferior assets that because of the change in financing cost and maybe backed up 3% to 5%. Nothing major.

componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp. Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also, during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measure most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's second quarter 2016 earnings. 
Before turning the call over to Marc Holliday, Chief Executive Officer of SL Green Realty Corp., I ask that those of you participating in the Q&A portion of the call, please limit your questions to 2 per person. 
Thank you. I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, operator. We're pleased that all of you joined us on this gorgeous day at New York City, and we're even happier that we were able to put out yet another quarter of strong operating results and market-leading capital transactions. Our seco
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, operator. We're pleased that all of you joined us on this gorgeous day at New York City, and we're even happier that we were able to put out yet another quarter of strong operating results and market-leading capital transactions. Our second quarter results continue a trend in 2016 of surprising to the upside and leasing velocity and rental achievement. We executed another 620,000 square feet of Manhattan office leases, highlighted by the recently announced expansion of Bloomberg in 919 Third Avenue and the renewal and expansion of New York Life at Graybar Building. In fact, SL Green was responsible for 3 of the 8 largest leases transacted in the second quarter in Midtown, Bloomberg, New York Life and Wells Fargo at 100 Park Avenue. 
The mark-to-market on the second quarter Manhattan leases was a robust 16%, bringing first half 2016 average rental increases on replacement leases to 28%. And that's on about 1.5 million square feet of leasing during 6 months. I think it speaks for itself as an extraordinary accomplishment. 
Velocity continues even into the month of July, with another 84,000 square feet of leasing in office in Manhattan in just the past 3 weeks at an 18% mark-to-market inclusive of the recent Omnicom renewal at 220 East 42nd Street. 
In terms of forecasting these leasing trends for the remainder of the year, I would note that the best indicator of what those results are likely to trend towards would be our current leasing pipeline. That current pipeline stands today at about 1.6 million square feet, the vast majority of which is comprised of leases pending, 4 leases out for signature. And notably, the mark-to-market on all of those pipeline deals exceeds 20%. 
So fortunately for shareholders and unfortunately for Steve Durels and his leasing team, we must and are increasing our full year guidance for completed Manhattan office leases to 2.6 million square feet for the full year and mark-to-market on those leases, which are replacement leases, to 22% mark-to-market. So numbers that, in each case, are fairly significantly ahead of where we were in December. That sound you just heard was Steve hitting the floor. You can pick yourself up, Steve, and let's keep -- let's just put the best face on and go forward, okay? 
In this manner, we provide additional motivation and encouragement to our leasing and operations team to execute at the highest level that's consistent with this firm's culture of hard work and outperformance. 
These leasing results and our projection of second half performance is driven by continual demand for high-quality, well-located, reasonably priced office space, which descriptively is the sweet spot of our entire portfolio. 
Midtown space continues to be in high demand as the vacancy rate decreased 10 basis points to 9.2%, and sublease space in Midtown stands at only 2.9 million square feet, near historical lows over the past 8 or 9 years for sublease space. Very important barometer, we haven't talked about that on the last few conference calls, but we're talking about sublease space in Midtown that's about 1.1% of total inventory. So very, very well. 
Job creation in the financial security sector is roughly flat for the year. I think, contrary to market perspective that there has been some substantial contraction in this sector, it's actually, I think, going down about 1,000 jobs year-to-date, which on that job basis is essentially 0. But interestingly, the FIRE sector, finance, insurance real estate, is accounting for much of the first half leasing activity in Midtown and elsewhere. Health care is also making a reasonably good showing, but I would say financial services had an above-average showing in the first half of the year. 
That activity, and all that -- whether it's the FIRE sector, health care or otherwise, is driven by jobs and job creation. Unfortunately, the June New York City job numbers are not out yet. They're going to be out imminently. We would have hoped to have had them for the call, but we don't. But if it's any indicator, the national numbers that came out from Bureau of Labor Statistics for June were quite strong relative to May and earlier. And we're hopeful that the New York City numbers will follow and inform the national numbers. In part, it's almost self-fulfilling because the end of the Verizon strike in and of itself will probably put back on the rolls of the city, I think, 3,000-plus jobs in June. So we're just hoping that and more growth on top of that, but we'll see shortly.
So that's a quick snapshot of the leasing picture. I'm sure you guys will have questions as we go forward. But I also want to make sure we touch upon the investment side of the portfolio. We did complete some important divestitures during the quarter, including the Citigroup headquarters building sale, 33 Beekman sale, and sale of the suburban property in Greenwich. The proceeds of these significant capital transactions went to pay down debt and invest in certain new opportunities, including a 20% stake in a recently completed residential project on the West Side, known as Sky, and an additional investment in the debt and preferred equity portfolio. 
On the topic of DPE, we are still on track and reaffirm our December guidance that for year-end balances, we'll be just shy of $2 billion, about $1.95 billion of balance, and contribution for the year should be on the order of about $200 million of gross revenues from that book of business.
We have sizable, identified pipeline of deals that we expect to close during the second half of the year, carrying routine spreads of approximately 9.9% for that pipeline book of business, which is higher than first half's achievement, but when blended will certainly exceed the 8.5% that was used in our earnings guidance back in December and then our earnings revision at the first quarter. So that's a very, I'd say, positive story and a good market for us to be conducting our business with on the lending side as well as on the equity on real estate side.
We have been market leaders in the provision of subordinate debt capital for large and small New York City commercial projects for years and years. We established that position by being the most active lender in that market, I guess, for nearly 20 years. So there's a reputation and franchise and knowledge of the business, which I think you'll see has been paying off over the years and will be a shining example through the balance of this year. 
With excellent visibility at this point into our remaining 2016 production and performance, given there's only 5.5 months to go, our focus will naturally turn to 2017 and beyond. In order to meet our stated objective of delivering market-leading recurring earnings growth and sector-leading total return to shareholder growth, we have positioned our investment portfolio to generate substantial increases in NOI through leasing up the remainder of the growth portfolio and taking advantage of the embedded rental mark-to-market in our stabilized office and retail portfolios. 
These engines of growth should enable us to continue to deliver sector-leading increases in FFO over the next 3 to 5 years, and this is before accounting for the earnings contributions from One Vanderbilt. Speaking of One Vanderbilt, we are on track with this iconic development project, with the site now almost 100% cleared of the 4 older buildings that formerly occupied the site. Heavy equipment is rolled in to complete the removal of the last 2 floors. And in 3 weeks, we will have a clean site ready to be excavated and foundations poured. Extraordinary amount of credit goes to our construction and operations team for undertaking over the past year what we believe to be the largest surgical demolition of commercial buildings in decades. And it was done on time, on budget and in a safe manner. And New York City is better for it. There's barely a day that goes by we're not getting a comment from somebody who sees how that site is now being transformed in a way to upgrade the appreciation you have of these great landmark properties that surround the site, like Grand Central and Chrysler and Lincoln and others. It's by allowing what will replace those buildings, the new building having setbacks to the property line in a tapered form to let in maximum light there, enormous benefit to the city, to the skyline and to this company by adding this extraordinary building to our portfolio. 
Our financing arrangements for the $1.5 billion construction loan are on track as we've signed the final term sheet with a consortium of 5 lenders, and we will look to have the loan fully committed and closed by the end of the third quarter.
You also saw we took advantage of interest rates by entering into a $300 million swap, 7-year term swap. And what's interesting to note is that in the past 2 Decembers, Andrew Mathias, quick write-up on the screen, another engine of earnings growth, which I think doesn't get the proper amount of due, which is not top line revenue growth but bottom line debt service savings. And we showed that there was extraordinary amount of mark-to-market savings that we could achieve over the next 3 to 5 years in our debt book by having rates just basically stay roughly where they were when we went through the analysis in December. In fact, rates have fallen since then, so I would imagine the opportunity for us at this moment exceeds the $30 million or $40 million per year annually that we have forecasted at that point. And these swaps are one -- just one point of evidence of how we can take advantage of that because the rate we locked in for 7 years is actually lower than the floating rate we had forecasted for the year. Recall, we always model LIBOR curve plus 50 basis points, and the amount, what was it, 1.13?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: 1.14%, we locked in for 7 years is actually below that floating rate now and now locked in for 7 years. So clearly, we are going to be intensely focused on these kinds of opportunities with the rest of our debt portfolio to take advantage of rates, lock i
componenttext:
1.14%, we locked in for 7 years is actually below that floating rate now and now locked in for 7 years. So clearly, we are going to be intensely focused on these kinds of opportunities with the rest of our debt portfolio to take advantage of rates, lock in these sort of historical lows where we can and where it's prudent to do so and wind up hopefully creating a fourth measure of earnings growth on the debt service expense savings side. 
So I feel like we are firing on all cylinders. I said that last quarter. I feel like the cylinders are still properly functioning. I feel very good about our positioning in the market for the present and for the future. Our same-store portfolio was 97.4% leased. Our leverage levels were the lowest in the company's history and getting better. Our liquidity exceeds $1.5 billion. We expect to have little or no line of credit balance outstanding by year-end based on projections for the balance of the year. We have substantial storehouses of growth embedded in the portfolio, which I mentioned, and we're on track to develop the greatest buildings in New York City.
So with that, I'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of David Toti with BB&T.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of David Toti with BB&T.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on the sort of tenant mindset from your perspective. You got a bunch of big leases expiring in the next year or 2, and the market's been a little bit jittery. Have you noticed any change in attitude in renewal conversations or new t
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on the sort of tenant mindset from your perspective. You got a bunch of big leases expiring in the next year or 2, and the market's been a little bit jittery. Have you noticed any change in attitude in renewal conversations or new tenant conversations in the last quarter or 2?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve will address the sort of the tenant mindset and/or mood, but I just wanted -- I want to go back to the supplemental while Steve's answering. I think we have very little in the way of -- not even large expirations, very little in the way of expiratio
componenttext: Steve will address the sort of the tenant mindset and/or mood, but I just wanted -- I want to go back to the supplemental while Steve's answering. I think we have very little in the way of -- not even large expirations, very little in the way of expirations in the next -- for the balance of this year and next year. So something we've done and we've done with like a single-minded focus is to do a lot of not just current leasing but forward leasing. The only way we could lease 2.6 million square feet this year when we only had like 1 million or 1.2 million square feet rolling is by putting to bed what could be either exposure or opportunity in 2016, '17, '18. So we'll look back -- I think just I want to make sure we're clear, we have very little in the way of rollover exposure for the balance of this year and next year. But with that said, Steve, what's the thought?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the feedback we're getting from tenants today is no different than what we were getting a year ago. The general mood from the tenants that we speak to was they feel good about their businesses. They think they're in a healthy position. I thin
componenttext: Yes. I think the feedback we're getting from tenants today is no different than what we were getting a year ago. The general mood from the tenants that we speak to was they feel good about their businesses. They think they're in a healthy position. I think it depends on the type of industry you're talking about as to how bullish they are, but most people are still in the mindset of expanding their businesses, making capital commitments as far as restacking or rebuilding and changing how they like to use their space. And I don't think that's ever going to go away for the next several years to come because it's a bit of a cultural thing. And tenants, we've continued to see tenants that have 2017, '18 expirations a willingness to engage in early renewals. And as Marc touched on, a lot of the sort of outperformance on the leasing velocity within our portfolio is a combination of filling vacancy but also tenants' willingness to step up and do early renewals. And in the 1,600,000 square feet that is in our pipeline, there are some very mini deals inside that pipeline, which we hope to have success on before the end of the year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And if I could just follow up with a quick follow-up. And I know in a vast market, we've actually seen this before, about the presence of WeWork in the New York City market now occupying close to 3 million square feet by some estimat
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And if I could just follow up with a quick follow-up. And I know in a vast market, we've actually seen this before, about the presence of WeWork in the New York City market now occupying close to 3 million square feet by some estimates and recently demonstrating some weakness in revenues or in profits. Does it have any -- does that concern you at all as that number gets larger and larger in the market? And I'm thinking back to the late '90s when we saw a number of sort of WeWork-like tenants kind of disappear during periods of economic weakness. Does that prevent -- present incremental risk in the market, in your mind?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't know that it's accurate to compare WeWork to the other tenants you mentioned. I forgot what period you mentioned, but I guess maybe 2000 or whatever. Was that...
componenttext: Yes. I don't know that it's accurate to compare WeWork to the other tenants you mentioned. I forgot what period you mentioned, but I guess maybe 2000 or whatever. Was that...

componenttextpreview: Late '90s.
componenttext: Late '90s.

componenttextpreview: Late '90s.
componenttext: Late '90s.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm old enough to remember that far back at this point.
componenttext: Yes. I'm old enough to remember that far back at this point.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and we were there, too. So it's a different company with a different model, a very successful model and a model that's attracting an enormous amount of financial support. So to me, the difference between companies, not just fractional office companie
componenttext: Yes, and we were there, too. So it's a different company with a different model, a very successful model and a model that's attracting an enormous amount of financial support. So to me, the difference between companies, not just fractional office companies or full-service communities like WeWork that do their business but really any company to ride through any period of downturn is simply -- well, not simply but is, in large part, capacity and liquidity. So I think that if any of these companies are capitalized properly, and WeWork looks to be like they are, then these downturns in New York tend to be short-lived. Downturn doesn't mean things like go to 0. Downturns in New York may just be marginal rent reductions of 10%, 15%, 20%. I think that the model we've seen them execute in this market is sort of best-of-class, and I think that is generally perceived to be such when you look at the landlords that are doing business, looking to WeWork as sort of, in many cases, a prime tenant. So it doesn't give us concern. 3 million square feet for any tenant on a 400 million square foot inventory, I don't want to be too dismissive, but it's not like 3 million square feet in a 100 million square foot market. It's -- this market is 4x that size. And therefore, we don't -- it's not something that keeps us up at night.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
