componenttextpreview: Just want to go back to an earlier comment on the leasing side. Steve, I know you said that tenants in general are kind of in an expansionary mode. I'm just curious, are you seeing the pendulum swing back at all on tenants trying to get more efficient wit
componenttext: Just want to go back to an earlier comment on the leasing side. Steve, I know you said that tenants in general are kind of in an expansionary mode. I'm just curious, are you seeing the pendulum swing back at all on tenants trying to get more efficient with space?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are they getting more efficient? I think that every tenant continues to try to maximize efficiency. And I -- you've heard me say it in the years past, I don't think that's a trend that ever goes away. It's just a function of what people are willing to do
componenttext: Are they getting more efficient? I think that every tenant continues to try to maximize efficiency. And I -- you've heard me say it in the years past, I don't think that's a trend that ever goes away. It's just a function of what people are willing to do through a combination of technology and ultimately allocations of square footage per person. But yes, everybody wants to either use their space differently, and that can be sort of like just cultural; and others, as to -- they want to use it differently, and that goes to how much space per employee. So -- but I don't think we're seeing anything different today than we saw last year or 18 months ago or even 2.5 years ago.

But I don't -- I think those are exceptions to the rule.

componenttext: Nothing of note. I mean, we would -- if we saw a contraction in this market, a, we would tell you; b, we'd have a different tone on this call. There's no subleased space. That's the first sign of contraction, and shadow vacancy space doesn't really exist. All the big financial firms that might have had a sublet space in the past, Craig, they all own their buildings now. And not even -- Goldman owns their own building.

componenttext: Those buildings are not going to be, for the most part, multi-tenanted. JPMorgan owns their own building at 270. I don't think they're subletting the building. I don't think they're going to, like, shed space and take in and go multi-tenant 270 Park. So it's a different market today, and it's good. It's more balanced. More diverse. A lot of the big financials own their own facilities for safety and security and control reasons, which is probably smart. That puts less -- more tenants competing for less inventory because that space is not on the market on a direct or sublet markets. So we're -- I hear the nature of the questions. We're just not seeing it right now, which is why we're upping our guidance on different levels. If we saw that, we're probably going to hold tight or decrease.

componenttext: Matt, on same-store NOI, sorry if I missed this. But last year, you guys had the termination fee associated with 919 Third. Did that have any effect on same-store NOI growth this quarter? Were there any other kind of onetime items? And what would the normalized result be if you adjusted for any of that?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It didn't have any effect on same-store cash NOI. The termination fee we received last year at 919 is paid out over time, so it's included in GAAP NOI but not in cash NOI. So if you're looking at, pure cash termination fees we received second quarter of l
componenttext: It didn't have any effect on same-store cash NOI. The termination fee we received last year at 919 is paid out over time, so it's included in GAAP NOI but not in cash NOI. So if you're looking at, pure cash termination fees we received second quarter of last year would be about $2.2 million as against about $1.4 million we received in the second quarter of this year. So it did affect GAAP NOI but not cash NOI.

componenttext: Okay. And then can you guys talk a little bit about the Omnicom extension you guys recently signed? I think that reduces their expiration in 2017 to close to 225,000 to 250,000 square feet. So what's the plan for the rest of that space? I think there have been some talk about selling a condo interest in the 300,000 square feet that they had expiring when we talked about it last quarter. So is there any update on what's going on there?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Omnicom story is a great story on many fronts. When their lease was originally scheduled to expire, we had 0 expectation that they would be renewing any portion of the space because they've got a big portfolio in town, and they were making other plans
componenttext: The Omnicom story is a great story on many fronts. When their lease was originally scheduled to expire, we had 0 expectation that they would be renewing any portion of the space because they've got a big portfolio in town, and they were making other plans. But we have a very good relationship with them, and their business needs changed, they came back around the Horn, did a big deal with us at the beginning of the year and then thought they were put to bed. And then this most recent renewal is a function of them growing the body count and wanting to do business with one of their preferred vendors. So we picked up another 64,000 square feet. We've got a large lease that we're -- a large transaction that we are working on for a big chunk of what's remaining, but it's premature to announce.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp. Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, manag
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp. Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also, during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measure most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's second quarter 2016 earnings. 
Before turning the call over to Marc Holliday, Chief Executive Officer of SL Green Realty Corp., I ask that those of you participating in the Q&A portion of the call, please limit your questions to 2 per person. 
Thank you. I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, operator. We're pleased that all of you joined us on this gorgeous day in New York City, and we're even happier that we were able to put out yet another quarter of strong operating results and market-leading capital transactions. Our seco
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, operator. We're pleased that all of you joined us on this gorgeous day in New York City, and we're even happier that we were able to put out yet another quarter of strong operating results and market-leading capital transactions. Our second quarter results continue a trend in 2016 of surprising to the upside in leasing velocity and rental achievement. We executed another 620,000 square feet of Manhattan office leases, highlighted by the recently announced expansion of Bloomberg in 919 Third Avenue and the renewal and expansion of New York Life at Graybar Building. In fact, SL Green was responsible for 3 of the 8 largest leases transacted in the second quarter in Midtown, Bloomberg, New York Life and Wells Fargo at 100 Park Avenue. 
The mark-to-market on the second quarter Manhattan leases was a robust 16%, bringing first half 2016 average rental increases on replacement leases to 28%. And that's on about 1.5 million square feet of leasing during 6 months. I think it speaks for itself as an extraordinary accomplishment. 
Velocity continues even into the month of July, with another 84,000 square feet of leasing in office in Manhattan in just the past 3 weeks at an 18% mark-to-market inclusive of the recent Omnicom renewal at 220 East 42nd Street. 
In terms of forecasting these leasing trends for the remainder of the year, I would note that the best indicator of what those results are likely to trend towards would be our current leasing pipeline. That current pipeline stands today at about 1.6 million square feet, the vast majority of which is comprised of leases pending, 4 leases out for signature. And notably, the mark-to-market on all of those pipeline deals exceeds 20%. 
So fortunately for shareholders and unfortunately for Steve Durels and his leasing team, we must and are increasing our full year guidance for completed Manhattan office leases to 2.6 million square feet for the full year and mark-to-market on those leases, which are replacement leases, to 22% mark-to-market. So numbers that, in each case, are fairly significantly ahead of where we were in December. That sound you just heard was Steve hitting the floor. You can pick yourself up, Steve, and let's keep -- let's just put the best face on and go forward, okay? 
In this manner, we provide additional motivation and encouragement to our leasing and operations team to execute at the highest level that's consistent with this firm's culture of hard work and outperformance. 
These leasing results in our projection of second half performance is driven by continual demand for high-quality, well-located, reasonably priced office space, which descriptively is the sweet spot of our entire portfolio. 
Midtown space continues to be in high demand as the vacancy rate decreased 10 basis points to 9.2%, and sublease space in Midtown stands at only 2.9 million square feet, near historical lows over the past 8 or 9 years for sublease space. Very important barometer, we haven't talked about that on the last few conference calls, but we're talking about sublease space in Midtown that's about 1.1% of total inventory. So very, very well. 
Job creation in the financial security sector is roughly flat for the year. I think, contrary to market perspective that there has been some substantial contraction in this sector, it's actually, I think, going down about 1,000 jobs year-to-date, which on that job basis is essentially 0. But interestingly, the FIRE sector -- finance, insurance, real estate -- is accounting for much of the first half leasing activity in Midtown and elsewhere. Health care is also making a reasonably good showing, but I would say financial services had an above-average showing in the first half of the year. 
That activity, and all that -- whether it's the FIRE sector, health care or otherwise, is driven by jobs and job creation. Unfortunately, the June New York City job numbers are not out yet. They're going to be out imminently. We would have hoped to have had them for the call, but we don't. But if it's any indicator, the national numbers that came out from Bureau of Labor Statistics for June were quite strong relative to May and earlier. And we're hopeful that the New York City numbers will follow and inform the national numbers. In part, it's almost self-fulfilling because the end of the Verizon strike in and of itself will probably put back on the rolls of the city, I think, 3,000-plus jobs in June. So we're just hoping that and more growth on top of that, but we'll see shortly.
So that's a quick snapshot of the leasing picture. I'm sure you guys will have questions as we go forward. But I also want to make sure we touch upon the investment side of the portfolio. We did complete some important divestitures during the quarter, including the Citigroup headquarters building sale, 33 Beekman sale, and sale of the suburban property in Greenwich. The proceeds of these significant capital transactions went to pay down debt and invest in certain new opportunities, including a 20% stake in a recently completed residential project on the West Side, known as Sky, and an additional investment in the debt and preferred equity portfolio. 
On the topic of DPE, we are still on track and reaffirm our December guidance that for year-end balances, we'll be just shy of $2 billion, about $1.95 billion of balance, and contribution for the year should be on the order of about $200 million of gross revenues from that book of business.
We have sizable, identified pipeline of deals that we expect to close during the second half of the year, carrying routine spreads of approximately 9.9% for that pipeline book of business, which is higher than first half's achievement, but when blended will certainly exceed the 8.5% that was used in our earnings guidance back in December and then our earnings revision at the first quarter. So that's a very, I'd say, positive story and a good market for us to be conducting our business with on the lending side as well as on the equity on real estate side.
We have been market leaders in the provision of subordinate debt capital for large and small New York City commercial projects for years and years. We established that position by being the most active lender in that market, I guess, for nearly 20 years. So there's a reputation and franchise and knowledge of the business, which I think you'll see has been paying off over the years and will be a shining example through the balance of this year. 
With excellent visibility at this point into our remaining 2016 production and performance, given there's only 5.5 months to go, our focus will naturally turn to 2017 and beyond. In order to meet our stated objective of delivering market-leading recurring earnings growth and sector-leading total return to shareholder growth, we have positioned our investment portfolio to generate substantial increases in NOI through leasing up the remainder of the growth portfolio and taking advantage of the embedded rental mark-to-market in our stabilized office and retail portfolios. 
These engines of growth should enable us to continue to deliver sector-leading increases in FFO over the next 3 to 5 years, and this is before accounting for the earnings contributions from One Vanderbilt. Speaking of One Vanderbilt, we are on track with this iconic development project, with the site now almost 100% cleared of the 4 older buildings that formerly occupied the site. Heavy equipment is rolled in to complete the removal of the last 2 floors. And in 3 weeks, we will have a clean site ready to be excavated and foundations poured. Extraordinary amount of credit goes to our construction and operations team for undertaking over the past year what we believe to be the largest surgical demolition of commercial buildings in decades. And it was done on time, on budget and in a safe manner. And New York City is better for it. There's barely a day that goes by we're not getting a comment from somebody who sees how that site is now being transformed in a way to upgrade the appreciation you have of these great landmark properties that surround the site, like Grand Central and Chrysler and Lincoln and others. It's by allowing what will replace those buildings, the new building having setbacks to the property line in a tapered form to let in maximum light there, enormous benefit to the city, to the skyline and to this company by adding this extraordinary building to our portfolio. 
Our financing arrangements for the $1.5 billion construction loan are on track as we've signed the final term sheet with a consortium of 5 lenders, and we will look to have the loan fully committed and closed by the end of the third quarter.
You also saw we took advantage of interest rates by entering into a $300 million swap, 7-year term swap. And what's interesting to note is that in the past 2 Decembers, Andrew Mathias, quick write-up on the screen, another engine of earnings growth, which I think doesn't get the proper amount of due, which is not top line revenue growth but bottom line debt service savings. And we showed that there was extraordinary amount of mark-to-market savings that we could achieve over the next 3 to 5 years in our debt book by having rates just basically stay roughly where they were when we went through the analysis in December. In fact, rates have fallen since then, so I would imagine the opportunity for us at this moment exceeds the $30 million or $40 million per year annually that we have forecasted at that point. And these swaps are one -- just one point of evidence of how we can take advantage of that because the rate we locked in for 7 years is actually lower than the floating rate we had forecasted for the year. Recall, we always model LIBOR curve plus 50 basis points, and the amount, what was it, 1.13?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: 1.14%, we locked in for 7 years is actually below that floating rate now and now locked in for 7 years. So clearly, we are going to be intensely focused on these kinds of opportunities with the rest of our debt portfolio to take advantage of rates, lock i
componenttext:
1.14%, we locked in for 7 years is actually below that floating rate now and now locked in for 7 years. So clearly, we are going to be intensely focused on these kinds of opportunities with the rest of our debt portfolio to take advantage of rates, lock in these sort of historical lows where we can and where it's prudent to do so and wind up hopefully creating a fourth measure of earnings growth on the debt service expense savings side. 
So I feel like we are firing on all cylinders. I said that last quarter. I feel like the cylinders are still properly functioning. I feel very good about our positioning in the market for the present and for the future. Our same-store portfolio was 97.4% leased. Our leverage levels are the lowest in the company's history and getting better. Our liquidity exceeds $1.5 billion. We expect to have little or no line of credit balance outstanding by year-end based on projections for the balance of year. We have substantial storehouses of growth embedded in the portfolio, which I mentioned, and we're on track to develop the greatest buildings in New York City.
So with that, I'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of David Toti with BB&T.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of David Toti with BB&T.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on the sort of tenant mindset from your perspective. You got a bunch of big leases expiring in the next year or 2, and the market's been a little bit jittery. Have you noticed any change in attitude in renewal conversations or new t
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on the sort of tenant mindset from your perspective. You got a bunch of big leases expiring in the next year or 2, and the market's been a little bit jittery. Have you noticed any change in attitude in renewal conversations or new tenant conversations in the last quarter or 2?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve will address the sort of the tenant mindset and/or mood, but I just wanted -- I want to go back to the supplemental while Steve's answering. I think we have very little in the way of -- not even large expirations, very little in the way of expiratio
componenttext: Steve will address the sort of the tenant mindset and/or mood, but I just wanted -- I want to go back to the supplemental while Steve's answering. I think we have very little in the way of -- not even large expirations, very little in the way of expirations in the next -- for the balance of this year and next year. So something we've done and we've done with like a single-minded focus is to do a lot of not just current leasing but forward leasing. The only way we could lease 2.6 million square feet this year when we only had like 1 million or 1.2 million square feet rolling is by putting to bed what could be either exposure or opportunity in 2016, '17, '18. So we'll look back -- I think just I want to make sure we're clear, we have very little in the way of rollover exposure for the balance of this year and next year. But with that said, Steve, what's the thought?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the feedback we're getting from tenants today is no different than what we were getting a year ago. The general mood from the tenants that we speak to was they feel good about their businesses. They think they're in a healthy position. I thin
componenttext: Yes. I think the feedback we're getting from tenants today is no different than what we were getting a year ago. The general mood from the tenants that we speak to was they feel good about their businesses. They think they're in a healthy position. I think it depends on the type of industry you're talking about as to how bullish they are, but most people are still in the mindset of expanding their businesses, making capital commitments as far as restacking or rebuilding and changing how they like to use their space. And I don't think that's ever going to go away for the next several years to come because it's a bit of a cultural thing. And tenants, we've continued to see tenants that have 2017, '18 expirations a willingness to engage in early renewals. And as Marc touched on, a lot of the sort of outperformance on the leasing velocity within our portfolio is a combination of filling vacancy but also tenants' willingness to step up and do early renewals. And in the 1,600,000 square feet that is in our pipeline, there are some very meaty deals inside that pipeline, which we hope to have success on before the end of the year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And if I could just follow up with a quick follow-up. And I know we've asked Marc, we've asked you this before, about the presence of WeWork in the New York City market now occupying close to 3 million square feet by some estimates a
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And if I could just follow up with a quick follow-up. And I know we've asked Marc, we've asked you this before, about the presence of WeWork in the New York City market now occupying close to 3 million square feet by some estimates and recently demonstrating some weakness in revenues or in profits. Does it have any -- does that concern you at all as that number gets larger and larger in the market? And I'm thinking back to the late '90s when we saw a number of sort of WeWork-like tenants kind of disappear during periods of economic weakness. Does that prevent -- present incremental risk in the market, in your mind?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't know that it's accurate to compare WeWork to the other tenants you mentioned. I forgot what period you mentioned, but I guess maybe 2000 or whatever. Was that...
componenttext: Yes. I don't know that it's accurate to compare WeWork to the other tenants you mentioned. I forgot what period you mentioned, but I guess maybe 2000 or whatever. Was that...

componenttext: Late '90s.

componenttext: Late '90s.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm old enough to remember that far back at this point.
componenttext: Yes. I'm old enough to remember that far back at this point.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and we were there, too. So it's a different company with a different model, a very successful model and a model that's attracting an enormous amount of financial support. So to me, the difference between companies, not just fractional office companie
componenttext: Yes, and we were there, too. So it's a different company with a different model, a very successful model and a model that's attracting an enormous amount of financial support. So to me, the difference between companies, not just fractional office companies or full-service communities like WeWork that do their business but really any company to ride through any period of downturn is simply -- well, not simply but is, in large part, capacity and liquidity. So I think that if any of these companies are capitalized properly, and WeWork looks to be like they are, then these downturns in New York tend to be short-lived. Downturn doesn't mean things like go to 0. Downturns in New York may just be marginal rent reductions of 10%, 15%, 20%. I think that the model we've seen them execute in this market is sort of best-of-class, and I think that is generally perceived to be such when you look at the landlords that are doing business, looking to WeWork as sort of, in many cases, a prime tenant. So it doesn't give us concern. 3 million square feet for any tenant on a 400 million square foot inventory, I don't want to be too dismissive, but it's not like 3 million square feet in a 100 million square foot market. It's -- this market is 4x that size. And therefore, we don't -- it's not something that keeps us up at night.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: And I would say, on the investment side, we haven't seen any change. There's some expectation that New York will draw even more capital interest as London is less attractive for foreign investment. Still too early to tell on that front. We're monitoring the deals that are in the market now, and certainly, values are holding up or even taking another step forward. But it's too early to sort of tie that to Brexit or not.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And my second question is on your leasing pipeline. I was wondering if One Vanderbilt was a component of that, and if so, how much?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It's -- in that 1.6 million, nothing is directly connected to One Vanderbilt nor would we expect it to be. We are 4-plus years out before we're delivering the building. And although we're actively presenting the building, we are early to the game. And
componenttext: No. It's -- in that 1.6 million, nothing is directly connected to One Vanderbilt nor would we expect it to be. We are 4-plus years out before we're delivering the building. And although we're actively presenting the building, we are early to the game. And we've got a stretch goal for the company to do some leasing this year of about 200,000 square feet. But like in every year, we have a list of goals, and then we have stretch goals because we push ourselves to outperform. And we're working hard at it, but nothing to announce yet.

componenttext: Just wondering on the leasing activity that you've done for the quarter here. You guys have posted some very good results here in the first half. componenttextpreview: Yes. So I mean, I think it sort of speaks for itself. We are -- we'd like to think of ourselves as having among the best platforms in New York City and executing these kind of deals. So there's a wide disparity of buildings and ownership groups that compr
componenttext: Yes. So I mean, I think it sort of speaks for itself. We are -- we'd like to think of ourselves as having among the best platforms in New York City and executing these kind of deals. So there's a wide disparity of buildings and ownership groups that comprise the 400 million feet of inventory in the city. I hope we're, if not the best, among the best, but I'd like to think we are the best. And as a result, we, I think, have a unusual scale and footprint in the city, almost 30 million square feet of real estate. So we are able to kind of leverage that position to maximize our relationships with tenants, partners, lenders and vendors to keep this portfolio 97.5% leased, maximize our rent, keep our TIs, leasing concessions low. I don't think anybody mentioned that, but I think it's worthy of mentioning. I think we are about $26 a foot or $30 a foot thereabout for the quarter. So quite efficient, I think, in terms of how we executed the business, and that's our calling card.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just add, too. I think the market is better than those reports are actually indicating as well. A lot of the market reports that get printed are -- lag reality. And we're in a better market than statistically that's being reported, as evidenced by
componenttext: Let me just add, too. I think the market is better than those reports are actually indicating as well. A lot of the market reports that get printed are -- lag reality. And we're in a better market than statistically that's being reported, as evidenced by some of the deals that we are working on, that we think are going to close in the third quarter and as evidenced by some of the deals that closed at the very end of the second quarter. So we are ahead of the market, we're doing well, but I think the market's better than what it's actually been those -- in those reports.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just going back to the Brexit question just on a different angle. I mean, I guess it's still very early days in terms of what's going on and what the impacts might look like. But I guess does this pique your interest at all in the -- lookin
componenttext: And then maybe just going back to the Brexit question just on a different angle. I mean, I guess it's still very early days in terms of what's going on and what the impacts might look like. But I guess does this pique your interest at all in the -- looking at London again?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I think that, that sort of reinforces our strategy, which is a question from time to time of wanting to be sort of a sharpshooter in one market. I think we attempted to not just -- it wasn't by accident. We chose to do $25 billion of business i
componenttext: All right. I think that, that sort of reinforces our strategy, which is a question from time to time of wanting to be sort of a sharpshooter in one market. I think we attempted to not just -- it wasn't by accident. We chose to do $25 billion of business in one market. It was designed to be done in what we thought was the market that had the best liquidity, stability, transparency, depth of market participants, Fortune 500 tenants. London, I think, exhibits many of those traits, but I think New York is a better market going in. And I don't think there's any more desire on our part to diversify into that market or other markets, which we would almost deem as like adverse diversification. So there's plenty for us to do in this city, both -- in office, retail, multi then preferred equity. We've got actually quite a full plate. And while there may be some good opportunities in London that emerge, my guess is that'll be taken advantage of by people who have or groups that have significant footprints in that market. So I wouldn't think so, but it's not something we've looked at all that closely at the moment. If shareholders start asking us to take a look at it, maybe we'll become more focused. But it's not a topic.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: So whether it's the reports from the brokers or street FFO estimates, you topped expectations in the second quarter. And I'm just curious about your guidance for the full year. Are you expecting kind of -- I guess I could back up, was this better than your expectations for 2Q? And then do you expect any kind of slowdown the rest of the year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Matt. So the quarter was, on expectations, maybe slightly better. It was a really solid quarter, solid first 6 months of the year. We obviously always want to be accurate in our guidance, conservative and prudent. And as we look out over the balance
componenttext: It's Matt. So the quarter was, on expectations, maybe slightly better. It was a really solid quarter, solid first 6 months of the year. We obviously always want to be accurate in our guidance, conservative and prudent. And as we look out over the balance of the year, where we reset guidance only 3 months ago, which is pretty unusual, only 3 months into the year to adjust. We feel good with the range. You have to keep an eye on a couple of things that we have out there, not the least of which is the potential impact of the Aropostale situation at 1515 Broadway, which has not yet resolved itself. That may have an impact. And so at this point, we felt it was prudent to keep the FFO guidance for the moment unchanged.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up, I'm not sure how much you could say on this, but on One Vanderbilt, the decision to JV or not sell a JV interest and then kind of the timing of that, how do you think about the risk/reward of mitigating some of the lease-up ri
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up, I'm not sure how much you could say on this, but on One Vanderbilt, the decision to JV or not sell a JV interest and then kind of the timing of that, how do you think about the risk/reward of mitigating some of the lease-up risk, maybe JV early maybe you wait and try to get a better pricing as it's closer to stabilization? Or is it too early to talk about that?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said in December and reiterated on the last call and I guess I'll say again now, just as a refresher, all focus right now is on closing out that loan, as I think it should be. I think the first order of business and an important part of the
componenttext: Well, what we said in December and reiterated on the last call and I guess I'll say again now, just as a refresher, all focus right now is on closing out that loan, as I think it should be. I think the first order of business and an important part of the overall capitalization of this project is to get a properly structured price, $1.5 billion construction loan facility closed out, which we've been working intensely hard on for several months now and looks like we're nearing the conclusion point and hope to have that close in the next 60 days or so, 60, 75 days. So I think at -- along the way, we have begun to have conversations with equity investors, I would say, all of which have gone exceedingly well in terms of receptivity of these various institutional players who have the capacity to fund a deal like this and have the desire to be a part of development projects, which are kind of best building, best market, best location. With that said, there are certain signals from our shareholders and analysts about trying to expedite, do it rapidly. We're not on that approach. It's a bad approach. We don't want to -- I think, I mean, just there's no exact right or wrong , but we think that for a project like this, we should see the whole market. And there's going to be a lot of different opportunities out there, different structures, different amounts, different kind of yield enhancements available to this company. We're working very closely with Hines in this regard. I'd say by the end of this year, we'll have covered, I don't know, like, maybe 40 of the top domestic and foreign investors in the world for a project like this. And then we'll try and zero in and grind it down to the right partner for a project like this. You don't want the wrong partner. You want to make sure this is the absolute right partner, shares a long-term vision, has the capacity to fund side by side all the way through the project and has a real deep love and affection for this project. I'm confident we'll get there as I was confident we would find the -- pull together the debt financing. It is not -- this is not on a -- like a urgent track, not on a fast track. It's on what I would call kind of a responsible track for a project like this. Remember, there's very little money spend right now. I keep reinforcing the fact that most of the money spend begins middle of '17 when you start going vertical on a project. We've kind of fully decided unencumbered. We have no partners. We'll be funding whatever remains in demo and activation just out of cash flow between now and year-end. And then we get to do some initial loan draws where our expectation is we'll be able to do initial loan draws on the loan facility to basically prime the pump for 2017. So we have time. We think the market's coming our way because as rates drop and you have things like Brexit, which take a fairly attractive and competitive market and maybe puts it on the sidelines for a year or 2, I think we'll be the beneficiary of, at least temporarily, if not permanently, some excess investment dollars, searching for projects like One Vanderbilt. And I think it's our job to take advantage of that. So we're on -- we're proceeding at pace, and we'll definitely keep you apprised, but I have said, I didn't expect much in the way of announceable events on the JV side in '16. I would probably reiterate that at this point.

Matt, please. And other questions I'm sure you'll have at that point, I would say suffice it to say, we look at it as a very good piece of financing that is, in all respects, equal or, well, really consistent with our business plan in all respects, not just in pricing but in things as it relates to funding and et cetera. So we're going to just get that done, and then hopefully on the next call, we'll be able to share with you some details.

componenttext: I mean, but Marc, can you just at least say, are there still things that you -- like documents that you still have to go over with the lenders? Or is it just a matter of lawyers going over the loan document before it's signed in 60 days?

componenttext: I'm not sure. We're documenting the deal, so I mean, that's the whole 60, 75. And we're at the point of a term sheet. And now the term sheet has all -- now you document and close. So that's where we are. It's not like documents are in escrow. But it's -- so it's really customary.

componenttext: Maybe if we just think about the investment environment in New York city overall, have you seen buyer pools or buyer appetites change to date? headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's still a little bit too early to tell. I mean, we're seeing values hold up to take a step forward even in certain cases. But it's too early to tell whether those buyers are sort of forum shopping and would have otherwise been investing in Lond
componenttext: I think it's still a little bit too early to tell. I mean, we're seeing values hold up to take a step forward even in certain cases. But it's too early to tell whether those buyers are sort of forum shopping and would have otherwise been investing in London but are now investing in New York or if it's just the natural flows of capital we've been talking about consistently, which are really -- continue to drive values in New York. So it's not -- just not sure if it's situational or if it's more just the overall trend we've been tracking.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

If you think about rents when you first announced the project and first thought about the project to where they are now to where they'll be when you sign, what's the trajectory those meant?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we put rents up in December. And our whole approach was to price the building in 2021 at rents that are consistent with what the best buildings are getting in the city today. So we view that very conservatively because our pro formas are based on, I
componenttext: Well, we put rents up in December. And our whole approach was to price the building in 2021 at rents that are consistent with what the best buildings are getting in the city today. So we view that very conservatively because our pro formas are based on, I guess, what you would say no growth in those rents over 5 or 6 years, offer today's best rents, even though this building will -- as a physical -- as physical space and infrastructure, sustainability and views and ceiling heights and concrete [ph] nature, will be far in excess of most of those buildings considered the best buildings. We just kind of priced it based off of today's rents. And those rents are going to go up and down over the next 5, 6 years. You mentioned earlier the bulk of the leasing we expect to occur, I guess, probably 2018 and beyond. So the real question is, what's the market then? We feel very good about the project's positioning and the rent positioning of the project where we sit today, not just where we sat in December. And we might be conservative; we might not be. But I don't think we're aggressive, and the returns are such that even if the rents are 3% to 5% off, the deal returns for the development side of this quality are still far, far in excess of baseline returns.

componenttext: Weekly, I mean, monthly. There are deals on this sheet, none of which existed in December of '15. Financing deals are not like this. Real estate deals can take anywhere -- can take 1, 2, 3 years to ferment. Transactional activity financings are typically -- have a 3- to 4-month shelf life kind of thing. So none of this was in pipe in December. This is all brand-new product. That which we projected to close in first half, we closed it. You saw we sold a lot of product because if we don't syndicate, then we're going to be far in excess of our balances at year-end. So we may originate over the second half of the year well over $1 billion, but the real issue is not what are we going to close. It's what are we going to retain. We control that, Jamie. So that's how we can be highly confident of hitting our goals when we have a pipeline that might be $1 billion to $1.5 billion, and we're only looking to originate and retain maybe $600 million, $700 million, $800 million between now and then.

componenttext: Well, just if you -- the quick math is, let's say, you have a $75 rent and a $25 OpEx, and that's $50 net, and -- or a $75 rent goes up by 22% while your OpEx stays constant, your cash rent, your net rent is going up much more than 22% unless, of course, you've got a big OpEx increase factored in. And I'm just trying to sense if you guys do that math or not.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is right because it's 22% gross to gross, which would be higher if you went net to net. I think that's right, Matt, yes? Yes, I think that's right. But I guess what we're looking at is within our NOI at any given point in time, you have the net. So t
componenttext: That is right because it's 22% gross to gross, which would be higher if you went net to net. I think that's right, Matt, yes? Yes, I think that's right. But I guess what we're looking at is within our NOI at any given point in time, you have the net. So the question is, how much contribution are you getting to the NOI, which you already -- remember, NOI is already taken out of the expenses. So the contribution is the differential in the gross rent. So if the NOI of the building is $10 million and we sign a new lease and the gross rent goes from $75 million to $80 million, we've got $5 a foot more that's going to drop to that bottom line through the NOI because expenses don't go up when you sign the lease. Your point is that increase on a net basis is probably more than 22%. I think that's right. So we can take a look at that.

componenttext: So the quarter would have been almost 150 basis points higher. But the tendency, Nick, is for the larger leases, the outlier leases may not quite get as much mark-to-market. Your point is, hey, the bigger leases have the biggest mark-to-market and drive the deals. That's not usually our experience in this market. It's the opposite. By number of deals, the number of deals, we have big, big mark-to-market, but then you get some larger deals where you don't always have the exact same pricing power, and you may have to take a lower amount. But whether it's 16% or 28% or 22%, I mean, these are big numbers we're talking about.

componenttext: Yes, no, that's helpful. I mean, is this -- is New York City still a market where you could see some positive rent growth -- not that you necessarily need it, but is -- would things sort of flatten out from here, you think?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I have to look at our own portfolio and our own stats. We've got 1.6 million in pipe with a 20% mark-to-market. So I couldn't sit here and say I think rents are going down because of that evidence. You know what I'm saying? I mean, we could look out i
componenttext: Oh, I have to look at our own portfolio and our own stats. We've got 1.6 million in pipe with a 20% mark-to-market. So I couldn't sit here and say I think rents are going down because of that evidence. You know what I'm saying? I mean, we could look out into the future and sort of speculate as to what the longer-term trends might look like. But we're busily at work trying to close out that 1.6 million at fairly substantial rental increases. So I guess I'd had to answer that question by saying it looks like we're going to get those increases. The other way of saying this, I wouldn't have raised the guidance 22% if I didn't feel pretty good about that. So I did say earlier at the outset that it has surprised us to the upside. I didn't expect the second half of the year to be quite as good as it looks like it's panning out to be. In response to someone's earlier question, maybe we're outperforming the market. So you could have a situation where both things are true, and that's okay for us, which is maybe the market is slowing a bit and rental growth is slowing a bit. But if our portfolio is still full speed ahead, then I don't want to, like, question it. I want to go with that and do more of that and keep going and differentiate ourselves from the market. That's what you look for, I think, in top companies in any industry is that kind of differentiation. We're not bigger than the market, but we can certainly do better than the market, and I think we have and will. So I think both could be true, Nick, but we see a very good environment over the next 6 months to conduct our business and finish out our year and hit these sort of sector-leading numbers and then towards the end of the year, we're going to give you our view of '17, which I think it's a little too early because I'd like to see a few more months of jobs numbers before I even go there. Let's see June, July, August and the balance of the year and see where those jobs numbers go because if the private sector job numbers and opportunity job numbers are up and still not up as much as last year and the years prior but in the range of 50,000 new jobs plus and 50,000 plus are office-using jobs, then we're still in a good market. But I want to see that data.

componenttext: Just want to go back to an earlier comment on the leasing side. Steve, I know you said that tenants in general are kind of in an expansionary mode. I'm just curious, are you seeing the pendulum swing back at all on tenants trying to get more efficient with space?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are they getting more efficient? I think that every tenant continues to try to maximize efficiency. And I -- you've heard me say it in the years past, I don't think that's a trend that ever goes away. It's just a function of what people are willing to do
componenttext: Are they getting more efficient? I think that every tenant continues to try to maximize efficiency. And I -- you've heard me say it in the years past, I don't think that's a trend that ever goes away. It's just a function of what people are willing to do through a combination of technology and ultimately allocations of square footage per person. But yes, everybody wants to either use their space differently, and that can be sort of like just cultural; and others, as to -- they want to use it differently, and that goes to how much space per employee. So -- but I don't think we're seeing anything different today than we saw last year or 18 months ago or even 2.5 years ago.

componenttext: Those buildings are not going to be, for the most part, multi-tenanted. JPMorgan owns their own building at 270. I don't think they're subletting the building. I don't think they're going to, like, shed space and take in and go multi-tenant 270 Park. So it's a different market today, and it's good. It's more balanced. More diverse. A lot of the big financials own their own facilities for safety and security and control reasons, which is probably smart. That puts less -- more tenants competing for less inventory because that space is not on the market on a direct or sublet markets. So we're -- I hear the nature of the questions. We're just not seeing it right now, which is why we're upping our guidance on different levels. If we saw that, we're probably going to hold tight or decrease.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It didn't have any effect on same-store cash NOI. The termination fee we received last year at 919 is paid out over time, so it's included in GAAP NOI but not in cash NOI. So if you're looking at, pure cash termination fees we received second quarter of l
componenttext: It didn't have any effect on same-store cash NOI. The termination fee we received last year at 919 is paid out over time, so it's included in GAAP NOI but not in cash NOI. So if you're looking at, pure cash termination fees we received second quarter of last year would be about $2.2 million as against about $1.4 million we received in the second quarter of this year. So it did affect GAAP NOI but not cash NOI.

componenttext: Okay. And then can you guys talk a little bit about the Omnicom extension you guys recently signed? I think that reduces their expiration in 2017 to close to 225,000 to 250,000 square feet. So what's the plan for the rest of that space? I think there have been some talk about selling a condo interest in the 300,000 square feet that they had expiring when we talked about it last quarter. So is there any update on what's going on there?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Omnicom story is a great story on many fronts. When their lease was originally scheduled to expire, we had 0 expectation that they would be renewing any portion of the space because they've got a big portfolio in town, and they were making other plans
componenttext: The Omnicom story is a great story on many fronts. When their lease was originally scheduled to expire, we had 0 expectation that they would be renewing any portion of the space because they've got a big portfolio in town, and they were making other plans. But we have a very good relationship with them, and their business needs changed, they came back around the Horn, did a big deal with us at the beginning of the year and then thought they were put to bed. And then this most recent renewal is a function of them growing the body count and wanting to do business with one of their preferred vendors. So we picked up another 64,000 square feet. We've got a large lease that we're -- a large transaction that we are working on for a big chunk of what's remaining, but it's premature to announce.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp. Third Quarter 2016 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, managem
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp. Third Quarter 2016 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Also, during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's third quarter 2016 earnings. 
Before turning the call over to Matt DiLiberto, Chief Financial Officer of SL Green Realty Corp., I ask that those of you participating in the Q&A portion of the call please limit your questions to 2 per person. Thank you. 
I will now turn the call over to Matt DiLiberto. Please go ahead, Matt.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone. Before I turn the call over to Marc, I just wanted to take the opportunity to remind everybody of our Annual Investor Conference being held on Monday, December 5, here in New York City at Jazz at Lincoln Cent
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone. Before I turn the call over to Marc, I just wanted to take the opportunity to remind everybody of our Annual Investor Conference being held on Monday, December 5, here in New York City at Jazz at Lincoln Center. For more information, you can email slg2016@slgreen.com. The invitations should be going out in the next couple of weeks. The format has changed slightly this year. We will be beginning at 9 a.m. on Monday, December 5. The door is opening at 8:30 a.m. for a light breakfast, and we would expect to be completed by 1 in the afternoon. So again, for more information, please email slg2016@slgreen.com. 
With that, I will turn it over to our CEO, Marc Holliday.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Matt, and thank you for dialing into the call today. We are happy to have the opportunity to review with you the results of the third quarter and provide some additional commentary on how we see things shaping up in New York City. Conti
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Matt, and thank you for dialing into the call today. We are happy to have the opportunity to review with you the results of the third quarter and provide some additional commentary on how we see things shaping up in New York City. 
Continuing a trend this year where we have outperformed many of our 2016 operating and financial goals, we had a very strong third quarter, punctuated by 1.3 million square feet of Manhattan office leases signed at a market-leading 29% mark-to-market. Once again, SL Green has demonstrated its ability to outperform on the leasing and operational front, notwithstanding any perceived or actual slowdown in the tenant market. In fact, in the first 20 days of October, we concluded 9 additional Manhattan office leases for a total of 212,000 square feet, highlighted by the 2 leases we announced this morning with Comcast and Nixon Peabody at Tower 46, and we welcome those 2 tenants to our portfolio. This brings our total Manhattan leasing production to 3 million square feet. Year-to-date, that's 50% more than we originally forecast and a 28% mark-to-market on replacement leases, which is about double what we originally projected at the beginning of the year. These accomplishments are not just market-leading. They are extraordinary by any measure and will rank among the 2 or 3 best leasing years in our 19-year history as a public company, all the more notable because we achieved these results notwithstanding additional supply from Hudson Yards, making the point that high-quality, well-located and reasonably priced office space is still in very high demand. As further evidence of that tenant demand, we have a current leasing pipeline of nearly 600,000 square feet, approximately half of which are leases pending and out for signature. So I think that shows that notwithstanding we have cleared out a substantial amount of pipeline year-to-date, we still expect to achieve a lot more over the next 2.5 months as we close out the year. 
Assuming the successful completion of these pending leases, we are looking at a rollover schedule in New York City for 2017 and '18 that averages less than 900,000 square feet per annum or just about 3% of our portfolio square footage each year. That's the lowest rollover rate in recent history. That places our portfolio and this company in an unusually excellent offensive and defensive position by allowing us to focus our efforts on those future rollover spaces as and when they come up over the next 24 months and selectively make early deals with those tenants, the ones that allow us to drive the best economics possible. 
Notwithstanding our track record at keeping our portfolio well-leased throughout market cycles, we get the inevitable question: whether we can continue to outperform the market. And I believe the answer is absolutely an unequivocably yes. While office using job growth has slowed in the second half of the year, the information sector continues to add jobs while the losses in the financial sector have been quite modest through August, even though the prevailing view is much different and inaccurate, that being significant shedding of jobs in the financial sector. The numbers simply don't back that up, and that -- those are numbers that come right from OMD [ph].
September job numbers are not out yet, but there are a few interesting points to make about the health of the city economy up and through Q2, and part of these numbers are through September. Each of the big 5 banks have reported third quarter results, financial results, and pretax earnings were up 50% year-over-year. And revenues, which were flat for Q1 and Q2 for the big 5, were up 20% year-over-year in Q3. Add to that that total New York City jobs has reached another record level this year of 4.3 million workers, driven by private sector job growth through the second quarter of 77,000 new jobs, with third quarter numbers coming out imminently. Hotel occupancies are still as strong as last year, in the high 80s percent occupancy range, and only a slight decline in ADR, the average rate, even though there was a lot of new supply being absorbed this year as a result of construction that was taking place in years past. And Airbnb continues to be a competitive force, notwithstanding hotels having an excellent year, showing that tourism in the city is still very robust and has not missed a beat as a result of Brexit or otherwise. 
So while New York's economy and job growth metrics aren't on the same pace as last year's record levels, by the way, it's something that we had forecasted to you at the beginning of the year, it is still shaping up to be a relatively good year with above-average job growth, economic performance and  leasing activity, along with below-average sublet availability of well under 2%.
We also have a positive outlook for longer-term trends in tenant demand due to the expectation that New York City will continue to benefit from nation-leading population and job growth, extremely low interest rates by any historical standard and fairly limited new contributions to office inventory over the next 5 years as compared to the total 400 million square foot inventory of office properties that currently exist in all of Manhattan. 
Today, we gathered -- I'm sorry, Tuesday. It seems like today, but it was Tuesday. We gathered for a very proud moment in this company's history as we, along with Mayor de Blasio and many other elected officials, formally broke ground on the development for One Vanderbilt, a spectacular project that will transform the skyline and establish a new blueprint for the revitalization of East Midtown. This groundbreaking event followed on the heels of our announcement recently of the $1.5 billion construction loan closing, and that was led by 5 different domestic and international banks and carries with it an up to 7-year term, which is largely unprecedented in the construction loan market. And also, on top of that, we announced the withdrawal litigation and claims against the city and the project. So a lot accomplished in the -- since our last phone call in terms of clearing the decks for continued progress on the construction of One Vanderbilt, the financing. And along with that, we continue to be on budget and on track with that project. 
Andrew and I are extremely proud of our team for these great accomplishments, and we are excited to be part of this truly historic project. We understand that investor sentiment is mixed, but we look forward to fully educating everyone at our upcoming Investor Day that Matt just spoke about as to the incredible physical attributes of the building; the compelling economics of the project given our cost basis; and the transformative effect it will have in the surrounding area, in which the majority of our invested dollars reside. 
So with that, I'm sure there are people out there that have many questions on the quarter's results. And we would like to get right into it, and field [ph] the first one, operator.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't seen many declines. I mean, I would characterize rents generally as flat in the submarkets that we operate in, primarily Fifth Avenue, Times Square, SoHo and Upper Madison. We're still seeing tenant demand, but I would say tenants are slower to
componenttext: We haven't seen many declines. I mean, I would characterize rents generally as flat in the submarkets that we operate in, primarily Fifth Avenue, Times Square, SoHo and Upper Madison. We're still seeing tenant demand, but I would say tenants are slower to make decisions, which has led to some longer lead time in terms of leasing up vacant space. But there are still active tenants looking in the market, and we're in discussions on a lot of our vacancy in the portfolio now.

componenttext: Yes. I think we feel pretty good about being able to achieve our mark-to-market on the vacated Aropostale space. And that will ultimately come to pass as a positive event for the company. I think we feel highly confident.

componenttextpreview: Just, Marc, on One Vanderbilt, you guys have finished the construction loan, so yes, sort of going against the list, the checklist that you guys signed off. As you guys think about, especially in light of leasing activity that you have, as you think about
componenttext: Just, Marc, on One Vanderbilt, you guys have finished the construction loan, so yes, sort of going against the list, the checklist that you guys signed off. As you guys think about, especially in light of leasing activity that you have, as you think about next steps, whether it's JV or leasing -- you guys have paid off like almost $1 billion, I think, of incremental debt, so in a sense, you've shored up the balance sheet. Do you still feel like you need to JV it before you get substantially more leasing done? Or do you feel that if you get more leasing done, there's more value to be extracted when you do -- if you should bring in a JV partner?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a great question, Alex. I just want to clarify one thing. I don't think we felt or feel the need, I guess, [ph] the need to JV it. From day 1, I've always said we had absolute flexibility to build it out of cash flows. We go forward [ph] over th
componenttext: Yes, it's a great question, Alex. I just want to clarify one thing. I don't think we felt or feel the need, I guess, [ph] the need to JV it. From day 1, I've always said we had absolute flexibility to build it out of cash flows. We go forward [ph] over the next 4 years or bring in a JV partner. So the -- I would characterize it more as an intent and desire to bring in a JV partner, which is there simply because of the feel [ph] of the project and for the significant amount of yield enhancement we can create by bringing in a JV partner, obviously, at the right time given that our cost basis in the property is low and there's a lot of execution in terms of the development in [ph] leasing, for which there's a lot of fee income that's associated with that. So I think it's always been our goal from the outset to bring in a JV partner. I think the kind of schedule we had -- I had mentioned to investors at the beginning of the year was something along the lines of toward the end of this year to start to get to what we would consider more serious discussions with investors, knowing that we had to get a few milestones behind us in order to best position our presentation of this project to shareholders. And I think we've done that. I'd say we've done it as good or better than I even could have contemplated in terms of -- we have kind of best-in-class financing. The site, if you or others on the phone haven't seen it recently, it's really exciting and, I think, very impactful to walk over to 42nd and Vanderbilt just -- and get a sense of the scope of the project and the location of the project in its direct proximity to Grand Central and just how extraordinary it will be when that building is up in 4 years. The response from the tenant community so far has been nothing short of excellent in terms of having, I would say, checked every single box that we possibility could check in what you would want to do in delivering a best-in-class office building, with an understanding that tenants in the 50,000 to 250,000 square foot range typically are not making those kind of space commitments much more than 18 to 24 months ahead of time, which, given our schedule, would put the bulk of that leasing effort sometime towards the end of '17 and into '18, I think 2018 being the kind of the sweet spot of our marketing efforts. So with that said, we are in front of -- we're having discussions with a number of different potential JV partners. The good news is we're on a path, and I feel very comfortable that we'll be able to achieve our goals. But obviously, our goals are to make sure that the deal is properly structured with the kind of partner that shares our view and vision for long-term ownership and, on an economic basis, that's equitable and fair for both parties. So I think that we're doing -- we're on track there, and we'll just see how it goes.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But I mean, the point is, do you feel that it's better -- it's more prudent to JV it because it's a really large project? Or it sounds like you don't feel like you're giving up upside because once you have more leasing done, it would seem like a JV
componenttext: Okay. But I mean, the point is, do you feel that it's better -- it's more prudent to JV it because it's a really large project? Or it sounds like you don't feel like you're giving up upside because once you have more leasing done, it would seem like a JV partner would pay more for it. And you said, Marc, your spend now through next year really isn't that much given it's just dirt right now. It's not like you have a structure up.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Alex, I'm not speaking as to exact timing, so whether it's the beginning of the year, middle of the year, end of the year next year, I mean, I think you got to trust us to do the right thing by the asset. We -- I don't think -- we've done a lot o
componenttext: Yes. And Alex, I'm not speaking as to exact timing, so whether it's the beginning of the year, middle of the year, end of the year next year, I mean, I think you got to trust us to do the right thing by the asset. We -- I don't think -- we've done a lot of really successful joint ventures, successful for us, successful for our JV partners. I think we're very skilled at this in terms of, most importantly, selecting the right partner, having the right structure, sharing the right vision and then obviously, getting the right economic package for both parties. So I'm confident we will do a good job there. We don't feel pressure. We don't feel the need. There is a desire for the reasons that I mentioned. The timing, I think you got to leave to us to be the measure of when the right time to do it is. But we're not the kind of people that try to grab the last dollar. We don't warehouse space when we think rents are ticking up. It's a business. We've got a lot of other projects and investments to focus on beyond One Vanderbilt, so we don't want to let it consume us. It's as important and spectacular as it is. It's one investment, and this is a $20 billion-plus company. So we have a lot of other things we're focused on as well. And I think we'll take it in due course, and we'll time it for when it's optimal to do it. And I don't think we're going to ever look back. We never look back and say, oh, should've, could've. It'll be fine when we get it done.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just quickly, second question. Matt, you didn't mention guidance. Your beat onto The Street was pretty big in the third quarter. Is there anything offsetting in the fourth quarter that we should be thinking about that would affect the run rate?
componenttext: Okay. And just quickly, second question. Matt, you didn't mention guidance. Your beat onto The Street was pretty big in the third quarter. componenttext: To be at the upper end of our range implies a $1.39 fourth quarter, to be at the upper end of our either normalized or absolute guidance range. We are certainly trending at the high end of our range. Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, there aren't many anomalies like we've seen in the -- or nonrecurring items like we've seen in the third quarter, so it should be a pretty clean quarter. And we look at it within the range, at the upper end to maybe slightly ahead but not warranting to change the guidance.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Feldman with Bank of America.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess going back to One Vanderbilt, I mean, we have seen the higher end of the market, see some slowdown from hedge funds, financials under pressure. What are you guys monitoring as you think about -- you remain confident in the project, but what are yo
componenttext: I guess going back to One Vanderbilt, I mean, we have seen the higher end of the market, see some slowdown from hedge funds, financials under pressure. What are you guys monitoring as you think about -- you remain confident in the project, but what are you monitoring, what should The Street be monitoring as they think about your prospects to be successful there and hit your target rents?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's important to keep things in perspective as far as the timing goes. We don't deliver this building until -- for occupancy until 2020. So to measure the depth of the market by what's happening today in 2016 at the high end of the market I don't r
componenttext: Well, it's important to keep things in perspective as far as the timing goes. We don't deliver this building until -- for occupancy until 2020. So to measure the depth of the market by what's happening today in 2016 at the high end of the market I don't really think is necessarily the barometer that we [ph] should be focused on. I think that whether the market is robust or not, this is a unique product that offers a unique value proposition to those tenants that need the finest office product in the world. And we know that it's going to be received a warm welcome because the feedback that we get from tenants today as they evaluate the project really don't look at it on a dollars-per-square-foot basis. They look at it on the cost-per-seat basis. And what the building offers from an efficiency point of view, meaning the amount of -- the lesser amount of square footage per employee that the tenants can occupy in this building, offset because of the column-free floors, the amount of infrastructure that's already baked into the building, and the amount of amenity space that tenants house outside of their demised premises allow them to reduce their total occupancy cost per head. And I really think that as we get closer to the prime lease-up period, we're going to be converting those conversations that we're already having with prospective tenants over to leases. And just I think -- and we'll speak to it in greater detail at the Investor Conference, but the rents that we're targeting are not the high end of the -- not the highest end of the market, surprisingly enough. When you really normalize the rents for the majority of the office space in this building, you get into a -- one could argue is an affordable rent for those tenants who need the best product in the world.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Are you able to quantify the -- in terms of the conversations you're having, like how many square feet of interest there really is at this point?
componenttext: Okay. Are you able to quantify the -- in terms of the conversations you're having, like how many square feet of interest there really is at this point?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I have a presentation an hour after this call today for 0.5 million square foot. I had 2 presentations last week, and I'm probably running at a clip of 1 to 3 presentations almost every single week. The majority, you'll be interested to know, are fi
componenttext: Well, I have a presentation an hour after this call today for 0.5 million square foot. I had 2 presentations last week, and I'm probably running at a clip of 1 to 3 presentations almost every single week. The majority, you'll be interested to know, are financial-related businesses, and most of them are in the 100,000 to 200,000 square foot range, some as small as 30,000 to 60,000 square feet. And I point that out because when you're in that size range, as Marc mentioned earlier, we're early to the game for those type of tenants to really pull the trigger on a decision. They have to be -- they're educating themselves with the opportunity. They're preparing themselves to make a decision, but they need it closer to the finish line for delivery before they actually pull the trigger.

componenttext: First, Steve, how many tenants, when it's all said and done, do you think you could actually just pull from existing SL Green building, existing SL Green tenants, that's one? And then second, are you thinking about this joint venture to appease the shareholders, or it's the right real estate thing to do? Said another way, if doing a joint venture was not going to help your stock price, repeat, not going to help your stock price, would you actually do it?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So I'll take the first one and Marc will respond to the second one. We have shared the One Vanderbilt presentation with a couple of tenants within our portfolio and they're good candidates for the building. It's an interesting conversation beca
componenttext: All right. So I'll take the first one and Marc will respond to the second one. We have shared the One Vanderbilt presentation with a couple of tenants within our portfolio and they're good candidates for the building. It's an interesting conversation because some of those discussions with those tenants, we point out to them, assuming that they're retro tenants, we point out to them that where their anticipated escalated rent will be upon exploration of their current leases in our portfolio, which we just keep them knowledgeably about that is that it puts them within $5 to $10 of what our pro forma rent is for One Vanderbilt. And then when we further point out to them the ability for them to lease less square footage because of the relative attributes of the building that I spoke about earlier, that in reality, it would translate into an occupancy savings for those tenants. So we're having those conversations, we've targeted some of those tenants, and we're out there actively getting in front of them.
