headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was going to move to stock price, okay interesting. The answer is you have to just trust and believe in what we say. We're not JV-ing it to get a few bucks of stock price, that would be criminal. You know what I'm saying? It would be outlandish to do s
componenttext: It was going to move to stock price, okay interesting. The answer is you have to just trust and believe in what we say. We're not JV-ing it to get a few bucks of stock price, that would be criminal. You know what I'm saying? It would be outlandish to do something like that for the sole purpose of thinking the stock will be [indiscernible] portfolio. By the way, it's almost like everything we've heard for the past 18 months about do this, stock price will do that, has been completely wrong. [indiscernible] I think the under on that, we're doing it for the same fundamental and sound reason we would typically JV any large project for some diversification of investment opportunity. I mean, we have other uses for the capital. And if properly structured, economically, while we won't maximize aggregate profit, we should maximize aggregate return. And that's what we have always been about. That's how we've been able to drive 7.7% growth in FFO from the date -- compounded growth of FFO from the day of our IPO back in 1997. It's how we've been able to drive outsized investment past [ph] total return to shareholders and it's really how we do our business, is by balancing aggregate gain, which would drive you to retain everything, versus maximizing return on capital which leads you to do a JV. Maybe it's a partial JV, maybe it's not half, maybe it's 40% like we did with Pru in 11 Madison, maybe it's 35% or 30% or 25%, you estimate and then you don't give up much in the way of governance. But there is something between 30% and 50% where we can structure, I think, a very appropriate joint venture, introduce this product to the domestic and more weighted international community who loves to own best project, best market, best location. When you can check those 3 boxes, it's unusually you can check those 3 boxes, but when you can, there's deep demand for that product. I think it's warranted that we and prudent that we do that for diversification for return maximization. And I think that is a good course. We don't give up much by doing it. We will always own the majority of the project, whether it's 51% or more. It will have SL Green's brand on the building, and it's something that we're all going to be very, very proud of, no matter what -- anyone who have reservations at this project now is going to be standing at that ribbon-cutting in 2020, and is going to feel like a champion when we open the doors to a least successful #1 building in New York City. And we're be able to stand up and say, which many others can't, we did it profitably, on-time, on-budget.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a little more straightforward in general, though. On the balance sheet side of things, you guys have been a net seller over the last 2 quarters and the leverage -- the level continuing to come down. Trying to figure out what the debt-to-EBITDA is ri
componenttext: Maybe a little more straightforward in general, though. On the balance sheet side of things, you guys have been a net seller over the last 2 quarters and the leverage -- the level continuing to come down. Trying to figure out what the debt-to-EBITDA is right now, but probably somewhere maybe high 7 [ph] in the 8 [ph] I'm just kind of curious in the leverage metrics. Have you guys got where you want to be, and maybe - I know you probably talked about this in the Investor Day, but kind of give us a sneak peek on what you're thinking about in terms of leverage going into next year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on a consolidated basis, our debt-to-EBITDA is 6.5x and on a combined basis, that's all in. It's about a turn higher than that. It's about a full turn on both metrics lower than we had originally projected to be at for the year, so we were certain
componenttext: Yes. So on a consolidated basis, our debt-to-EBITDA is 6.5x and on a combined basis, that's all in. It's about a turn higher than that. It's about a full turn on both metrics lower than we had originally projected to be at for the year, so we were certainly comfortably in it 7.5x and now we're at 6.5x. So we're right in the area we'd like to be with $2 billion of liquidity, our target is 1. We have a very comfortable liquidity position. So I think we're exactly where we wanted to be and slightly ahead. It gives us a lot of flexibility on the balance sheet.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I know as much as we try to orient the thinking on this particular topic to debt to value as opposed to debt-to-EBITDA, because not all EBITDA is created the same and I think it's a distorted metric to be used when applied towards all sorts of de
componenttext: Yes. And I know as much as we try to orient the thinking on this particular topic to debt to value as opposed to debt-to-EBITDA, because not all EBITDA is created the same and I think it's a distorted metric to be used when applied towards all sorts of desperate companies. Putting that aside, if you look at debt to value for those few people out there that's still look at the traditional, that definition of the leverage ratio, we are right about 35% debt to value, which I think by any measure in New York City, maybe internationally, but certainly in Manhattan, is considered to be at a very low level. So I still look at 1 out of every 10 reports, uses the words above average leverage, not exactly sure what that means. But the reality is, our leverage level, based on our assets and the equity support we have on those assets, something much closer to 35%, which -- we have to compete against people who are 50%, 60%, 70% debt to value routinely, and we do it, we do it because I like to think we have the best of class investment teams here and we're able to do it. But it's obviously not as easy to achieve the kind of growth that we do achieve using a more expensive capital than our competitors. So we just have to be that much better on the volume, that much better on the execution to make up for it, and we have but looking at it from that standpoint, not just at the EBITDA, that's where our levels reside right about now.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Manny [indiscernible] with Citi.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marc, I appreciate your commentary earlier about sort of the oncoming supply. Given the fact that that supply is newer product, the fact that there are incentives that make it economically beneficial to the tenants. Why wouldn't it be a bigger factor to t
componenttext: Marc, I appreciate your commentary earlier about sort of the oncoming supply. Given the fact that that supply is newer product, the fact that there are incentives that make it economically beneficial to the tenants. Why wouldn't it be a bigger factor to the sort of you realizing rental rate growth and you're realizing the leasing in your new projects?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's 2 reasons. I'm going to give you a bit of a curveball here. The addition to supply of new inventory in Manhattan is a good thing, whether -- I don't know how it's gotten characterized in this kind of awful thing. He didn't hear that
componenttext: Well, I think there's 2 reasons. I'm going to give you a bit of a curveball here. The addition to supply of new inventory in Manhattan is a good thing, whether -- I don't know how it's gotten characterized in this kind of awful thing. He didn't hear that from us, I mean that's for sure because because what that addition is a representation of a great market, because only great market can create the demand to warrant the construction of new projects and do it in a way for the vacancy levels are unchanged and they're still roughly right around 9.5%, 10%, which is where they've been for several years now and do it in a way where there's very little sublet space. And I think it's about [ph] 1.5% [ph], so historical lows, and do it in a way that's very measured. So it's not all coming on in 1 year. So when you look at the inventories we've done in-depth and we'll do again in December when we meet with a lot of you folks on the phone, I won't take you through the math now, but you basically winds your way down to sort of at most, I'll say, about 2.5 million to 2.75 million square feet per year. And when you calculate the start of the breakeven job growth to absorb that incremental square footage, it's only about 10,000 office using jobs a year. And over the past 5 years, at least the city has done 2x or 3x that. The issue is not the inventory to me, it's job growth. And we have office using job growth, then we're going to have a drop in the vacancy level, even with about a 1 -- I guess that works out to be -- no, not even to 75 basis point per year addition to inventories. We have 400 million square feet in Manhattan. And as I said earlier, we'll be adding about 2.5 million, 2.75 million square feet a year. And that's if most everything goes, not everything necessarily will go, but if everything goes. And that's a healthy market. And as evidence of that, in 2015 and '16, we competed against that and yet, we had 2 of our best years on record, last year and this year. Those are not aberrations, that's just a reflection of a market that can withstand this sort of incremental and pretty modest increase in inventory over the next few years. It's not going to be more than that, I would challenge anyone to show us the -- a calculation where it's more than about 75 [ph] basis points a year of increase. And as long as we have the job growth to offset or exceed that, we're in great shape. And even if the jobs fall below that any 1 or 2 given years, I think the effect on the vacancy rate will be de minimis. And we seem to be able to outperform within the market anyway, so even -- I think we're always going to get more than our fair share of leases. If anything, I see over the next 2 years, the issue for us is we're not going to have that much space to lease. So to kind of worry about what the effect of this incremental space delivery is going to be, a lot, much of which has been spoken for already, and represents growth out of the space that's being moved out of. And we factor that into our analysis. We don't have a lot of space so we're going to focus in hard on that space, try to get it done ahead of time, the best economics possible. If we can renew it, we're going tenant and I have no real concern that we won't be able to maintain a very high vacancy rate or a very high occupancy rate, low vacancy rate. Right now, we're 97.5% leased. I mean, that's -- I don't know if there's another company in New York that's 97.5% leased, same-store and maybe by year end [ph] it will be higher than that. So it's mostly -- we're very positive in the, what I would call the modest additions coming to market and the fact that those additions are largely almost exclusively far west side and downtown, which no matter what, are going to compete at a rental price point that is less than core midtown. And that's not in any way to disparage those markets, those were important markets for companies that want to be there and want to sacrifice certain of the amenities and locational attributes of being a midtown just -- for a lower rent price point, that's fine, but for every one that does, there's many that don't. And that's why we leased 250 leases a year in Midtown is because those 250 tenants don't want to be far from the downtown, but there are some that do, and there's room for both so I don't see an issue.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: A quick one in operations and maybe this one is for Matt. NOI margin, or NOI revenues fell this quarter, same-store NOI kind of retrenched. If you said ti early in the call, I didn't hear you. Was there any kind of onetime impact or things we should be thinking about that impact in the quarter that either repeats or doesn't repeat going forward, Matt?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, the big thing that happened in the quarter that was nonrecurring was Aro, where we not the only lost about $2 million in rent, like actual cash rent, but we had a $70 [ph] million write-off of old straight line and [indiscernible] balances, that g
componenttext: Sure, the big thing that happened in the quarter that was nonrecurring was Aro, where we not the only lost about $2 million in rent, like actual cash rent, but we had a $70 [ph] million write-off of old straight line and [indiscernible] balances, that goes right through rental revenues on the income statement. That $2 million cash rent loss also flows through same-store, so you have 2 factors in our same-store for this quarter, which obviously close to the year and will flow through the balance of the year, sales reflects the fourth quarter. The loss rent from Aero was about $2 million. We also gave free rent to Omnicom over at 220 42nd Street as part of their recent renewal. That was about $1.2 million in the quarter and will be a slightly larger number in the fourth quarter. So we kept our 6% same-store NOI target for the year, which is sector-leading by a lot. We would be at 6.6% to the 9 months, were not for those couple of those anomalies. We will work hard to maintain the 6%, 6% in spite of those couple of things for the full year. But that's what you saw in rental revenues and same-store.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Second question, maybe 2 parts to it. One, just tell us more additional asset sales and kind of your core midtown market assets that maybe you've stabilized, fairly a little concerned by getting ahead of some of the leased expiration? Are there mor
componenttext: Great. Second question, maybe 2 parts to it. One, just tell us more additional asset sales and kind of your core midtown market assets that maybe you've stabilized, fairly a little concerned by getting ahead of some of the leased expiration? Are there more assets you can sell despite the fact that you're ahead of your own leverage target. And if I got a b question in there, I'd say, can you talk about the 11 Madison kind of repurchase that you had to go through and what's the likelihood of that?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Repurchase. So I'll address the 11 Madison Park. That was -- the modification going forward is customary, so there is a very, very nominal chance you have to buy that back, miniscule is probably a better word. What we had there was a closing that happened
componenttext: Repurchase. So I'll address the 11 Madison Park. That was -- the modification going forward is customary, so there is a very, very nominal chance you have to buy that back, miniscule is probably a better word. What we had there was a closing that happened kind of in reverse order to traditional closing, where normally you get that modification between contract signing and closing. We did a simultaneous and then left a little tail until you get that modification done. That will get done here in the next few weeks and alleviate the buyback.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just more assets?
componenttext: And just more assets?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of more asset sales, we're always evaluating asset sales, I would say, getting 11 Madison done and getting the Blackrock recapitalization done at 57th Street. That we've satisfied our targets in terms of generating liquidity and the liquidity pos
componenttext: In terms of more asset sales, we're always evaluating asset sales, I would say, getting 11 Madison done and getting the Blackrock recapitalization done at 57th Street. That we've satisfied our targets in terms of generating liquidity and the liquidity position that we set in. However, it's a great market to be a seller of assets. There's still an enormous amount of demand for prime real estate assets and we're always sort of evaluating the next sale. So I wouldn't be surprised to see us explore the market for more asset sales, but none that we're going to identify to that.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jed Reagan [ph] of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jed Reagan [ph] of Green Street Advisors.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: What are you seeing in terms of rent growth trends in Manhattan today? Is it fair to characterize the market as flattening out in your view? Or are you seeing any changes in the concession environment?
componenttext: What are you seeing in terms of rent growth trends in Manhattan today? Is it fair to characterize the market as flattening out in your view? Or are you seeing any changes in the concession environment?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The rents have been pretty much as we anticipated this year. They've been on the low sides of that 3% to 5% range. It depends on where you are -- which submarket you're talking about, which part of the marketplace, it's the high end or low end of the mark
componenttext: The rents have been pretty much as we anticipated this year. They've been on the low sides of that 3% to 5% range. It depends on where you are -- which submarket you're talking about, which part of the marketplace, it's the high end or low end of the market. Clearly, there's more velocity in the more commodity price point portion of the market, so call it the $50 to $80 price point as compared to the above $100 price points and particularly, above $130. But there has been rent growth. We've seen rent growth in certain of our assets and clearly, you get a sense of that from the mark-to-market that we're posting. So but on the concession side, at the high price point end of the market, the concessions clearly have stepped up on the capital side, not on the free rent side because you've seen a few landlords rather than adjusting kind of rents for very expensive space, simply sort of offset it with more capital to stay competitive. But I think that's a thin part of the market as opposed to the overall marketplace. Our confessions on average have been pretty consistent throughout the year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And there's been some chancery [ph] that maybe you've been looking at investment in IRT [ph]. Would you say those rumors are off the mark?
componenttext: Okay. And there's been some chancery [ph] that maybe you've been looking at investment in IRT [ph]. Would you say those rumors are off the mark?

componenttext: I'm not going to -- don't even ask. I mean for you to bring it up is absurd, I mean really absurd. Not going down this rabbit hole the second time with you guys. Next question.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to ask about a little bit on the street retail. 650 Fifth is something you guys have owned for a while. And I know the last retailer, it seems like closed in the basement. I'm just wondering if you could sort just talk about that project
componenttext: I guess I wanted to ask about a little bit on the street retail. 650 Fifth is something you guys have owned for a while. And I know the last retailer, it seems like closed in the basement. I'm just wondering if you could sort just talk about that project and just in particular, I guess following up, what other investment opportunities do you think might unfold? And do you think you're a net seller or a buyer in that business over the next 12 months?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, on 650 Fifth, we are working hard. I mean, it's been a focus of ours. We've had -- seems to be a little slick on that project with a couple of deals we got -- we thought spinning distance of getting it on to the finish line and then fell apart. But
componenttext: Steve, on 650 Fifth, we are working hard. I mean, it's been a focus of ours. We've had -- seems to be a little slick on that project with a couple of deals we got -- we thought spinning distance of getting it on to the finish line and then fell apart. But we're  -- we continue to work hard on that project and we have a couple of interesting prospects for the space, so continue to be optimistic. We'll have something to announce there, hopefully, in the near future. In terms of the street retail business and I think the pricing and the market for these assets has definitely moved us a bit to the sidelines. You haven't seen us as active in retail as we have in the past, and that's a -- that's unfortunate in terms of our acquisition volumes, but very encouraging in terms of the value of the assets that we own. When you've seen assets like 693 Fifth, and many, many other assets trade at really core stabilized type values with enormous valuation, we feel boldened about the inventory that we own, just difficult for us to really buy much value-add out there given the investment landscape now.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess, could you talk a little bit about the debt and preferred book? You guys were pretty active in the quarter. What is your expectation kind of in the fourth quarter, and how do you see that sort of trending over the next couple of yea
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess, could you talk a little bit about the debt and preferred book? You guys were pretty active in the quarter. What is your expectation kind of in the fourth quarter, and how do you see that sort of trending over the next couple of years?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think with the fourth quarter, we're on track for our stated guidance of about another $150 million which should put us whether on $2 billion for year end of balances. It's a good time in the market for the business. The CMBS market has come back but th
componenttext: I think with the fourth quarter, we're on track for our stated guidance of about another $150 million which should put us whether on $2 billion for year end of balances. It's a good time in the market for the business. The CMBS market has come back but there's still a lot of uncertainty regarding risk retention. And that's moved quite a number of originators a bit to the sidelines. So it's pushing nontraditional capital to the forefront in terms of getting financings done. And we feel very good about the opportunities that we're finding and the debt we're originating now. So we've also been active syndicators which we have been in years past and are on track this year to be another active syndicator, sort of verifying the liquidity and the positions that we own, and we'd expect that to continue as well through the fourth quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Related to that last question. Matt, correct me if I'm wrong, but I think the $41 million of additional income from the recap of your debt investment was included in the investment income line, which would make the residual investment income a little over, and say $34 million, which is a pretty substantial drop from the first 2 quarters. So is that right? And if so, was there anything else onetime in nature going on?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. So the -- you're correct, the $41 million of incremental was in investment income. The balance or the income from the balances moves each quarter based on investments that are in there and the average balance. We did originate a bunch this quarter, bu
componenttext: No. So the -- you're correct, the $41 million of incremental was in investment income. The balance or the income from the balances moves each quarter based on investments that are in there and the average balance. We did originate a bunch this quarter, but I think on average, the balance was lower this quarter, and we had some pretty juicy investments pay off earlier in the year, like 550 Madison and 645 West 42nd. So we're on track for our full year targeted income in the third quarter, borrowing that 1 $41 [ph] million item that you noted was below but we are on track for the balances of net income for the year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then, Steve, if I'm hearing you right from their earlier commentary with respect to some of the questions that were asked. It seems as though the higher price point segment of the market continues to be tough currently. But do you t
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then, Steve, if I'm hearing you right from their earlier commentary with respect to some of the questions that were asked. It seems as though the higher price point segment of the market continues to be tough currently. But do you think it can get better by the time kind of you guys aren't delivering. So I guess is that right? And what do you think it is that my drive improvement and amend in that segment?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, let's put it in perspective. If your view is the high-end market is well into the triple-digit rent, there will be still a considerable number of leases signed this year. And at that price point, in fact, there will be more square footage lea
componenttext: Well, again, let's put it in perspective. If your view is the high-end market is well into the triple-digit rent, there will be still a considerable number of leases signed this year. And at that price point, in fact, there will be more square footage least this year at $100 plus rent than there was all of last year. So there were a fewer deals but what's interesting is the size of the deals is growing in that sector of the marketplace. And I think it's misleading to evaluate where our marketplace will be 4 years from now based upon where it's been over the past few quarters. So that -- I take a lot of our faith, or a lot of our confidence in our rents 4 years out based upon the tenant feedback that we get, as to them recognizing the quality of the asset.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nick Yulico of UBS.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Turning to the 28% all over that mark-to-market you've done year-to-date on new leases signed. How much of that will actually commence this year versus benefiting you next year?

componenttextpreview: I would say from a renewal perspective, obviously those will kick in immediately, certainly from a GAAP perspective. The new leasing, which is -- or things like [indiscernible] or the Tower 46 leases, those have 9- to 12-month of lead time on them. I don'
componenttext: I would say from a renewal perspective, obviously those will kick in immediately, certainly from a GAAP perspective. The new leasing, which is -- or things like [indiscernible] or the Tower 46 leases, those have 9- to 12-month of lead time on them. I don't have the numbers in my fingertips in terms of exactly how much the 3 million square feet we've done now will be next year. Later this year or next year, I'd say the majority, given where we are in the year that's been signed in the last couple of months is more impactful to the next year and certainly new leasing is a next year impacting item.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess you could go to some of this in the Investor Day. But yes, for use like say, your lease expiration schedule on Page 48 of the supplemental, it looks like your leases in place today are call it, a little over 10% below where market asking
componenttext: Okay. And I guess you could go to some of this in the Investor Day. But yes, for use like say, your lease expiration schedule on Page 48 of the supplemental, it looks like your leases in place today are call it, a little over 10% below where market asking rents are. So as we think about 28% on this year versus this page which says, averages out it will over 10%. How do we think about that sort of change in the mark-to-market and how it might affect, yes, you're saying your growth opportunities over the next couple of years?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll say it's accurate that we will into this in more detail in December, the lead off. But I would also say if you look back at where we thought our mark-to-market would be 1 year ago and what we did this year, it was not 28% either. So Steve has done a
componenttext: I'll say it's accurate that we will into this in more detail in December, the lead off. But I would also say if you look back at where we thought our mark-to-market would be 1 year ago and what we did this year, it was not 28% either. So Steve has done a very good job and now performing his own and our expectations. And we'll get into more detail on expectations for next year in about 6 weeks.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. Just one last one quickly. On the banks, I know everybody talks about -- the banks maybe not being as impactful as they were in the last cycle, banks have trimmed down space, maybe they don't shed some more space in the market. But I guess on
componenttext: Fair enough. Just one last one quickly. On the banks, I know everybody talks about -- the banks maybe not being as impactful as they were in the last cycle, banks have trimmed down space, maybe they don't shed some more space in the market. But I guess one of the things I'm wondering is maybe Steve or someone else, could have comment on is there is still some nonheadquarters bank space in the market that perhaps, banks won't need all of that in the next 5 years, as banks fix -- face some new capital rules that haven't even began yet. How should we think about that risk of this potential access space for banks in the market?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, I don't think we can do that on this call. That's a -- to forecast what we think is the near or midterm demand for banks and the impacts for it, we can take your question as duly noted and focus in on that in about a month and half. But we can't ans
componenttext: Nick, I don't think we can do that on this call. That's a -- to forecast what we think is the near or midterm demand for banks and the impacts for it, we can take your question as duly noted and focus in on that in about a month and half. But we can't answer that in 60 seconds. And the -- I just want to leave it with -- I don't think it's a foregone conclusion that banks are going to do poorly over the next few years or do great in the next few years. I mean we sort of take it as we see the numbers come in in terms of profitability and job growth. The banks right now are reasonably healthy. A lot of the leasing in the first half of the year was financial services driven, not just the big 5, but the financial sector, whether that will be in the case in the second half or not, we'll see. But we're not seeing, I think what you heard earlier, as any major reductions in bank space demand or putting on the space or sublet space, or anything that would raise sort of cautionary flags for us on the banks. It's a good trend that what used to be 40% of the market now is closer to 30% or 35% of the market, it's 1/3 of the market. And maybe in 3 to 5 years, will be 30% of the market because you have health care growing, education growing, the government sector is growing, information is growing, technology is growing, business services, the biggest grower. It's a dynamic market, that's the beauty of New York City, dynamic. And you have so many calls, there's so many claims on a limited amount of building inventory that it's just not easy for most tenants to lease space. And when they can, they're relatively quick to do so and we'll see -- we will forecast how we see banks playing into that mix in December. But it's a complicated question, not that we do a justice on this call, but it's duly noted.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Mailman with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Mailman with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly, I think you noted that you guys have ticked off a lot of boxes over what, I Tinkers investors have thought would move the stock, but you're still trading at a mid to high 20% of discount to NAV. You guys put in the $1 billion share repurchas
componenttext: Just quickly, I think you noted that you guys have ticked off a lot of boxes over what, I Tinkers investors have thought would move the stock, but you're still trading at a mid to high 20% of discount to NAV. You guys put in the $1 billion share repurchase plan not too long ago. Just curious your thoughts on executing a part of that, kind of how you view returns on buying back stock versus investing elsewhere and kind of how you manage leverage potentially?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first things, let's handle that in December, too. But it's a fair question.  We put that program in place because it would be imprudent not to, so we wanted to put something in place and make it meaningful so that we have a tool available to us if we s
componenttext: My first things, let's handle that in December, too. But it's a fair question.  We put that program in place because it would be imprudent not to, so we wanted to put something in place and make it meaningful so that we have a tool available to us if we see things happening within the stock that we feel are so violently dislocated that we view it as an opportunity that exceeds all other opportunities available to us at that time. So one, it could be viewed as therefore, moments in time. And then there's a second view which could be, if there continues to be sort of this systematic dislocation between private sector valuations which continue to be fairly robust and public market valuations, which I would say in general, are below that and for stocks like us, seem to be far below that, then I think you have to start looking at systematically dealing, how you approach that problem with stock buyback being one of the tools that could be used along with asset sales and dividends and special dividends and everything else. So it certainly isn't exclusive, but it's certainly something we are becoming increasingly focused on as we see a year like this year, where there's going to be $40 billion of sales probably by end of year, all of which are executed at cap rates and per square footage prices, pretty much right on top of last year's record, $60 billion or $65 billion of sales. And while the volumes have decreased, the pricing for the well located redeveloped, low positioned assets really haven't decreased, and we could see scenarios where in 2017, that demand may increase because on a relative basis, the kinds of returns those assets produce, which are anywhere between 5.5%, 6% unlevered and that might translate to 7% to 8% levered. Those are by and large, considered to be excellent core returns for great properties which justify the pricing levels which are so dramatically ahead of what the implied pricing levels are in the public securities. So I would say if they're at a prudent, if they are opportunistic and maybe, they're systematically, if this diversion doesn't seem to correct itself at some point in time, but for now, we have not executed on it at this point. And it's -- if not, I would say the current focus of us at the moment, because we have all these other what I consider, the excellent opportunities that we are taking advantage of both on One Vanderbilt, other equity investments, in leasing, in redeveloping and structure finance. We're having a robust year, but it is there and it's something that I think we are going to pay a lot of attention.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of Brad Burke of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of Brad Burke of Goldman Sachs.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to ask 1 question. Marc, bigger picture question, a follow-up on your point about in New York not meeting much growth to offset the 75 basis points of sort of annual supply growth. I mean the office job growth in New York has been pretty ro
componenttext: I'm just going to ask 1 question. Marc, bigger picture question, a follow-up on your point about in New York not meeting much growth to offset the 75 basis points of sort of annual supply growth. I mean the office job growth in New York has been pretty robust over the last 5 years and it doesn't seem to translate into meaningful improvement in midtown availability rates. So if we're now looking at what looks like decelerating job growth, why wouldn't that translate into higher availability rates going forward?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- if you look, I don't know what period of time you're looking at, Brad. But if you look at, we can do this in December, I hope [indiscernible] we've got a lot of stuff in December. If you look at, I'll call it, the trough of the market
componenttext: Well, I think the -- if you look, I don't know what period of time you're looking at, Brad. But if you look at, we can do this in December, I hope [indiscernible] we've got a lot of stuff in December. If you look at, I'll call it, the trough of the market to where we are today, I think the availability rate is about 400 basis points and that's what the job growth. So it's the best I can tell, because a lot of the. . .

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible]
componenttext: [indiscernible]

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our occupancy is up about 400 basis points, and I think availability has gone down from about 13.5 [ph] and [indiscernible] so that's a lot of space, 400 basis points or 400 million square feet. And since a lot of inventories future inventory, all o
componenttext:
Well, our occupancy is up about 400 basis points, and I think availability has gone down from about 13.5 [ph] and [indiscernible] so that's a lot of space, 400 basis points or 400 million square feet. And since a lot of inventories future inventory, all of that absorption, if you will, in reduction I think is -- have to think it through but it seems like predominantly, it's not exclusive to the job growth. I think it has been there. The only reason you haven't seen it, take a whole other ratchet down in 2016 is because the office, while private sector job growth is almost 80,000 jobs this year, which may put it on pace for 100 in total, by end of the year which would make it one of those rare record or near record years. The office using a lag behind that, we may only get this year, I'm speculating, about 10,000 plus jobs, which would be, let's call it half of prior year. But as I mentioned earlier, the big 5 numbers are up and even though you can't bench everything off of that, looking more broadly at Wall Street firms, broadly defined, their profits for the year were estimated to be by the city [ph] $10 billion. In fact, through the first half of the year, there were $9 billion. And the city, we will be revising the estimates for the full year, and it's going to be well in excess of $10 billion.  So it's not to say by a long stretch that office using job growth for the balance of this year into next year couldn't pivot and be higher. But in anyway, to answer your specific question as to whether it's been translated or not, we'll do a little study for December, but I think you have seen the correlation between job growth and reduction availability, which has been fairly programmatic through '15, and has leveled off a bit in '16. 
All right, everyone, thank you for the call. We're right at 3 '05, so right on time. We are looking forward, as we always do, to a great Investor Day in the newly revamped site looking through in the beginning. And the next time we have an opportunity to speak to everyone, so until then. We will keep working hard. Thank you very much.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp. Third Quarter 2016 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, managem
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp. Third Quarter 2016 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Also, during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's third quarter 2016 earnings. 
Before turning the call over to Matt DiLiberto, Chief Financial Officer of SL Green Realty Corp., I ask that those of you participating in the Q&A portion of the call please limit your questions to 2 per person. Thank you. 
I will now turn the call over to Matt DiLiberto. Please go ahead, Matt.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone. Before I turn the call over to Marc, I just wanted to take the opportunity to remind everybody of our Annual Investor Conference being held on Monday, December 5, here in New York City at Jazz at Lincoln Cent
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone. Before I turn the call over to Marc, I just wanted to take the opportunity to remind everybody of our Annual Investor Conference being held on Monday, December 5, here in New York City at Jazz at Lincoln Center. For more information, you can email slg2016@slgreen.com. The invitations should be going out in the next couple of weeks. The format has changed slightly this year. We will be beginning at 9 a.m. on Monday, December 5. The door is opening at 8:30 a.m. for a light breakfast, and we would expect to be completed by 1 in the afternoon. So again, for more information, please email slg2016@slgreen.com. 
With that, I will turn it over to our CEO, Marc Holliday.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Matt, and thank you for dialing into the call today. We are happy to have the opportunity to review with you the results of the third quarter and provide some additional commentary on how we see things shaping up in New York City. Conti
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Matt, and thank you for dialing into the call today. We are happy to have the opportunity to review with you the results of the third quarter and provide some additional commentary on how we see things shaping up in New York City. 
Continuing a trend this year where we have outperformed many of our 2016 operating and financial goals, we had a very strong third quarter, punctuated by 1.3 million square feet of Manhattan office leases signed at a market-leading 29% mark-to-market. Once again, SL Green has demonstrated its ability to outperform on the leasing and operational front, notwithstanding any perceived or actual slowdown in the tenant market. In fact, in the first 20 days of October, we concluded 9 additional Manhattan office leases for a total of 212,000 square feet, highlighted by the 2 leases we announced this morning with Comcast and Nixon Peabody at Tower 46, and we welcome those 2 tenants to our portfolio. This brings our total Manhattan leasing production to 3 million square feet. Year-to-date, that's 50% more than we originally forecast and a 28% mark-to-market on replacement leases, which is about double what we originally projected at the beginning of the year. These accomplishments are not just market-leading. They are extraordinary by any measure and will rank among the 2 or 3 best leasing years in our 19-year history as a public company, all the more notable because we achieved these results notwithstanding additional supply from Hudson Yards, making the point that high-quality, well-located and reasonably priced office space is still in very high demand. As further evidence of that tenant demand, we have a current leasing pipeline of nearly 600,000 square feet, approximately half of which are leases pending and out for signature. So I think that shows that notwithstanding we have cleared out a substantial amount of pipeline year-to-date, we still expect to achieve a lot more over the next 2.5 months as we close out the year. 
Assuming the successful completion of these pending leases, we are looking at a rollover schedule in New York City for 2017 and '18 that averages less than 900,000 square feet per annum or just about 3% of our portfolio square footage each year. That's the lowest rollover rate in recent history. That places our portfolio and this company in an unusually excellent offensive and defensive position by allowing us to focus our efforts on those future rollover spaces as and when they come up over the next 24 months and selectively make early deals with those tenants, the ones that allow us to drive the best economics possible. 
Notwithstanding our track record at keeping our portfolio well-leased throughout market cycles, we get the inevitable question: whether we can continue to outperform the market. And I believe the answer is absolutely an unequivocably yes. While office using job growth has slowed in the second half of the year, the information sector continues to add jobs while the losses in the financial sector have been quite modest through August, even though the prevailing view is much different and inaccurate, that being significant shedding of jobs in the financial sector. The numbers simply don't back that up, and that -- those are numbers that come right from OMB.
September job numbers are not out yet, but there are a few interesting points to make about the health of the city economy up and through Q2, and part of these numbers are through September. Each of the big 5 banks have reported third quarter results, financial results, and pretax earnings were up 50% year-over-year. And revenues, which were flat for Q1 and Q2 for the big 5, were up 20% year-over-year in Q3. Add to that that total New York City jobs has reached another record level this year of 4.3 million workers, driven by private sector job growth through the second quarter of 77,000 new jobs, with third quarter numbers coming out imminently. Hotel occupancies are still as strong as last year, in the high 80s percent occupancy range, and only a slight decline in ADR, the average rate, even though there was a lot of new supply being absorbed this year as a result of construction that was taking place in years past. And Airbnb continues to be a competitive force, notwithstanding hotels having an excellent year, showing that tourism in the city is still very robust and has not missed a beat as a result of Brexit or otherwise. 
So while New York's economy and job growth metrics aren't on the same pace as last year's record levels, by the way, it's something that we had forecasted to you at the beginning of the year, it is still shaping up to be a relatively good year with above-average job growth, economic performance and  leasing activity, along with below-average sublet availability of well under 2%.
We also have a positive outlook for longer-term trends in tenant demand due to the expectation that New York City will continue to benefit from nation-leading population and job growth, extremely low interest rates by any historical standard and fairly limited new contributions to office inventory over the next 5 years as compared to the total 400 million square foot inventory of office properties that currently exist in all of Manhattan. 
Today, we gathered -- I'm sorry, Tuesday. It seems like today, but it was Tuesday. We gathered for a very proud moment in this company's history as we, along with Mayor de Blasio and many other elected officials, formally broke ground on the development for One Vanderbilt, a spectacular project that will transform the skyline and establish a new blueprint for the revitalization of East Midtown. This groundbreaking event followed on the heels of our announcement recently of the $1.5 billion construction loan closing, and that was led by 5 different domestic and international banks and carries with it an up to 7-year term, which is largely unprecedented in the construction loan market. And also, on top of that, we announced the withdrawal litigation and claims against the city and the project. So a lot accomplished in the -- since our last phone call in terms of clearing the decks for continued progress on the construction of One Vanderbilt, the financing. And along with that, we continue to be on budget and on track with that project. 
Andrew and I are extremely proud of our team for these great accomplishments, and we are excited to be part of this truly historic project. We understand that investor sentiment is mixed, but we look forward to fully educating everyone at our upcoming Investor Day that Matt just spoke about as to the incredible physical attributes of the building; the compelling economics of the project given our cost basis; and the transformative effect it will have in the surrounding area, in which the majority of our invested dollars reside. 
So with that, I'm sure there are people out there that have many questions on the quarter's results. And we would like to get right into it, and field the first one, operator.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't seen many declines. I mean, I would characterize rents generally as flat in the submarkets that we operate in, primarily Fifth Avenue, Times Square, SoHo and Upper Madison. We're still seeing tenant demand, but I would say tenants are slower to
componenttext: We haven't seen many declines. I mean, I would characterize rents generally as flat in the submarkets that we operate in, primarily Fifth Avenue, Times Square, SoHo and Upper Madison. We're still seeing tenant demand, but I would say tenants are slower to make decisions, which has led to some longer lead time in terms of leasing up vacant space. But there are still active tenants looking in the market, and we're in discussions on a lot of our vacancy in the portfolio now.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just, Marc, on One Vanderbilt, you guys have finished the construction loan, so yes, sort of going against the list, the checklist that you guys signed off. As you guys think about, especially in light of leasing activity that you have, as you think about
componenttext: Just, Marc, on One Vanderbilt, you guys have finished the construction loan, so yes, sort of going against the list, the checklist that you guys signed off. As you guys think about, especially in light of leasing activity that you have, as you think about next steps, whether it's JV or leasing -- you guys have paid off like almost $1 billion, I think, of incremental debt, so in a sense, you've shored up the balance sheet. Do you still feel like you need to JV it before you get substantially more leasing done? Or do you feel that if you get more leasing done, there's more value to be extracted when you do -- if you should bring in a JV partner?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a great question, Alex. I just want to clarify one thing. I don't think we felt or feel the need, I guess, the need to JV it. From day 1, I've always said we had absolute flexibility to build it out of cash flow as we go forward over the next 4
componenttext: Yes, it's a great question, Alex. I just want to clarify one thing. I don't think we felt or feel the need, I guess, the need to JV it. From day 1, I've always said we had absolute flexibility to build it out of cash flow as we go forward over the next 4 years or bring in a JV partner. So the -- I would characterize it more as an intent and desire to bring in a JV partner, which is there simply because of the scale of the project and for the significant amount of yield enhancement we can create by bringing in a JV partner, obviously, at the right time given that our cost basis in the property is low and there's a lot of execution in terms of the development and the leasing for which there's a lot of fee income that's associated with that. So I think it's always been our goal from the outset to bring in a JV partner. I think the kind of schedule we had -- I had mentioned to investors at the beginning of the year was something along the lines of toward the end of this year to start to get to what we would consider more serious discussions with investors, knowing that we had to get a few milestones behind us in order to best position our presentation of this project to shareholders. And I think we've done that. I'd say we've done it as good or better than I even could have contemplated in terms of -- we have kind of best-of-class financing. The site, if you or others on the phone haven't seen it recently, it's really exciting and, I think, very impactful to walk over to 42nd and Vanderbilt just -- and get a sense of the scope of the project and the location of the project in its direct proximity to Grand Central and just how extraordinary it will be when that building is up in 4 years. The response from the tenant community so far has been nothing short of excellent in terms of having, I would say, checked every single box that we possibility could check in what you would want to do in delivering a best-of-class office building, with an understanding that tenants in the 50,000 to 250,000 square foot range typically are not making those kind of space commitments much more than 18 to 24 months ahead of time, which, given our schedule, would put the bulk of that leasing effort sometime towards the end of '17 and into '18, I think 2018 being the kind of the sweet spot of our marketing efforts. So with that said, we are in front of -- we're having discussions with a number of different potential JV partners. The good news is we're on a path, and I feel very comfortable that we'll be able to achieve our goals. But obviously, our goals are to make sure that the deal is properly structured with the kind of partner that shares our view and vision for long-term ownership and, on an economic basis, that's equitable and fair for both parties. So I think that we're doing -- we're on track there, and we'll just see how it goes.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But I mean, the point is, do you feel that it's better -- it's more prudent to JV it because it's a really large project? Or it sounds like you don't feel like you're giving up upside because once you have more leasing done, it would seem like a JV
componenttext: Okay. But I mean, the point is, do you feel that it's better -- it's more prudent to JV it because it's a really large project? Or it sounds like you don't feel like you're giving up upside because once you have more leasing done, it would seem like a JV partner would pay more for it. And you said, Marc, your spend now through next year really isn't that much given it's just dirt right now. It's not like you have a structure up.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Alex, I'm not speaking as to exact timing, so whether it's the beginning of the year, middle of the year, end of the year next year, I mean, I think you got to trust us to do the right thing by the asset. We -- I don't think -- we've done a lot o
componenttext: Yes. And Alex, I'm not speaking as to exact timing, so whether it's the beginning of the year, middle of the year, end of the year next year, I mean, I think you got to trust us to do the right thing by the asset. We -- I don't think -- we've done a lot of really successful joint ventures, successful for us, successful for our JV partners. I think we're very skilled at this in terms of, most importantly, selecting the right partner, having the right structure, sharing the right vision and then obviously, getting the right economic package for both parties. So I'm confident we will do a good job there. We don't feel pressure. We don't feel the need. There is a desire for the reasons that I mentioned. The timing, I think you got to leave to us to be the measure of when the right time to do it is. But we're not the kind of people that try to grab the last dollar. We don't warehouse space when we think rents are ticking up. It's a business. We've got a lot of other projects and investments to focus on beyond One Vanderbilt, so we don't want to let it consume us. It's as important and spectacular as it is. It's one investment, and this is a $20 billion-plus company. So we have a lot of other things we're focused on as well. And I think we'll take it in due course, and we'll time it for when it's optimal to do it. And I don't think we're going to ever look back. We never look back and say, oh, should've, could've. It'll be fine when we get it done.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just quickly, second question. Matt, you didn't mention guidance. Your beat onto The Street was pretty big in the third quarter. Is there anything offsetting in the fourth quarter that we should be thinking about that would affect the run rate? Because it looks like otherwise, it's like $1.35 type-ish number for the fourth quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: To be at the upper end of our range implies a $1.39 fourth quarter, to be at the upper end of our either normalized or absolute guidance range. We are certainly trending at the high end of our range. Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, there aren't many
componenttext: To be at the upper end of our range implies a $1.39 fourth quarter, to be at the upper end of our either normalized or absolute guidance range. We are certainly trending at the high end of our range. Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, there aren't many anomalies like we've seen in the -- or nonrecurring items like we've seen in the third quarter, so it should be a pretty clean quarter. And we look at it within the range, at the upper end to maybe slightly ahead but not warranting to change the guidance.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Feldman with Bank of America.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess going back to One Vanderbilt, I mean, we have seen the higher end of the market, see some slowdown from hedge funds, financials under pressure. What are you guys monitoring as you think about -- you remain confident in the project, but what are yo
componenttext: I guess going back to One Vanderbilt, I mean, we have seen the higher end of the market, see some slowdown from hedge funds, financials under pressure. What are you guys monitoring as you think about -- you remain confident in the project, but what are you monitoring, what should The Street be monitoring as they think about your prospects to be successful there and hit your target rents?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's important to keep things in perspective as far as the timing goes. We don't deliver this building until -- for occupancy until 2020. So to measure the depth of the market by what's happening today in 2016 at the high end of the market I don't r
componenttext: Well, it's important to keep things in perspective as far as the timing goes. We don't deliver this building until -- for occupancy until 2020. So to measure the depth of the market by what's happening today in 2016 at the high end of the market I don't really think is necessarily the barometer that anybody should be focused on. I think that whether the market is robust or not, this is a unique product that offers a unique value proposition to those tenants that need the finest office product in the world. And we know that it's going to be received a warm welcome because the feedback that we get from tenants today as they evaluate the project really don't look at it on a dollars-per-square-foot basis. They look at it on the cost-per-seat basis. And what the building offers from an efficiency point of view, meaning the amount of -- the lesser amount of square footage per employee that the tenants can occupy in this building, offset because of the column-free floors, the amount of infrastructure that's already baked into the building, and the amount of amenity space that tenants house outside of their demised premises allow them to reduce their total occupancy cost per head. And I really think that as we get closer to the prime lease-up period, we're going to be converting those conversations that we're already having with prospective tenants over to leases. And just I think -- and we'll speak to it in greater detail at the Investor Conference, but the rents that we're targeting are not the high end of the -- not the highest end of the market, surprisingly enough. When you really normalize the rents for the majority of the office space in this building, you get into a -- one could argue is an affordable rent for those tenants who need the best product in the world.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Are you able to quantify the -- in terms of the conversations you're having, like how many square feet of interest there really is at this point?
componenttext: Okay. Are you able to quantify the -- in terms of the conversations you're having, like how many square feet of interest there really is at this point?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I have a presentation an hour after this call today for 0.5 million square foot. I had 2 presentations last week, and I'm probably running at a clip of 1 to 3 presentations almost every single week. The majority, you'll be interested to know, are fi
componenttext: Well, I have a presentation an hour after this call today for 0.5 million square foot. I had 2 presentations last week, and I'm probably running at a clip of 1 to 3 presentations almost every single week. The majority, you'll be interested to know, are financial-related businesses, and most of them are in the 100,000 to 200,000 square foot range, some as small as 30,000 to 60,000 square feet. And I point that out because when you're in that size range, as Marc mentioned earlier, we're early to the game for those type of tenants to really pull the trigger on a decision. They have to be -- they're educating themselves with the opportunity. They're preparing themselves to make a decision, but they need it closer to the finish line for delivery before they actually pull the trigger.

componenttext: Hopefully, that answers your question, Jamie, put you a little bit at ease on One Vanderbilt. Let's move to the next question, which, hopefully, is not One Vanderbilt. Operator?
